PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
THESE FORESTS INCLUDE:

PARA.TAB: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and Other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PETITION.PARA: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PARA.TAB: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values

PETITION.PARA: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses our concern over the issue of East Timor.
Your petitioners urge the Senate to:
1. Ban all military aid to Indonesia because of its illegal occupation of East Timor and the gross abuse of human rights to its people.
2. Do not pursue foreign policy with Indonesia at the expense of human rights violations in East Timor.
3. Reverse the decision of the Australian recognition of Indonesia as ruler of East Timor.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia, and many species in these forests, are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licenses unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,
3.takes steps to ensure the rapid transfer of the wood products industry from all native forests and on to plantations, tree crops and agroforestry.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Eastlink
PETITION.PARA: The undersigned citizens petition the Senate of the Australian Parliament requesting the establishment of an all party Senate Inquiry into Eastlink, the proposed connection to the National Grid and associated decision making processes.

PARA.TAB: Eastlink,
1. Is contrary to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in their 1992 Report, titled Gas and Electricity.

2. Is proceeding without proper comparison of other options for meeting Queensland's future energy needs. There has been no proper comparison of impacts on rural productivity, economic, environment, health, development or lifestyles issues.
3. Work on Eastlink easement acquisition occurred prior to parliamentary or public debate on the options for Queensland.
4. Eastlink itself will not be adequate for Interstate trading and would entail considerable further upgrading and expenditure on additional High Voltage Lines and switching station.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows: that the Senate quickly and purposefully pass the proposed unamended Land Bill that will give dispossessed Aboriginal citizens the potential to purchase and own land.

PARA.TAB: To the Western Australian Green Senators we are specifically concerned that the Labour party may "get off the hook" again as they were able to in Western Australia when National land rights were proposed. It would be forever a blight on Western Australian citizens if they were responsible yet again for a failure of land rights legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)Poly Recyclers Pty Ltd of Brendale, Queensland, manufactures a soil retention device, Enviroedge, from 100 per cent mixed post-consumer plastic waste,

(ii)this company has developed a technique for combining different types of waste plastic, thereby enabling the one million tonnes of plastics presently being placed in landfill in Australia to be recycled, and
(iii)the product Enviroedge attracts a sales tax of 21 per cent whilst other garden edging made from timber, concrete and plastic, which is not recycled, does not attract the same sales tax penalty;

PARA.TAB: (b)declares that Poly Recyclers Pty Ltd, an Australia company contributing to the environmental, social and economic health of Australia, suffers a serious commercial disadvantage because of the imposition of this unjustified, unilateral sales tax; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TAB.TAB: (i)the persistence of factors impeding the progress of women through to the upper ranks of management in both the public and private sectors despite the Government's apparent efforts in the areas of affirmative action, equal opportunity and sex discrimination,
(ii)that whilst women make up just over 42 per cent of the Australian work force, they account for less than 3 per cent of senior management jobs and directorships, and

(iii)that this situation, as well as income inequality, exists for women despite their increasing rate of participation in the work force and despite the self-evident principle of equal pay for equal work being embraced as far back as 1972; and

PARA.TAB: (c)recognises that, despite the advances made by women in the work force to date, they are far from achieving real equality.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TAB.TAB: (i)with concern, that the impasse over the West Indies coverage was only settled in the end by Network Ten stepping into the breach, and
(ii)that the Minister stood by impotently as his television anti-siphoning rules failed their first major test; and

PARA.TAB: (e)reminds the Minister that he is unlikely to have continuing good fortune the next time his unworkable rules are put to the test by the television industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)condemns:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Federal Government for making a mockery of forest conservation by hoodwinking the community into believing that old-growth and high conservation value forests are being protected through the current rapid assessment process, and
(ii)the release for logging and roads of a further 53 coupes from the list of areas said to have been protected by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in late January 1995;

PARA.TAB: (b)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that 8 coupes in Western Australia's central forest region have been given over to logging on the basis that they do not have the conservation values for which they were originally listed, even though these areas have not been properly assessed by either the State or Federal Governments, when these areas represent much of what is left of the jarrah forest,

(ii)that, in approving road construction in Peak forest, the Government is committing environmental vandalism in a forest which has been given an interim listing on the register of the National Estate and is risking further destruction through the introduction of dieback into the area, and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Government to implement policies that will ensure a long-term solution to conservation concerns and the needs of timber workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)on 7 July 1995, the $17 million replica of the barque, HMS Endeavour, which will be touring the east coast of Australia on an historic journey marking the 225th anniversary of Captain Cook's voyage, will be unable to gain access as planned to the port of Cooktown, where the original Endeavour spent 47 days,

(ii)the Endeavour will be unable to gain access to the port because it is presently too shallow and, despite several representations from the people of Cooktown, the Queensland State Government has refused to dredge it because of yet-to-be-substantiated environmental concerns,
(iii)the harbour has been dredged previously and hydrographic surveys show that, while the low tide mark is presently 1.2 metres, in 1991 it was 1.4 metres and in 1949 was 2.7 metres,
(iv)the dredging of the harbour would involve removing approximately 200 000 cubic metres of silt from an area 700 metres long, 100 metres wide and 3 metres deep, at a cost of around $500 000,

(v)Cooktown is a viable port for maritime tourism and commercial fishing, however, these industries have not expanded, with maritime tourism visits being reduced later in 1995 due to inadequate access to the port, and

(vi)an alternative proposal to anchor the Endeavour off Grassy Hill in Cooktown and to ferry residents out to the ship is unacceptable, as the transportation process would be unsafe, requiring unrealistic weather conditions, because the ship will of necessity be anchored 1 kilometre offshore in deep and exposed waters; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Federal Government to undertake an immediate environmental assessment of the effect of dredging proposals for the port of Cooktown on the surrounding environment to:

TAB.TAB: (i)ensure that dredging of the Cooktown port occurs in an environmentally sound manner in time for visit of the Endeavour on 7 July 1995, and
(ii)open the port of Cooktown to allow the expansion of maritime tourism, commercial fishing and other viable industries which require port access.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My personal explanation relates to comments made in the other place last night by the temporary member for Bass, Mrs Silvia Smith. The Hansard now records what she said concerning me. I believe that her comments verge on criminal libel, and I will be writing to the House of Representatives Privileges Committee requesting it to deal with the outrageous allegations made against me by her. I will quote certain sections of what she said and then give my response to the parliament. Mrs Smith said:

SPEECH.PARA: It goes to the very core of our integrity as parliamentarians.
This is the disturbing matter that she had raised. She goes on:
I am talking about being paid for supposedly objective political comment.

PARA.TAB: The specific individual I refer to is Senator Eric Abetz. Senator Abetz, in the Hobart Mercury of 7 January this year, made a comment for which he received financial return.

SPEECH.PARA: I can categorically say to the Senate and the people of Australia that that is absolutely and utterly untrue. I would use another word, but that would be unparliamentary. The simple fact is that there is no substance to the allegation in any shape or form. It really does reflect on the person who would make such an allegation. I would say to her: present the proof or have the guts to say it outside of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I have been advised that as early on as January of this year, this particular member of the House of Representatives has been trying to run with this story and none of the media would run with it, until her disgraceful performance last night. Silvia Smith kept on by saying:

I have in my possession a copy of Senator Abetz's entry in the Register of Senators' Interests. In that document he discloses that he receives a substantial source of income from the legal firm Abetz, Curtis and Docking.

SPEECH.PARA: That also is untrue. At no stage did I indicate whether it was a small amount or a substantial amount. The standard form says that. All that I indicated was that I received an income from a legal firm—not Abetz Curtis and Docking but Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a different firm.

—It is a completely different firm. It absolutely galls me to have to explain my personal business dealings and have a reflection on my professional integrity as a lawyer and also have the reflection that then casts upon my family, my relatives, my business associates and my friends because they then wonder what is the truth.

PARA.TAB: When the state parliament of Tasmania ratified my nomination as a senator on 22 February 1994, I resigned from the partnership of Abetz Curtis and Docking. As part of the deal with my other partners, it was agreed that as my partnership share I would obtain another office. If I can briefly explain, Abetz Curtis and Docking ran two offices, one in the city of Hobart and one in the suburb of Kingston in which I live. It was agreed that I would get the business Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston; namely, the Kingston firm. It was agreed and I immediately thereafter set about to sell the firm Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston, of which I was the sole proprietor. Indeed, ironic as it is, I sold it to a legal firm called Shields Heritage, which is right smack bang in the middle of the electorate of Bass.

I am employed as a consultant to the firm of Shields Heritage and not Abetz Curtis and Docking. When Shields Heritage bought the firm Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston, they wanted to keep my name in relation to the firm and it is now known as Abetz and Co. in association with Shields Heritage.

The member for Bass got it wrong in relation to my disclosing that I received a substantial source of income. All I said was that I received income not from Abetz Curtis and Docking but from Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston. Indeed, I have the Register of Senators' Interests in front of me and it is clearly in the register that the nature of any other income was from Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston. It shows the lack of research done by the member.

I also indicate that the person in Abetz Curtis and Docking who handled all the trust bank business was my partner, Mr Roger Curtis, who remained with the city based branch of our former legal company. I did not have carriage of any trust bank work. Mrs Smith went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Abetz has committed the worst of all political crimes . . .

To be accused of a crime is, I believe, one of the most outrageous allegations that can be made and should not be made lightly. The federal member for Bass did not have the courtesy to ring me about these allegations. I indicate to the house that this morning, albeit at 9.30 a.m., I was still getting the answer phone in Mrs Smith's office. I rang her office to do her the courtesy of indicating that I would be responding. One would hope that Mrs Smith would engage in those sorts of courtesies in the future before she makes those sorts of scurrilous attacks.

PARA.TAB: She goes on to say that I have treated my public office and all Tasmanians with contempt. With great respect, she is the one who has treated them with contempt by feeding them untruths under parliamentary privilege, not having the guts to say it outside of this house so that the full force of the law could be brought to bear upon her. She then said:

SPEECH.PARA: He should realise that there is far more to the successful operation of a bank than paying his legal firm a fat retainer.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's women in politics for you.

—This matter, with due respect, is a lot more serious than that interjection would indicate. The seriousness of this is that I have been accused of obtaining a huge, substantial, fat—all those sorts of words—financial benefit in making some comments in relation to a dispute within the trust bank of Tasmania at the time.

PARA.TAB: She went on to say that this is the most appalling abuse of political position. I say the most appalling abuse of political position is to use parliamentary privilege to peddle untruths to reflect on a fellow member of this parliament and accuse him of committing crimes, as she has done. I simply say to the house and to the parliament that I take great offence at the allegations made. There is not a shred of evidence in support of the allegations made.

Let me simply place on the record that on 22 February 1994 I severed all ties with the legal firm known as Abetz Curtis and Docking. I traded as a sole trader from that date under the name Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston until 1 July 1994 when the transfer was made of Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston to the firm of Shields Heritage. Since 1 July 1994, I have been employed as a consultant to Shields Heritage. The comments that were in the Hobart Mercury on 7 January 1995 were made some six or seven months after I stopped being a principal in a firm and were made 12 months after I had severed my ties with the firm of Abetz Curtis and Docking.

To the best of my knowledge—and I am having this checked today—my firm, Abetz Curtis and Docking—Kingston, which I traded with, received no moneys in any shape or form from the trust bank in relation to legal advice, because they, of course, had their tie-up with my former partner, Mr Roger Curtis. I do not know whether the firm of Shields Heritage has any funding from the trust bank, because my position in that firm is simply that of an employee. I do the work that I am asked to do by my employers, the partners of Shields Heritage.

The allegations that have been made are scurrilous, untrue, shameful and disgraceful. They bring this parliament into disrepute. If anybody ought to be resigning over this, it ought to be the federal member for Bass. Labor, I believe, has a very real responsibility to either disendorse her or dissociate itself from her and discipline her. The very least that the federal member for Bass could do would be to apologise for the slur on my professional integrity as a lawyer, for the slur on my integrity as a parliamentarian and for the slur and doubt that are undoubtedly cast upon members of my family, my former professional colleagues and all my friends and associates in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: during Senator Abetz's personal explanation—I did not want to interrupt at the time—there was a comment from one of the National Party senators. I am unable to ascertain which one it was, but it was certainly one of two. It was about the standard of behaviour of women in politics. I found that particularly offensive and would like it withdrawn.
—I did not hear it. I invite the person who said it to volunteer to stand up and withdraw it. Unless somebody is prepared to withdraw, there is little more that I can do to pursue it.
—Mr Deputy President, not to blow this situation out of proportion, which Sue West is so capable of doing—
—Senator West, thank you.

—Senator Sue West is certainly capable of blowing situations out of proportion and that is what she is doing now. I did make that interjection. Before I withdraw, I would like to know what objection Sue West has to that interjection.
—Order!
—You idiot!

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I heard the interjection from Senator McGauran. It was simply this: `That's women in politics for you.' You stand condemned by your own words. I bet that every woman politician in this chamber, and most male politicians in this chamber, would be as offended as we are on this side of the chamber.
—On a point of order—
—Senator Macdonald, unless you have got something to contribute, I will rule on the point of order.
—That is just an abuse of the procedures.

—As the clerk advises—and I concur with the sentiments expressed—strictly speaking, it is not disorderly and it is not requiring of a withdrawal. I think Senator McGauran did withdraw it, anyway. Under the standing orders, I am unable to ask him to withdraw.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: while we are dealing with withdrawals, I think Senator Burns ought to withdraw the interjection he made while Senator McGauran was speaking.
—I did not hear that, either. I am sure Senator Burns is an honourable person and he will withdraw if he said something offensive.
—It was only advice by way of an observation. I withdraw it.
—I did not hear what the interjection was and, considering it was a reflection on myself, I ask Senator Burns to repeat it.
—I said you were an idiot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That government business notice of motion No. 2 standing in the name of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) for this day, relating to the consideration of legislation, be postponed till the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a motion to which at least Senator Harradine and perhaps some other senators may wish to speak, so it might be appropriate if I speak to it at this point. The reason for this being proposed is that senators would be aware that the issue of the cut-off motion has been one of concern now for some period of time. As Manager of Government Business in the Senate, I have been concerned about what I genuinely believe are some unintended consequences with the existing order of the Senate in relation to the cut-off issue.

PARA.TAB: I gave notice of a motion earlier this day with a preferred set of words from a government perspective. I proposed that particular notice of motion on the basis that, of course, the government has an amendment—that is, an amendment to a Senate order—and we have a situation where clearly the bill we have just dealt with, the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill, which the government wants to debate today, was introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 December last year. Therefore, it has been publicly available for consultation and scrutiny of all senators and, more broadly, in the community since that particular time.

Because that legislation was passed in the House of Representatives this sitting, the existing cut-off motion, the current order of the Senate, prevents debate on that bill in this sitting. So that obviously produces a situation where a bill introduced into the parliament in December of last year could not effectively be passed at the earliest until May 1994 without an exemption.

The notice of motion I gave earlier today seeks to give full effect to the principle of introducing in one sittings and debating in the next. That was an objective spelt out, I believe, by Senator Gareth Evans on 18 August 1993 in the statement he made to the Senate about accountability and Senate legislative processes.

I think it is proper to allow senators to give consideration, at least for a short period over the next 24 hours, to the notice of motion I have given today as well as the existing amendment which appears already on the red. I suggest that adjourning government business notice of motion No. 2 is the appropriate way to deal with this issue.

The government made very clear its position on 18 August 1993. Senator Evans, in what I think was a very important and clear contribution at that time, spoke about a reasonable concern of the Senate `to want commitments about the early access of all honourable senators to legislation and to the documentation that goes with that legislation to enable a reasonable time to prepare a response to it'. That is a principle that the government has accepted and has committed itself to work to achieving. We have always made clear to the Senate—and to a greater or lesser extent in the Senate I think senators have understood—that there are certain urgent and budget related bills that ought not properly for the good government of the nation be caught up in this particular cut-off procedure.
Senator Evans made clear in that contribution to the Senate in 1993 what the government was committing itself to doing. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we are prepared to do is address very directly the two basic issues . . . One is the dates on which bills are introduced and become available on the public record—the date on which we have access to the text and the supporting documentation. The second thing we are prepared to do is address the question of scheduling of the actual debates—the way in which those bills, whenever introduced, are actually dealt with.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: As to the introduction of bills, I am prepared on behalf of the government to undertake to introduce in either the House of Representatives or the Senate at least half the bills that are proposed for passage this session by 21 October.

SPEECH.PARA: He also said:

PARA.TAB: I further undertake to ensure that the remainder of the bills that are proposed for passage this session be introduced, either in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, by 18 November this year.

SPEECH.PARA: He talked then about some of the more general principles involved and said:

We have decided in principle that in future we will introduce legislation—to the extent it proves possible; I have to add that qualification—on the basis of introduction in one sittings for debate in the next. I guess that that is the optimal position for everyone in this chamber. It will give everyone the opportunity in the parliamentary break to fully consider their position and take such advice as they want, research it, produce sensible responses and deal with it.
He also went on in terms of the commitments that he made at that time to say:

I think it would probably take two or more sittings to fully implement a system based on, so far as possible, introducing legislation one sitting and debating it the next. All I can say is that steps are now being taken to make a significant start on it in these sittings; in other words, to try to work out, right now, what the legislative program will be for the first sittings next year and a way in which a significant number of the bills for passage next sittings—the autumn sittings next year—can be at least introduced and put on the table by the time we get up in December. I am not sure how big a start it is possible to make on that, but we are trying hard to do it.

Try hard we have since that period, with I think a considerable degree of success. There are unintended consequences in relation to the amount of legislation that has been caught up in the House of Representatives, with the situation that unless a bill has been introduced into the Senate in one particular session it cannot be debated until the subsequent session. That is the current situation. That was not intended at the time. I believe there is an acceptance from all senators that that situation ought to be addressed and the standing orders of the Senate changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that idea from?

—Senator, that is quite clear because, as I understand it, you are comfortable with the proposal that is currently on the red and are willing to support the change that is envisaged. The intention of the government has always been to see a bill introduced into parliament in one session for passage in the next. My reason for seeking a deferral until the next day of sitting for this particular matter is to ensure that further discussions can take place amongst senators and parties to see if agreement can be reached on this issue. I think that is a sensible approach.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to take too much time of the Senate. There is a notice of motion that senators can give consideration to. That notice of motion stands in my name and was given this morning. I ask senators to look carefully at these commitments that have been made by the government on the issue of introduction of legislation in one session for passage the next. I believe the notice of motion that I have given does address that commitment and does address this issue in a way that will best serve the interests of all senators to ensure that there is transparency and there is an opportunity for senators and members of the general community to have the maximum opportunity to examine legislation, develop their views on it and receive input from other interested parties.

At this point, I believe it is appropriate that we do defer this matter for a short period of time so we can further address the options informally and so the Senate can make a final determination on this issue. We should not have to deal with the consistent procedural problems that we faced with what I believe are genuinely unintended consequences of the cut-off motion as it now stands as an order of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the opposition, all I say is that although Senator Gareth Evans made the government's intention very clear earlier, today Senator Faulkner has made it very unclear what the government's current intentions are. The coalition agreed with the motion that is now on the Notice Paper, and Senator Faulkner did mention that to Senator Harradine. Now the government seems to have got it wrong. Senator Faulkner gave notice of a new motion today, and I believe it is a very sensible idea that we postpone this for 24 hours so that we can have a good look at the new motion and, of course, so that the government can get a grip on its own motion in the next 24 hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On that point, I think the standing orders are a little vague as to whether or not a senator can debate a postponement motion. Of course, when a motion to adjourn the debate is put, there is no debate permitted on that motion. Under standing order 201(3) it makes it perfectly clear when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: When a debate is adjourned, by motion or by the granting of leave for a Senator to continue the Senator's speech, the resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting without any question being put, unless a motion is agreed to fixing another time for the resumption of the debate.

A motion to adjourn the debate is not open to debate or amendment. Clearly, if we have a motion to postpone a matter to a particular day, for example 5 May 1995, then surely that must be open to debate because it is a motion to postpone not a motion to adjourn in the strict sense of standing order 201. I am not arguing the point—I thank the Senate for leave to speak to this matter—but I simply make the point for future reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that. I draw your attention to standing order 67 and remind you that we are not adjourning debate, we are postponing a motion. Standing order 67 says, `such a motion shall be put and determined without amendment or debate.'

—I appreciate that and stand corrected. The matter that has been put before the Senate by Senator Faulkner sounded eminently reasonable as Senator Faulkner always sounds, but that is not precisely what was meant at the time. I know full well what was meant at that particular time and I do not think Senator Faulkner was involved in the discussions at that time. The discussions were about the accountability package that the government was going to bring forward. We know that there have been problems right along the line with that accountability package. I for one can stand here and say that the government has not delivered on the accountability package. It is trying to weasel out of it in respect of the matter before us today—the Auditor-General legislation. I will not go into that.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the matters that Senator Faulkner raised. As far as I am concerned—and I believe as far as the opposition, the Australia Democrats and the Greens are concerned—the integrity of the Chamarette motion would be sullied if the proposal, as put in Senator Faulkner's notice of motion today, were actually carried. That would mean that it would enable the government of the day to come in on the last day of this session of parliament in April—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we are not sitting in April, Senator.
—I think we are sitting at least the first week in April.
—Close to it.

—Yes, close to it. It would enable the government to go into the House of Representatives on the last day of the session and lob 50 packages of bills into that House and have them debated in the May sittings and then it would expect us to deal with them in the same sittings. That would completely undermine the very important Chamarette motion which was adopted by this chamber. I am not going to support that. That is precisely what this motion will do, but there will be more on that tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: Let us make it perfectly clear, apropos of what I said about Senator Faulkner, that it sounded very reasonable. The government is not reasonable about these issues. The government is very irrational about these issues. Look at how it is dealing with legislation at this point in time. We have a piece of legislation that was introduced into the House of Representatives and came into this chamber this session—the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. That bill goes to the very heart of the government's responsibilities on protecting the human rights of persons who are likely to be forced back to China to face coerced abortions or sterilisations. That is what that bill does.

That bill came before this chamber and was referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Even the majority of the committee was less than enthusiastic about it. There were dissenting reports by the opposition, the Democrats and me. I know the Greens are opposed to it as well. What does the government do? Instead of bringing that particular bill on for debate or seeking to exempt it from the cut-off point—and it would not have got that—it introduced the legislation in even worse form in the House of Representatives late last night, expecting it to be debated today. Why has the government done that? Because it wants to have a trigger for a double dissolution. That is the only reason why it wants to do it. That is precisely the only reason that it wants to do it.

So the government is playing fast and loose. It is using grubby political tactics and using those who are likely to suffer the cruellest of human rights violations as a political football. The government is cynical, callous and corrupt. Any government that would do that is corrupt. I must say that any government which would play off the human rights of persons for a grubby political purpose is corrupt. I have never said that about a government before in all my 20 years in this place, but I say it now. Today is one of the darkest days that this parliament has known because of what this government is doing about that legislation.

Why didn't the government seek to bring the legislation before us so that it could be properly discussed and so that there could be amendments brought forward by the opposition, by the Democrats, by the Greens and by me to ensure our international responsibility not to refoule—that is, not to send back persons to their persecutors? Why were we not given that chance? The reason we were not given that chance is that, had we amended that legislation to provide that sort of protection and had it gone back to the House of Representatives and the government used its numbers there, it would not have been a double dissolution trigger. As we all know under the constitution, for a double dissolution trigger the bill must be introduced into the House of Representatives. The minister is not down there, but the government has introduced it there for that grubby political purpose. No-one should trust this government again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Motion (by Senator Parer and Senator Kernot) proposed:
(1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, be appointed to inquire into and report on or before 24 October 1995, on the following matters:

TAB.TAB: (a)the reasons for and the scope of the noise impact associated with the opening of the parallel runway at Kingsford Smith Airport (KSA), including the impact on schools and learning, residents' health, the environment, and property values;
(b)the reasons for the discrepancies between the predicted and actual noise impact associated with the parallel runway, and proposals to prevent such discrepancies in future;

(c)the likely effectiveness of the operational and remedial measures that have been implemented, or are planned to be implemented, to reduce the noise impact of KSA, and whether there are other potentially effective measures that could be implemented;
(d)the likely effectiveness of the arrangements for monitoring the noise impact of the airport, and whether there are other monitoring measures that could be implemented;
(e)the planned development of Sydney West Airport (SWA), including its noise impact on the communities in the vicinity of the airport;
(f)the environmental implications of airport leasing, with particular reference to the following scenarios:
(i)private leasing of KSA separately from SWA,
(ii)private leasing of KSA together with SWA, and
(iii)retention of KSA in full public control;
(g)the possible need for further public consultation on, and environmental assessment of, the operations at KSA and the planned development of SWA; and
(h)any other matter arising in the course of the inquiry that the committee considers is reasonably relevant in reporting on the foregoing matters.

PARA.TAB: (2)The committee consist of seven Senators:

TAB.TAB: (a)three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: (3)The committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4)(a)The chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members of the committee;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;
(d)the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and
(e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

PARA.TAB: (5)The quorum of the committee be three members.

(6)The committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(7)The committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.
(8)Without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the committee observe the following procedures:

TAB.TAB: (a)As a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination.

(b)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the committee by that person in accordance with that statement.
(c)Evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a subcommittee resolves to hear evidence in camera.
(d)The chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

TAB.TAB: (e)The recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990, as varied by the Senate from time to time, concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings.
(f)The secretary is authorised to supply for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports.
(g)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the committee be published.
(h)Subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person, be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

PARA.TAB: (9)(a)The terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media.
(b)Written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard.

(10)The committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)The committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)The committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not formally oppose the motion, but I seek leave to incorporate a statement as to why we oppose it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE MOTION ON SYDNEY AIRPORT
The inquiry into the operations of Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport advocated by the Australian Democrats and the Opposition should not be supported.
It is breathtaking for its hypocrisy and lack of understanding of the issues surrounding the operations of Sydney's Kingsford Smith and the Government's plans for Badgery's Creek (Sydney West).
The Government has instituted measures to ameliorate the effects of aircraft noise while ensuring the airport is operating safely and efficiently.

An analysis of operations of the Airport by the CAA over the December/January period compared with operations before the new runway opened on 4 November 1994 demonstrates that some 58000 people are better off under the new arrangements.

This does not mean that people are not suffering significantly from aircraft noise. They are. And that's why on 8 December 1994 the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport announced a number of measures to minimise the number of people affected by aircraft noise.
These include:

PARA.TAB: Establishment of designated flight paths

SPEECH.PARA: These are designed to confine overflights to the narrowest flight paths in order to minimise the number of people affected.
These flight paths apply to all jet take-offs and landings.
The arrangements were introduced on 2 February 1995 and are working effectively.

PARA.TAB: Requirement for jet aircraft to depart from the southern end of the main north-south runway

SPEECH.PARA: By requiring take-offs from the southern end of the runway, jets attain more height before reaching residential areas.
These procedures have been implemented and are operating well.

PARA.TAB: Curfew enforcement

SPEECH.PARA: The Curfew Regulations have been amended to provide for financial penalties for unauthorised operations during the curfew. The regulations providing for a maximum penalty of $25,000 for breaches of the curfew were put in place before Christmas 1994.

PARA.TAB: Operational noise control

SPEECH.PARA: All take-offs must be to the south of the airport over Botany Bay unless otherwise required on safety or weather reasons.
No take-offs to the north from the new runway.

PARA.TAB: Noise Treatment Measures

SPEECH.PARA: The program of voluntary acquisition of homes within the 40ANEF noise contour and the insulation of schools, colleges, hospitals, child and health care facilities down to the 25 ANEF contour is well underway.
Residences between the 30 and 40 ANEF contour will also receive insulation. The Department of Administrative Services has been given responsibility for managing the insulation program.
This program is in line with international noise amelioration practices.
The program has been accelerated and is scheduled to be completed in 3 years.

PARA.TAB: Sydney West Airport

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's commitment to the construction of a major runway at Sydney West Airport (Badgery's Creek) by 1998/99 is unequivocal.
To date the Government has expended $150 million to acquire the Airport site, purchase noise affected properties, build local access roads and conduct concept design.
The Government has committed a further $120 million for the building of a 2900 metre runway which will be capable of accommodating medium haul B747 operations.
We have commenced an EIS on road link construction at an approximate cost of $200 million to coincide with the opening of the 2900 metre runway.
We have also started a joint Commonwealth/State engineering study to secure a rail corridor as a basis for effective rail links between Sydney West, Kingsford Smith Airport and the city.
These measures constitute a comprehensive approach to the operational issues concerned with Sydney Airport.
The other issues raised in the notice of motion are being addressed in the Federal Airports Scoping Study on the leasing of the airports. The results of the scoping study will be available shortly.
The matters are being addressed and this notice of motion is redundant. However noting the numbers are against us we acknowledge that the Select Committee will be established.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on a supplementary hearing arising from the consideration of additional estimates 1994-95 and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report has its genesis in public concern about the role of the National Media Liaison Service, commonly known as—
—Wrong report, Senator. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. The matter can be raised at another time when they have got their act together.

—There is a very real problem, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Notice Paper tells us Senator Coates was to present a report on a supplementary hearing arising from consideration of the 1994-95 additional estimates but we are not told which aspect of the additional estimates was being considered. That ought to be clarified. Also, there was to be the tabling and consideration of another report of Senator Coates's committee last week, which we did not reach. It appears now that Senator Coates is forgetting about the one dealing with the National Media Liaison Service and dealing with Senator Baume's office.

—Just to help Senator Abetz, the report he was just speaking to was tabled last Thursday. Senator Reid, I think, moved a motion to take note and sought leave to continue her remarks later. I think the matter will come up under committee reports on Thursday, as is the standard practice.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—This is the report on the original estimates and not the report on the supplementary estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I think this is one of the supplementary matters, but we are trying to determine which one. My understanding is that it is on the supplementary hearings but not on the hearings in relation to the National Media Liaison Service.
—Both can be debated Thursday.

—I am sure that if there is an opportunity now, and if Senator Coates is correct that this matter deals with Senator Baume's office, amongst other things, this would be a matter Senator Baume would undoubtedly wish to address. I signed the minority report in relation to that and would seek to address that as well. Unfortunately, in the confusion, because the Notice Paper does not tell us which one is going to be discussed, I prepared for the National Media Liaison Service debate as opposed to Senator Baume's—
—It was tabled days ago, and you did not notice. But that is all right.
—I am aware of that.
—Senator Abetz, you may speak to this report if you so wish.

—Now that we have clarified which report is before the Senate, I seek to address some remarks about the supplementary estimates meeting in relation to the electorate office of Senator Michael Baume. Senator Baume has been dealt with in a peculiar and vindictive manner in relation to the way the department has approached his entitlements as a senator.

PARA.TAB: The minority report dealing with Senator Michael Baume's electorate office has been signed by a number of coalition senators who very much feel that Senator Baume is quite right to feel aggrieved at the way he has been treated. I want to discuss the National Media Liaison Service and the way it engages in political behaviour in this country. The new electorate office given to Senator Michael Baume in the Commonwealth parliamentary offices requires every visitor to that office to walk past the office of the National Media Liaison Service. The service can monitor each and every single person that comes into his office.

Let us make no mistake: Senator Baume has been the brave senator who has fought and exposed the way the companies of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have dealt with pigs and the way that they have underpaid people and not put in returns. Senator Baume has been picked out for particular attention, with vitriolic responses by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) on many occasions because of his pursuit of truth. Now, when he wants to change his electorate office—after the lease on his current electorate office expired and he wanted to move—he is denied that right.

The interesting thing is that, if you are a Labor senator, like Senator Stephen Loosley, you can spend $34,000 moving out of the Commonwealth parliamentary offices into the central business district; you can get yourself some exposure and be dealt with favourably. But Senator Michael Baume is forced to move in. Why the different treatment between Senator Stephen Loosely and Senator Michael Baume? The only obvious reason is that Senator Stephen Loosley is part of the Labor Right that runs this Labor government and will always look after its mates, and Senator Michael Baume has made a name for himself in exposing some of the dubious practices of the Labor Right in his home state of New South Wales. There is no other explanation. It is so convenient to make every visitor to Senator Baume's office walk past the National Media Liaison Service office. You can say that we are paranoid—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are; never a truer word spoken.

—I said `you can say'. It is not me saying it; it is you, Senator Sherry. Unless you can come up with a cogent explanation as to why Senator Stephen Loosley was allowed to move out and why Senator Michael Baume was forced to move in and was not entitled to what every other senator in this country has been entitled to, you have got a lot to answer for. The supplementary hearings, quite frankly, were full of obfuscation. I was there for part of them and heard and saw what had occurred.
—Where is your office; are you happy with it?

—My office is in 3 Brooke Street, Hobart, not in the Commonwealth parliamentary offices—and thank goodness it is a long way away from your politically motivated National Media Liaison Service, Senator Sherry. That is what all this is about. You people are now seeking to hold on to power by any means. In this case, it is not by fair means; it is by foul means.
—How is it foul?

—Senator Sherry has asked how it is foul. If you lead with the chin, you have got to expect something to land on it. I will tell you, Senator Sherry, why it is foul. You have treated Senator Loosley to a $34,000 office. As I understand it, Senator Baume's office would have been more modest than Senator Loosley's. You have got money for Senator Loosley, but you have not got money for Senator Baume. Senator Baume wanted to move into the electorate where he actually lives. You have denied him an electorate office which is close to where he lives.
—His electorate is New South Wales.

—That is quite right. I stand corrected by Senator Sherry. I should not have said `electorate'; I should have said `community'. The point is made that it is quite appropriate for a senator to seek a space for his electorate office within the community that he identifies with, that he feels part of and where there is local knowledge of that member within that area. That is what Senator Baume has sought to do. There is nothing strange about that, but the government wants to place him up in the Commonwealth parliamentary offices where its members want to move out—people like Senator Loosley.
—Is that because they are under observation?

—No. They have the National Media Liaison Service doing the work for them. Senator Loosley does not have to be up there to observe because he has the National Media Liaison Service doing that sort of work.

PARA.TAB: We know that Senator Michael Baume has landed punch after punch on the Prime Minister and has done a fantastic job in exposing what would otherwise be called corrupt practices within company structures to avoid prosecution, the underpayment of staff, conflicts of interests and purchasing properties at a very cheap price and then being able to sell them again at a later stage. Senator Baume has exposed all of this to the parliament and to the people of Australia.

For his hard work, for his efforts in pursuing the truth, you as a government are now victimising him—and deliberately victimising him—to ensure that he does not have the sort of exposure he might otherwise enjoy as an entitlement of a senator in this place.

For Senator Sherry to seek to defend the government on this does really reflect very poorly, and indeed very sadly, on Senator Sherry. I would like to think that the reason Senator Sherry is interjecting is simply blind loyalty to his government, without any understanding of what actually occurred at the hearing, without hearing the evidence and without having read the transcript afterwards.

I am sure that any decent person having heard the evidence and having read the transcript would have come to the conclusion that we on the coalition side of this place have come to; that is, Senator Michael Baume has been dealt with in a discriminatory way and the reason for that discrimination is his party political allegiance and the excellent job that he has done in relation to exposing the Prime Minister and certain elements of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales for their very dubious practices.

I am very pleased to put my name to the minority report that has just been placed before the Senate and fully support Senator Baume in his very strong criticism of the way he has been dealt with in relation to his electorate office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for supporting the minority report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, which has been signed not only by members of this committee but also by the participating members. In fact, I think it is probably the greatest number of people signing a dissenting report that I can recall in this parliament. It shows the strength of feeling in the opposition ranks about the discriminatory and dishonest manner in which this government and this minister have dealt with this matter. I put on the record the details of the minority report. In fact, I seek leave to incorporate the minority report in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Minority Report by Coalition Members and Participating Members on the Department of Administrative Services Additional Estimates Involving Senator Baume's Electorate Office Relocation.
The failure by the Executive Government in these hearings to recognise the rights and duties of Senators examining the Estimates, should not be allowed to pass.

Grossly unsatisfactory, misleading, incorrect and non-answers from the Department of Administrative Services have compounded the serious problem of Ministerial denial of the rights of a Senator who has moved his principal place of residence, similarly to relocate his electorate office (on the expiration of its lease) into the same area.

Questions at the hearing related to the rejection by the Minister, the Honourable Frank Walker, of his Department's repeated recommendations that Senator Baume's electorate office be relocated from Wollongong to Narellan NSW.

The Minister denied a request to provide the Committee with a copy of a departmental minute to the Minister dated 8 November, 1994, requesting his permission to seek suitable office accommodation for Senator Baume in Narellan, which he had rejected; a question asking for reasons for the Minister's reversal of his earlier decision to refuse Senator Loosley's relocation out of the Sydney Commonwealth Parliamentary Offices into another CBD location with an annual rental cost of $34,000 (a relocation the Department has reported as partly due to "accommodation pressures in the CPO" while the Minister was forcibly relocating Senator Baume into the CPO offices) received the response that it was none of Senator Baume's business; officials made repeated errors of fact in their responses, for many of which they subsequently apologised saying they had not intended to mislead, and failed to answer direct questions, several of which they took on notice despite previous advice to the department that this matter would be raised in detail. No answers to these questions on notice have yet been provided.

All the questions raised in this minority report bear directly on the cost of Ministerial decisions relating to Senators' office accommodation, and are of particular significance to the estimates process when they involve rejections of departmental advice. Refusals to provide this information raise serious matters of principle affecting the Senate estimates process and merit further attention by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I incorporated that report is to dramatise just a few points. Apart from anything else, there were simply grossly unsatisfactory, misleading, incorrect and non-answers from the Department of Administrative Services. I believe that was under instructions from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who has behaved totally improperly in this matter from the very beginning.

PARA.TAB: The minister has provided no justification whatsoever for wasting something like $100,000 of taxpayers' money by refusing permission for me to have an electorate office in a cheap rental area in Narellan outside the Sydney metropolitan area and instead forcing me into the high rent central business district of Sydney. To make way for me—the department keeps on denying this—in the Commonwealth parliamentary office in Sydney, the minister ultimately agreed to move Senator Loosley, who was initially denied permission to move out of those offices, to an area which will cost the taxpayer $34,000 in rent per year against the rent of around $15,000 that would have been paid for my office in Narellan.

Senator Loosley has been allowed to move out, and the reason for the subsequent action of the minister withdrawing his objection to Senator Loosley's move is, according to the department, `accommodation pressures in the Sydney CPO'. That is why Senator Loosley was allowed to leave, but of course there was plenty of room at the inn when Senator Baume was required to move there as some kind of Christmas present.

This kind of dishonesty is just unacceptable. Let me explain to Senator Sherry how Labor members in Tasmania are discriminated for by this government. For his colleague Senator Murphy, a Labor Tasmanian, to establish an office in Launceston, the rent is $36,000 a year and the fit-out cost is $70,000—more than double the rent that I could have had for an office in Narellan and certainly far more than any fit-out cost. This is evident active discrimination by the government in Tasmania, but there is a whole schedule of them here. It is incredible. Mary Crawford in Queensland costs taxpayers $43,000 a year rent and $62,000 in fit-out costs.

I am the only person, according to the department, who has been dealt with in this way. A letter from the department says that it is unprecedented that a senator should not be allowed to have an electorate office in proximity to his principal place of residence. It is incredible that this minister, for one shameful political reason, decided that I should not be allowed to have my office there. And the political reason is that his factional mate the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) is on a two per cent margin.

I am flattered that the Minister for Administrative Services takes the view that my having an electorate office in the marginal Labor seat of Macarthur would so damage his factional mate that he would lose his seat. I must say I agree with him. I think I am an effective senator and it would probably damage the poorly performing, incompetent member for Macarthur whose only qualification for protection is that he is a member of the minister's faction and so has to be looked after.

I think my presence there may well damage his ability to be re-elected because I notice that my Wollongong office was being inundated with requests from the electors of Macarthur to look after them because their local member was so hopeless. It is helped by the fact that I used to be the member for Macarthur when it was well represented in the House of Representatives. So there are no doubt many reasons why people would prefer to ask me as a member of parliament to look after their problems than the present incompetent member.

The simple fact remains that his department recommended to this minister on several occasions, in accordance with precedent, that I should be allowed to move into the Narellan area. The location that I had found was right opposite the site of the proposed council chambers for that rapidly expanding region. In other words, it was a magnificent opportunity to get an ideal location at a very low rent, because all those developments had not yet taken place. It would have been an ideal location for an electorate office—either for a senator or for the member of the House of Representatives who was elected for that region. I would have hoped that after the next election it may have been appropriate for the House of Representatives member—who, naturally, will be a member of the Liberal Party—to convince me that it was a better location for him than for me. Whatever the situation, it was unprecedented, according to the department, that the minister rejected this recommendation.

It is improper for any minister, where he has the right or discretion to grant requests like this, not to grant them, recklessly—in other words, to refuse his permission on any grounds other than sound, sensible, rational grounds. It is illegal, in fact. That means I would have to take this dishonourable minister to the Federal Court in order to pursue it because it does not come under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I would have to spend a very large amount of money to demonstrate the illegality of this minister's behaviour.

We all know it is improper but it also happens to be illegal. While it is true that you must have the minister's approval to move your electorate office—even when your lease has expired and you are being thrown out, you still need the minister's approval—this minister refused that approval as recommended by his department in an unprecedented way, without giving any justification as to the cost.

We have already seen the overwhelming cost of Labor relocations. Yet we had the departmental officials, as we have seen in this report, obfuscating, and the minister telling the committee and me that we had no right to inquire as to the details of why $34,000 was being wasted in order to give Senator Loosley the opportunity to move out—as they said, to ease the accommodation pressures so that I could move in. It is an absolute disgrace.

There is a matter of serious principle here. No minister of the House of Representatives can tell the Senate that it is not its business to inquire into the expenditure of public money. That is what this minister has done. It is a very serious matter and I believe it must be pursued in this chamber.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald) adjourned.
