SPEECH.PARA: TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
This bill amends ten bills administered within the Transport portfolio.

Most of the amendments are of a technical nature and represent a fine tuning and clarification of provisions of various acts within the portfolio. The amendments do not introduce substantial new policies.
I do not propose to deal with the minor technical amendments in this speech, but instead will concentrate upon the more significant amendments contained in the bill.

There are a number of amendments to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 and the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 which implement some revised accountability arrangements applying to Commonwealth Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. They provide for Ministerial notices about the strategic direction of the enterprises, the supply of information to Ministers and ministerial nominees, the payment of interim dividends, the appointment of Chief Executive Officers and Acting Chief Executive Officers by Boards and, in the case of the Australian National Railways Commission, the setting of financial targets.

Staff of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority are currently employed under the Public Service Act 1922. The Government considers that this arrangement is not compatible with the proposed accountability standards. Accordingly, employment of staff of the Authority will be removed from the ambit of the Public Service Act 1922. Staff of the Authority will now be appointed and employed under conditions determined by the Authority. It should be noted however that a person employed by the Authority before the commencement of this amendment shall be taken, immediately after the commencement, to be employed under the same terms and conditions.

By amendment of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959, the bill increases to the equivalent of $500,000 the liability limits in respect of passenger death or injury for Australian international carriers. These amendments compliment regulations made in October 1994 under that act which increased to $500,000 the passenger liability limit for domestic carriers and foreign carriers whose States of registry are not parties to the Warsaw Convention. Australia cannot, consistent with its international obligations under the Warsaw Convention, impose higher liability limits in respect of foreign international carriers whose States of registry are parties to that Convention. However I consider it important that all passengers carried to and from Australia are provided with the same level of protection. Accordingly, the Department of Transport will approach the relevant foreign carriers requesting them to increase their limits to the same level.

The Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 currently provides for the fitting of a compliance plate to indicate that a vehicle meets national standards. The administration of this scheme is being made more flexible by introducing "identification plates" which will indicate a vehicle's status in relation to compliance with the national standards. The range of identification plates will include the existing compliance plates and allow for the determination of different types of plate, how they are to be fitted and, in some cases, allow for the imposition of conditions.
The bill makes a number of amendments to the Navigation Act 1912.

Firstly, that act is being amended to prevent a seafarer from claiming compensation for injury under both the act and the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992, thereby preventing possible double dipping.

Secondly, Part IV of the Navigation Act is being amended to enable Australia to adopt a resolution of the International Maritime Organisation that will permit the early implementation of a system of ship survey and certification that is harmonised between the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974, the International Convention on Load Lines 1966 and the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973. The harmonised system will standardise the duration of certificates issued under the three Conventions. The costs of these requirements to shipowners will be reduced as it will be possible to program several surveys at the same time and there is greater flexibility in the times at which surveys can be arranged.

Thirdly, the act is amended to incorporate the terms and principles adopted by the International Maritime Organisation in its International Convention on Salvage 1989. The Convention provides greater incentives for effective and timely salvage operations and to assist with the protection of the environment.

Fourthly, the bill amends offence provisions in the act relating to the abuse of alcohol and other drugs by seafarers. In view of the Government's responsibility to ensure the safety of life at sea and to protect the marine environment it is considered necessary to provide an objective standard of impairment by alcohol and drugs, and to prescribe forms of tests similar to those in other transport modes.

The maritime industry has been consulted and generally supports the introduction of standards and prescribed methods of testing of impairment due to alcohol or other drugs. The industry for its part will introduce and promote policies and practices to control and regulate the use of alcohol and drugs by persons employed in ships.
Finally, the Government has taken the opportunity in amending the Navigation Act to remove a large number of outdated and sexist references in that act.

The amendments to the Protection of the Sea Legislation Amendment Act 1986 will enable Australia to accede to the 1992 Protocol amending the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969.

Australia has been a party to the parent treaty, the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969 (Civil Liability Convention), since 1984. The primary objective of the Civil Liability Convention is to create a system of compulsory oil pollution liability insurance for the owners of oil tankers.

The 1992 Protocol was developed to overcome the effects of inflation on the real values of the limits of liability. For vessels of less than 5,000 gross tons the protocol envisages liability of three million special drawing rights, as defined by the International Monetary Fund. This is equivalent to approximately $A5.8 million.

For larger vessels, liability is calculated on the basis of the vessels tonnage, with an overall maximum for the ship's liability of 59.7 million special drawing rights of the International Monetary fund, or $A114.5 million. These levels ensure that the damage that such a ship can cause will be more effectively compensated.
Compensation available under Civil Liability Convention is supplemented by a separate convention, known as the Fund Convention, which will shortly enter into force for Australia.

Other amendments effected by the 1992 Civil Liability Convention Protocol include extension of the geographic scope of the convention to cover incidents occurring in the 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone.
This will afford additional protection to sensitive areas such as the Great Barrier Reef and safeguard existing and potential fisheries in the Australian fishing zone.
The scope of the legislation will also be extended as tankers in ballast and combination carriers are now included in the coverage of the Civil Liability Convention.

The 1992 Protocol replaces an earlier 1984 Protocol, which Australia acceded to in June 1988. The 1984 Protocol was expressed to enter into force when ratified by ten countries, including six which have at least one million gross tons of tanker tonnage. While thirteen countries, including Australia, have ratified the Protocol to date, only two have the required minimum tanker tonnage.

In recent years the International Maritime Organisation, which administers the Convention, has recognised that the 1984 Protocol is unlikely to gain the required ratification by countries with the minimum tonnage unless it is ratified by the United States, the world's leading oil importer. This is now unlikely to occur, as the liability provisions of the United States' Oil Pollution Act 1990 are inconsistent with those of the CLC Protocol and therefore preclude US ratification.
As a result, the 1992 Protocol was adopted as a replacement Protocol, with the only substantive alteration to the earlier Protocol being a less restrictive entry into force provision.

The amendments to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 will reduce the maximum crew level for eligibility for a grant from 23 to 18. This accords with the existing crewing practices in the Australian Trading Fleet.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY (NON-BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
This bill gives legislative force to a number of non-budget measures, improving the effectiveness and delivery of a wide range of social security payments.
Several initiatives are to assist families, especially those taking on new parental responsibilities.

Under current arrangements, family payment for a newborn child is backdated to the child's birth if a claim is lodged within 13 weeks of the birth. Similarly, when a newborn child is placed with an adoptive parent, family payment is backdated to the time when the child entered the parent's care if the form is lodged within 13 weeks of the child's birth. However, there is no backdating provision for people who adopt older, rather than newborn, children. These people may be paid only from the date of claim.

This bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 so that arrears of family payment may be paid from the date a child enters an adoptive parent's care if the claim is lodged within 13 weeks of the date the child is placed in the person's care.

Presently, when a person who is receiving family payment for one or more children takes on the care of a new child, whether by birth or adoption, it is unnecessary for the person to lodge a new claim for the new child. It is sufficient to notify the Department of the addition to the family for the increased rate to be paid. However, there is currently no rule allowing the increased rate to be backdated to the new child's birth or the date the new child came
into the person's care. Accordingly, the rate may be increased only from the first family payment payday after the actual birth or the date the new child came into the person's care.

This bill makes amendments to allow rate increases for second and subsequent family payment children to be backdated if the Department is notified of the birth of the second or subsequent child within 13 weeks of the birth or the date the child came into the person's care.

Additional family payment rates applicable to children under the age of 16, are adjusted each year on 1 January so that the sum of the combined basic family payment and additional family payment does not fall below a certain percentage (benchmarks of adequacy) of the combined pensioner couple maximum basic rate. From 1 January 1995, additional family payment rates applicable to children under the age of 16 were increased by $1 per week as a result of a decision taken in the 1993-94 Budget context. To preserve the benefit of the $1 increase, this bill changes the current level of benchmarks of adequacy so that the increased rates of additional family payment are reflected in the benchmarks. Therefore, from 1 January 1996, additional family payment rates will increase in line with the higher benchmarks.

Sole parent pension is currently available to people bringing up children on their own, in a number of situations. People may qualify if they are not members of a couple, or, if they are members of a couple but living separately and apart from their partners.

The Social Security Act as it is currently drafted, does not require the separation be permanent or indefinite. As a result, people could qualify for sole parent pension if they were living separately and apart from their partners on a strictly temporary basis. It was never the intention that a person might qualify for sole parent pension because, for example, their partner was going overseas on a holiday or was required to be away from home temporarily for work reasons.
The bill amends the act to ensure that the principle that people living separately and apart from their partners on a strictly temporary basis do not qualify for sole parent pension.

The amendments will not, nor are they intended, to reduce the financial and other assistance provided by the Department of Social Security to people at risk of, or who have sustained, domestic violence.
This bill also introduces special measures to assist those people in our community caring for disabled relatives or friends.

One measure concerns the current inconsistency that a frail or disabled person may travel overseas for a holiday without their own social security entitlement being affected, whereas their carer may not accompany them because carer pension is generally not portable.

This amendment allows a carer pensioner to accompany the person being cared for overseas without loss of qualification, provided that the period of absence is temporary and does not exceed 3 months. This will permit a disabled person to retain the support of their carer while travelling overseas to visit their homeland, for example, or seek medical treatment.

Since July 1993, carer pensioners have been entitled to participate in employment or education and training within the limitations imposed by their caring role. However, while long term recipients of many social security payments are entitled to an employment entry payment assisting them with the costs of starting employment and an education entry payment to assist with the costs of taking up study, these entitlements have not been available to carer pensioners. This bill introduces an employment entry payment of $100 and an education entry payment of $200 for carer pensioners.

This bill also introduces measures to assist people claiming sickness allowance. The requirement to serve an ordinary waiting period is removed if the Social Security Secretary is satisfied that it will cause the person severe financial hardship. A similar rule already applies to people who claim job search and newstart allowance.

Mobility allowance is provided to assist with transport costs incurred by disabled people. It is generally payable to handicapped people who are in gainful employment, vocational training, voluntary work or certain approved job search activities. Disabled recipients of job search, newstart or youth training allowance are necessarily engaged in job search activities and yet they have not had access to mobility allowance for technical reasons. This bill ensures that these people will have access to mobility allowance.

In April 1993, an amendment to the Social Security Act 1991 extended the availability of fringe benefits to all disability support pensioners, regardless of income, for 12 months after their payments ceased. However, the continuation of fringe benefits was unintentionally restricted to pensioners who lose their qualification because they commence full time work. It does not extend to those whose pension is cancelled because of their earnings but who do not commence full time work. The dependent pensioner partners (ie, wife or carer pensioners) of these disability support pensioners also lose their entitlement to a fringe benefit extension.

The amendments made by this bill allow customers whose disability support pension is cancelled because of their earnings, whether from full time work or not, to retain their eligibility for fringe benefits for a period of 12 months.

Currently, disability support pensioners who lose qualification as a result of commencing full time work may have their pensions suspended (for a period of 2 years), rather than cancelled. Should they again become qualified for disability support pension during that 2 year period, an accelerated restoration process replaces the need for a new claim. This provision, introduced as part of the Disability Reform Package, was designed to serve as an incentive for customers to attempt employment.

In contrast, however, pensioners whose disability support pensions are cancelled because of their earnings from part time work would have their pensions cancelled upon expiry of any earnings credit. Such people would have to undergo a new claim assessment process if they again become eligible for pension. As a result, a disincentive exists for people to attempt part time work, the only option available to many disability support pensioners. This is contrary to the spirit of the Disability Reform Package. This bill applies the 2 year suspension rule to all persons whose disability support pensions cease because of their earnings.

Partner allowance commenced in September 1994 as a direct payment to the dependent partner of a recipient of job search, newstart or sickness allowance or special benefit. The payment had previously been made as an add-on to the rate paid to the allowance or benefit recipient.

At present, partner allowance may only be paid 14 days in arrears. This may disadvantage some people in some cases if a person's partner is granted job search, newstart or sickness allowance or special benefit more than 14 days before the lodgment of a claim for partner allowance.

To address this problem the bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 so that partner allowance may be backdated to the date the person's partner claims job search, newstart or sickness allowance or special benefit, provided the claim for partner allowance is made within 14 days of the partner's claim.

This bill makes a number of amendments to the job search and newstart programs. Specifically, the bill allows the Social Security Secretary the option of requiring a person to attend a particular place for a particular purpose as a condition of payment of job search or newstart allowance. This option will be exercised in situations where, for example, the Secretary considers that a particular program information session held outside DSS and the CES would be valuable for the person.

This bill also amends provisions of the Social Security Act 1991 relating to the appropriation of money from which job search and newstart training supplements are paid, to more accurately reflect the source of those funds. Entitlement to the supplement is contingent on approval of participation in a vocational training program or labour market program by the Employment Secretary. This approval is not subject to review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
This bill makes a number of amendments to simplify, and make more equitable, the cancellation and debt recovery provisions of the Social Security Act 1991.

Certain provisions operate to create a debt when a person receives a payment that is calculated at a rate greater than the correct maximum payment rate. This applies whether or not the person notified the Department of a change in circumstances and the debt commences from the date of the relevant event or change in circumstances. As the debt incurred will be the same whether or not the Department is advised, this acts as a disincentive for people to notify the Department of changes in circumstances.

To provide an incentive for social security recipients to notify promptly, changes in circumstances, and to ensure that treatment is consistent with the treatment of other recipients who notify changes resulting in loss of qualification, this bill ensures that recipients who notify a change in circumstances that affects the maximum payment rate will incur a debt, only from the end of the notification period. This allows them a period of grace.

Under the current legislation, there is a clear distinction between qualification and payability for a social security payment. The general scheme of the Social Security Act 1991 is that payment is no longer payable to a person who loses qualification for it. However, the debt recovery provisions are not as clear on this point as they might be.

This bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 to ensure that, once a social security recipient has lost qualification, the recipient will have no further entitlement to payments. This proposal does not disturb the current rules that allow for the continuation of payment to the end of the notification period. Rather, it provides an incentive for clients to notify a change in circumstances within the prescribed period.

There are an estimated 170 local exchange trading systems or similar community exchange programs in existence nationally, the largest with 1500 members. As goods and services are exchanged without recourse to money, these systems are a useful community initiative, particularly in representing a form of activity that helps social security recipients keep contact with labour market skills and habits.

At present, goods and services provided in return for non-cash credits are assessed as income for the purposes of the income test in the Social Security Act 1991, which discourages participation in these schemes. This bill exempts certain non-cash credits from the income test to overcome this disincentive.

This bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 to allow notice of a decision to be given to a person for the purposes of the Act if that notice is sent by pre-paid post to a person's post office box last known to the Secretary. This amendment clarifies the Department's response to a number of Federal Court decisions.
The bill will also make amendments that will allow the Minister for Social Security to declare, by notice in writing and published in the Gazette, a particular class of debt that may be waived.

This amendment recognises the development of a data matching program between the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office's Reportable Payments System (RPS) in relation to the incomes of non-PAYE tax payers. The amendment will enable particular classes of debts arising under the Principal Act to be waived for those who would be affected by the new data matching program and who volunteer advice to the Department of Social Security about their true circumstances.

From 20 March 1995, a new payment type, income support supplement, will be introduced into the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The arrangements for carer pension need to take into account the introduction of income support supplement. Unless the carer pension provisions are amended, carer pensioners will lose qualification for carer pension if they care for a person who receives an income support supplement instead of a social security payment. Accordingly, the bill includes amendments that deal with various carer pension provisions to ensure that carer pensioners are not disadvantaged by the introduction of the income support supplement.
This bill also makes amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990.

PARA.TAB: The bill before the Senate makes amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and it provides for an additional member of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to represent the interests of Aboriginal people living adjacent to the park. It also provides for increases in penalties under the act, the making of statutory management plans, public participation in planning and management, and an increase in the powers of marine park inspectors. The bill also makes minor amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act to allow for fees collected under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act to be paid into the national parks and wildlife fund and allows for the use of credit cards by the director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

In relation to the first matter, the appointment of an additional member to the authority to represent the interests of Aboriginal people, I should indicate to the Senate that there are currently three members of the authority: the chairman representing the Commonwealth government; a director-general representing the state government; and an independent member representing all other groups. It is true that over the last 12 months Aboriginal groups living adjacent to the reef have had to cope with a plethora of issues on which they are being consulted and that there is a need for a more efficient process to address these issues, particularly in relation to the Great Barrier Reef. These issues have created problems for not only the Aboriginal groups but also other groups which have had an interest in the reef.

Over the past 12 months a number of concerns have been brought to my attention, primarily those of tourism operators who have faced serious delays and costs during the authority's processing of permit applications and renewals. The regulation which is at the centre of these concerns is regulation 13AC(4)(b) in the criteria for assessment of applications for permission. This regulation requires that before an application for a permit is approved by the authority the authority must address `the need to protect cultural and heritage values held in relation to the Marine Park by traditional inhabitants and other people'.

This regulation has become prominent in the authority's permit processing over the last year with the introduction of the native title legislation and the acknowledgment of Aboriginal associations with land and sea areas in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park vicinity. The authority has stated that it now spends up to 10 per cent of its total resources on addressing Aboriginal and Islander concerns.

Presently companies which wish to operate or develop within an area where there may be an Aboriginal association have to advertise their intention to develop or operate in the area and then provide an information kit to the authority to be distributed to groups which may have concerns. If there are no responses from the groups involved to these actions, the authority contacts the groups for a response. Once an interest has been voiced by Aboriginal groups in relation to the permit, usually in response to the authority's contact, negotiations begin between the groups involved and the applicant.

Concerns have been raised with me that the authority, in addressing these regulations, is prompting and encouraging Aboriginal groups to take issue with permit applications. The main concerns I have, however, relate to the negotiation process or, should I say, the lack of it. There are no guidelines or plans in place for this negotiation process. Neither operators nor the Aboriginal groups are clearly advised who they are to deal with, how they are to go about the negotiations or how long the process will take. As well, the interests of Aboriginal groups in the area are usually not clearly defined and no proof of their association appears to be required.

There have been several reports of Aboriginal groups not turning up to organised negotiation meetings, and there have been other reports that outside sources have given groups questions to ask at meetings which have little relevance to the group's needs. Without specifically naming any companies, but to give senators some ideas of the problems which are occurring, I mention a couple of the following as examples.

One company in Cairns was recently refused approval for a multimillion dollar pontoon proposal near Green Island. The pontoon concept was developed over two years and involved many thousands of dollars of investment. The authority's reason for not allowing the permit was simply that the company had not satisfied regulation 13AC(4)(b), which is that regulation I spoke of previously. So, after all that money, the company was simply told it had not satisfied the regulation. No other explanation was given.

Another company which has been operating in the outer Barrier Reef for five years was recently advised, on applying for a renewal of its operator's permit, that it had to contact three Aboriginal groups in the area to see if its operations would affect any interest these groups may have in the area. The authority then contacted these groups asking of any association they had with the area, what impact on that association the company's activities might have and whether they approved of the company continuing operation in the area. The company's permit will not be renewed until these groups have responded. This company has invested over $20 million in this operation, and it employs over 100 people.

Last year, another company was delayed for 20 months and faced added costs of over $10,000 before its mooring rights were approved in the Michaelmas Cay off Cairns. After lengthy and uncertain negotiations with Aboriginal groups and the authority, the company agreed to employ members of the Aboriginal group claiming an interest in it and, subsequently, the permit was given.

Investment in tourism is a very high risk area, with foreign investment typically more sensitive to elements adversely affecting the investment risk. The uncertainty which has been created by this unworkable permitting process is deterring further investment locally and new investment from overseas.

I appreciate that it has been a learning process for the authority, Aboriginal groups and business people and that it has had to deal with a large number of permit applications whilst at the same time satisfying requirements under the legislation. However, this uncertainty has to be contained. It has been suggested to me by respected tourism industry leaders that there is a lack of understanding and knowledge in the authority about tourism and other industries' interests in the marine park as well as Aboriginal interests.

I urge the minister, in the appointment of the person to the authority, to look not only at that person's ability to represent Aboriginal groups but also at their ability to appropriately address tourism and other industry interests in the marine park. I think it is essential that this person who is appointed has experience in business and can take a balanced approach to addressing all concerns in relation to negotiating Aboriginal associations with the park.

As a priority, I urge the newly appointed member to have the authority establish clear guidelines where Aboriginal groups and industry can productively negotiate their interests in the reef. It is essential that a plan be put in place so that both parties are given a clear direction. The authority should perhaps also look at establishing a time frame for negotiations to ensure that, by a specific date, any residual uncertainty as to the existence of an Aboriginal interest in the area can be clarified and addressed.

The authority should also investigate the establishment of a register which clearly indicates which areas of the reef are affected by which particular Aboriginal association to ensure that the tourism industry can properly prepare for negotiations on proposed and existing permits. Similarly, Aboriginal groups should be informed of all current and proposed industry activity within the marine park waters. The authority also needs to establish better understanding or definitions of cultural heritage values. There have been very broad ambit descriptions of Aboriginal cultural interests in the marine park in the past. It may be worth the authority looking at whether that needs greater definition.

It may be necessary to establish some process whereby the Aboriginal association with the reef can be clarified before negotiations with industry begin. There is also a need for assistance to be given where appropriate to Aboriginal groups to establish an administrative and decision making structure to deal professionally with these types of negotiations.

The other matter I will briefly comment on is the increased penalties and increased powers of inspectors. These amendments seem to be a positive step towards ensuring that the authority has the ability to assist in the prevention of smuggling from Great Barrier Reef waters. There has been some concerns expressed about that and I raised the issue in the estimate committees. The department indicated to me that these reports in the Queensland media had been investigated and had been found not to be accurate. They included reports about the use of cyanide on the reef. That is a very serious accusation and, hopefully, that is something that the department and the Queensland fisheries people will keep in mind. There are other provisions in this bill which will increase penalties for those misusing the reef. I submit that we need to do more to ensure that this type of illegal activity does not continue.

I have been contacted by a number of users of the reef who have some reservations about the amendments to this bill which allow for the establishment of management plans by the authority. While it is important that the reef is managed by a sound plan, there is some concern that these amendments will give the authority power to make decisions on access and actions with regard to the reef area without requiring supporting parliamentary legislation. I understand from the research service that any such plans will be subject to regulations that can be disallowed in the Senate.

Concerns have been raised with me about amendments which clarify and increase the powers of the marine park inspectors. I have had some conflicting advice in this area and will be pursuing that in the committee stage, but I again simply urge the government to monitor these amendments to make sure that there are no unintended consequences. The coalition will be generally supporting the amendments. I hear that Senator Coulter has some committee stage amendments that he will be moving. We have not even seen them yet. How he expects me to deal with or comment on those, I do not know. At this stage, we will not agree to those amendments when they are moved because we simply have not seen them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were circulated yesterday.

—Mr McLachlan, the shadow minister responsible for this area, told my office about half an hour ago that he has not seen them. If Senator Coulter wants me to look at them, I suggest he get me a copy. (Time expired)

—We are debating the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, which seeks to make a number of amendments with respect to the protection of the environment and particularly with respect to the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. It is that part that I wish to address.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it will surprise nobody, either in this chamber or listening to the broadcast, that in his speech Senator Ian Macdonald sought to protect the commercial interests in relation to the Great Barrier Reef whereas I will seek to protect the environment. I simply point out to Senator Macdonald that if the environment is not protected the commercial interests will not exist anyway. I suggest that the protection of the environment is the far more fundamental matter to ensure.

The Great Barrier Reef is no doubt one of the great wonders of the world. The present generation of Australian people are the custodians of that great wonder. We are the custodians of the Great Barrier Reef not just for future generations of Australians but also for future generations of people from other countries. We are not just the custodians of the reef for humans; we also have to care for the reef so that the complex ecologies which compose the reef will persist in the indefinite future and will continue to evolve and carry out their processes of evolution and ecological interaction as if they had not been impacted upon by human intervention. That, after all, is what the long-term objective of conservation must be—so that it remains a wondrous area in which humans intrude to wonder, to research, to look at but not to impact so as to cause damage.

In recent times one has seen quite a number of alarming happenings in relation to the Great Barrier Reef which need to be taken note of. For instance, there is the increase in sea temperature to which many people have drawn attention. In the Caribbean, for instance, and to some extent in the northern parts of the Great Barrier Reef, one sees the loss of coral species possibly related to the increase in sea temperature. That would seem now to be an inevitable process because we are both as a nation and as a species on this planet inevitably going to increase the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and increase the further temperature of the ocean. Related to that increase in carbon dioxide, one has seen some alarming data on the way in which corals take carbonate out of the water and put it into building the reef structure. The ability of corals and other animals to take carbonate from the water depends critically on the carbonate-bicarbonate balance in the ocean. That balance has been quite seriously disturbed by the increase in carbon dioxide and the move from carbonate towards bicarbonate which will make it more difficult for corals and other species to take up carbon dioxide in the form or carbonate and sequester it in their shells. This is clearly a long-term hazard to the Great Barrier Reef.

One is also aware of the fact that there is increasing silting on the reef as a consequence of damage which has occurred on the contiguous shoreline. The growing of sugar cane particularly, which has gone too close to many of the creeks and rivers in northern Queensland, has resulted in silt being carried down and silt being deposited on the corals. At the same time, one has seen an increase in the nutrient load in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef which also disturbs the ecological balance of the reef. For instance, the balance between the algae and the corals themselves is disturbed in favour of algae which could in fact have quite a damaging long-term effect on the reef.

These are all matters to which our attention has been drawn in recent months and years. They are all matters which seem, at the moment, not to be fully controlled. They are all matters which presage damage to the reef. I point out to Senator Ian MacDonald that they are all matters which, in the longer term, if uncontrolled, would in fact remove the reef from its ability to support a buoyant tourist industry. So they are all matters to which government and the people of Australia need to pay very close attention.

Having said all this, I come to one of the points in our suggested amendments. I am rather surprised at what Senator Ian MacDonald has just said about those amendments, because they were circulated in the chamber yesterday. There was plenty of opportunity for him, as the person in this chamber responsible for dealing with those amendments, to look at those. Having had plenty of opportunity to look at them, it ill behoves him to suggest that he has not considered them. But I suggest to him that he consider the purpose of these, which is very simple. The first amendment is to write into the amending bill the precautionary principle and to pick up in that way some of the damaging developments which are occurring on the reef and other damaging developments which may occur which need to be covered by management plans.

Incidentally, I was a bit surprised to hear him criticise the development of management plans. There is a justified criticism of the government over management plans in the Lake Eyre suggested world heritage area and in the Willandra Lake area. I do not think the opposition can have it both ways. If there are to be management plans, there are to be management plans, and they should be adequately exposed to public gaze.

In relation to the barrier reef, it is absolutely appropriate that those management plans not only be developed but incorporate the precautionary principle, because we are dealing here with a structure which has been in existence for a very long period. It is still changing. It is an evolving structure, and it is, as I have indicated already, being seriously impacted on by very many human interventions, not least of which is the impact of tourism. Tourism is leading very much to, for instance, an increase in nutrients in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef. Nutrients are one of those things which are disturbing the ecology.

Senator Macdonald also drew attention to the Magnetic Quays development, which, I would have to agree with him, has been a disaster. Had the precautionary principle been written into management plans earlier, I suspect that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority would not have given permission for that development, with its heavy impact of silt on the area around Magnetic Island, to go ahead and it would not have proceeded to this aborted stage.

I want to address two areas for amendment. The first is the precautionary principle, and I ask that Senator Macdonald think about it. I am sure he is aware of the precautionary principle. I am sure that he would agree with that principle for the reasons I have outlined. All that amendment seeks to do is write the precautionary principle into the development of these management plans. I understand that the government will be supporting that amendment, and I ask Senator Macdonald to think again about that.

In relation to liability, the second area, we take a somewhat different view from both the government and the opposition. I cannot for the life of me see how the changes which have been made here tighten the liability for damage occurring in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority area. The offences have been changed from indictable to summary offences and several other hurdles have been put in the way of a successful charge being laid against those who damage the reef.

We would be moving from a situation where there is strict liability to one where there would be qualified liability depending upon the intention of the person who caused the damage. That, in our view, will weaken the legislation rather than strengthen it. This rather puzzles me in particular because if, say, a toxic substance such as cyanide, to use Senator Macdonald's example, were spilt into the reef it would not really matter to the reef whether the placing of that cyanide into the water was done intentionally or not—the damage will still occur.

A person who offends against, say, a speed limit on the road cannot claim that he or she did not intend to speed—the speeding is itself the offence. So we take the view that, because the damage will occur whether the act was done intentionally or not, a penalty should be laid against that person. We believe that the government has in this case really placed a barrier in the way of the possibility of successfully prosecuting people who do damage to the reef because they can simply claim that that damage was not intended.

Senator Macdonald also mentioned the Hinchinbrook development. Undoubtedly this will place a further considerable impact on that part of the reef—Hinchinbrook Island and Hinchinbrook Channel, which are near this development, even though the development is on the mainland.

Given that the administration of the Great Barrier Reef is hampered by lack of funds and given, as I understand it, that in the Hinchinbrook area there is only one national park ranger to supervise both the Hinchinbrook Channel and the whole of Hinchinbrook Island, which is a large one, it seems to me that those who place these greater impacts on a world heritage area have the responsibility to significantly contribute to the protection of the area which will be impacted by their development.

In this case, I strongly urge the minister to suggest that those who would develop the so-called Oyster Point development, such as Mr Keith Williams, should contribute perhaps an extra two rangers at their expense in perpetuity to supervise the activities of those who stay at this tourist development, should that tourist development proceed to the point where it contains the very large numbers of people Mr Williams said it will contain.

Those people should be a part of the national park service; they should not be within the employ of Mr Keith Williams or whoever runs the development. They should certainly be independent and able to monitor the impacts. Under the precautionary principle, they should be able to then advise the Queensland government and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority that certain damages are occurring and how under the precautionary principle that damage should be contained and further prevented.

We are supporting this legislation as we believe that it improves the present administration and management in this area, but in the committee stage we will be moving those two areas of amendment. I understand that the government is supporting the precautionary principle. I will argue further for strict liability when we get to the committee stage of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are currently considering, the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, is an omnibus bill that covers a number of portfolio issues and ranges across a number of topics. I specifically want to turn my attention and the Senate's attention to the amendments that relate specifically to the Norfolk Island Act of 1979. I note that one of the amendments embraced by this legislation is at the original request of the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island. The references in the act to `President' and `Deputy President' of the Norfolk Island Assembly will be changed by the bill to the nomenclemature of `Speaker' and `Deputy Speaker'.

PARA.TAB: We should always acknowledge that Norfolk Island is an important and integral part of Australia. It has a distinct and historical connection and an important constitutional relationship on the basis that it is situated within the ambit of the Australian constitution. Norfolk Island, as I am sure many senators will be aware, is a community that has grown out of the Pitcairn resettlement group of people who for so many years were fiercely in our folklore as a result of the Bounty and all the issues that have subsequently arisen. The Norfolk Islanders see themselves as a very distinct and special community with very special constitutional relationships.

I believe that we should at all times acknowledge that we must not patronise the Norfolk Island community. It is a community of approximately 2,000 residents, and we ought not to presume or assume that any changes that impinge on their constitutional and legal rights ought be imposed without a degree of special consultation. I am aware that there were resolutions of the Norfolk Island Assembly with regard to the amendment in this bill to change the nomenclature. The matter has not been without controversy and without reservation on Norfolk Island.

I spoke to Senator Sherry a few moments ago when he was the minister on duty and canvassed with him the opportunity to incorporate in my speech today an exchange of correspondence between the government of Norfolk Island, specifically a letter by the Hon. M.W. King, Minister for Tourism and Works, to His Honour Mr A.G. Kerr, the Administrator of Norfolk Island, dated 14 December 1994. I seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter to which I have been referring canvasses the reservation of the assembly but, at the same time, it acknowledges that the government of Norfolk Island realises the position in which the federal government is placed with this legislation and acknowledges that it should proceed at this stage. This brings me to the important point of constitutional arrangements for Norfolk Island. As I said, we should at all times acknowledge its special role and the need for close and continuing consultation.

PARA.TAB: We are well aware from today's media that the issue of the republic is once again on the agenda and has been placed there squarely by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his current trip to Germany. It is also quite coincidental that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon) is also in Germany at this same time. I wonder whether he is also looking at the issue of republicanism and how it might affect Australia's external territories.

I am sure that we, and Norfolk Islanders, would want to ensure that the federal government does not ride roughshod over the views of the Norfolk Islanders. The days of paternalism are over. The federal government must listen closely to the views of the Norfolk Island community and not impose its policies from afar, whether from Australia or from a prime minister and a parliamentary secretary currently in Germany.

This point was brought home to me by a report I read recently in the Norfolk Islander, the local newspaper, dated 10 December 1994. It concerned a visit to the island by the parliamentary secretary, Mr Warren Snowdon. The report, in part, read:

In conversation with Mr. Snowdon the question of the Australian Republic was raised. Mr Snowdon is a staunch Republican, he even has a watch to prove it, and we asked him where Norfolk Island would stand if the question of Australia becoming a Republic were put to the vote?

He said that Australians in Norfolk Island would be involved in the referendums the same as Australians in the mainland and that when Australia became a Republic, which he seems to believe is a foregone conclusion, that Norfolk Islanders, `would just have to cop it sweet'.

SPEECH.PARA: What a disgraceful statement from a parliamentary secretary for territories: that a number of people would just have to `cop it sweet' because of their unique and special constitutional arrangement. That is an horrific statement. It has portents not only for Norfolk Island but also for Christmas Island and Cocos Island. Each of these communities is, to some extent, adolescent in constitutional terms.

PARA.TAB: If we look at Christmas Island, which was declared an Australian territory in 1958, we see that the island residents participated in federal elections for the first time in only 1984 as part of the federal Northern Territory electorate. That is quite symbolic and important. The following year, the Christmas Island assembly was formed and recently we have seen a new legal regime, a capital works program and economic and town planning initiatives, all of which highlight the controversy involved in looking to the future.

While Christmas Island is coming of age in a constitutional sense, there are some fundamental questions that need to be addressed. I will flag some of them here. How, for example, will the eventual statehood of the Northern Territory affect Christmas Island? Will the islanders be able to, or want to, remain part of the Northern Territory electorate or will they prefer to be included in Western Australia as a shire or attached to the Australian Capital Territory, as Norfolk Island has recently been done, for federal election purposes for Australian residents?

What about the debate on Australia becoming a republic? Will the views of Norfolk Islanders, Christmas Islanders and Cocos Islanders matter? What are the constitutional options for Norfolk Island or Christmas Island? Is an island plebiscite needed in each of those cases? Are there any common threads with the islands, say, of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands or is the Norfolk Island experience, which has an established parliament, a good precedent to follow?

Naturally, as the shadow minister for external territories and also the Country Liberal Party senator for the Northern Territory, which embraces the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island, I am interested in the views of those residents. But obviously Mr Snowdon is not. He is also the member of the House of Representatives for Cocos and Christmas Islands, but he has given a portent of his feelings by telling Norfolk Islanders that they are just going to have to `cop it sweet'. Are the Christmas and Cocos Islanders also going to have to `cop it sweet' in relation to suggestions that Mr Snowdon obviously believes that, as the lackey of Mr Keating, he is going to have to develop the same republican views? Perhaps whilst the Prime Minister is in Germany—he is there at the moment—he will be addressing how we are going to choose any republican president.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe he could worry about the real job in had, which is selling business.

—I would hope so. The conference Mr Snowdon is attending in Germany, I believe, is on global warming, so it is going to be very interesting to see the relationships he develops in that particular area. It is important that we look at these constitutional issues. They are raised in this legislation because to this bill we are moving an amendment to bring the Norfolk Islanders in a closer relationship to a form of parliamentary representation.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that the coalition has flagged that after the next federal election it will proceed to a centennial convention in order to conduct a 100-year review of the Australian constitution. The coalition wants to give the Australian people their proper voice in a review of our constitution. That also includes the residents of Norfolk Island, of Christmas Island and of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It is not this `cop it sweet' mentality of Mr Keating, who seems to be wandering around in Germany pre-ordaining the way in which Australians will cop a president sweet or the way in which Mr Snowdon is going to tell the residents of these various islands how they should be part of Australia in the future.

By comparison, the Liberal and National parties would want to see a proper review of our constitution that embraces the issues that are currently needing to be addressed and have been so and have been changing since federation. We would involve detailed negotiations with the states and with the territories, not just the ACT and the Northern Territory—they are very important points—but also Norfolk Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. We would naturally see, in any convention of this nature, proceeding and looking at the matters that need to be addressed in so many areas as a major issue—not just Mr Keating's system of choosing a republican president.

Whilst I also have the opportunity to look at the issues that arise from this area of Norfolk Island, I note that in the parliament this week, in both the House of Representatives and this chamber, a report was tabled by the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. Whilst that report specifically looked at terms of reference that were engineered from the point of view of freight costs that affected the islands, the report itself canvasses many other areas and issues, in particular it canvasses this important area of constitutional rights.

A number of the recommendations that arose from the report looked at involving the Australian Bureau of Statistics in conducting a number of inquiries that needed to be very detailed and properly looked at in this whole area that needs to be addressed. But, again, I flag that this parliament must not impose upon Norfolk Island even the sort of nature of conducting inquiries; we must do that in a consultative process with the Norfolk Island assembly and the Norfolk Island government.

If we are going to run a major inquiry into the infrastructure of the island community, we must make sure that self-government really means something for that particular island. Whether it be the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and Norfolk Island, we need to look carefully at those particular issues that the Norfolk Islanders have requested that they themselves would want to look at in particular detail.

I would hope that we will have another opportunity in this Senate to look at the report of the joint standing committee in detail because it does canvass a number of issues on all three islands that need to be urgently addressed. Certainly the constitutional issues need to be addressed. I note, in particular, that the report highlighted gaping holes in the quarantine services that were addressed on Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. As this is part of my electorate, it naturally is a major issue of concern to me.

This bill also looks at environmental issues and the fact that exotic pests have been introduced into Christmas Island over the years is relevant. A federal parliamentary inquiry is now pointing the finger very specifically at quarantine. The federal government has a direct responsibility for quarantine and must take urgent action to ensure that Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island are properly protected in the future. I am concerned that the report tabled this week highlights very major issues of concern for Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. With regard to Christmas Island, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.144 The Committee was particularly concerned about the inadequacy of the quarantine regime on Christmas Island given the importance of Christmas Island wildlife and the fact that the largest part of Christmas Island is a National Park.

3.145 ANCA submitted that the quarantine regime and facilities for inspection of incoming containers to Christmas Island were entirely inadequate and had resulted in the introduction of pest species to Christmas Island. Giant African snail, Asian Wolf Snake and Oriental Fruit Fly were believed to have come to Christmas Island in freight shipments and had escaped to colonise the rainforest, perhaps because of inadequate inspection and treatment of containerised freight. Redback spiders were discovered in a shipment of timber from mainland Australia in August 1993. Rotten and insect-infested goods were reported in a shipment from Singapore in September 1993.

The committee added that it was satisfied that the serious inadequacies of the quarantine regime on Christmas Island are receiving attention. The committee may be but I am not yet. Similarly, if we look at the issue of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the report states:

4.109 The Cocos (Keeling) Islands host Australia's maximum security animal quarantine station. The quarantine station, from time to time, is home to high value exotic species such as alpaca, black rhino and ostrich, prior to their entry to the mainland.

4.110 In this context, the Committee was disturbed and surprised to discover that the facilities for quarantine inspection of freight containers delivered to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands were less than adequate.4.111 Freight containers delivered to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands could have been stored in Fremantle next to containers originating in South East Asia and could have been contaminated—by Giant African Snail for example—during storage. Exotic wood boring insects had been discovered in freight consignments from Singapore.

Those two quotes from that report highlight a major issue that needs the attention of both the environment section of the department and the territories section of the department. Again, we must look at the forms of government that are so important for these islands.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the outset, I am concerned about any action by the government—whether it is from the Prime Minister on a constitutional issue like the republic or whether it is from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, who has obviously walked away from his responsibilities in each of these areas and insulted the people of Norfolk Island by telling them that they just have to `cop it sweet' for what this Labor government gives them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

2Schedule 1, page 5, item 8, proposed section 38A, omit "intentionally or negligently".
3Schedule 1, page 5, omit item 9.

13Schedule 1, page 10, item 28, proposed paragraph 38L(1)(b), omit the paragraph.

There are two areas in which the Democrats are seeking to amend this legislation: the area which relates to strict liability, and the area, as I indicated earlier, which relates to the writing into the bill of the management plans which regulate the use of the precautionary principle. I suggest to the Senate that we look at the amendments as two sets; I think that would expedite the passage of the bill. I have moved the strict liability amendments as a block and will move the final amendment by itself. There is a slight rewording of that, which has also been circulated. It slightly changes the wording in relation to the precautionary principle, and I understand that that has been agreed to, but I will deal with the first set of amendments.

PARA.TAB: The original Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975—and I will refer to a couple of sections in that, because this is quite repetitive—is the act which this bill seeks to amend. I will refer to two sections only—section 38(4) and section 38A—because we can pick up the arguments with respect to those, and the same arguments apply to the other amendments. In the act as it stands at the moment, subsection 38(4) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)A person who:
(a) contravenes subsection (2); or

(b)having obtained the approval of the Authority under subsection (3) for the carrying on of operations for the recovery of minerals, carries on operations for the recovery of minerals otherwise than in accordance with that approval;
is guilty of an offence punishable—
et cetera. So the present legislation says that a person who carries out an act which is not in conformity, in this case with the approval, is guilty of an offence.

PARA.TAB: The amending bill, which we are seeking to amend by removing certain words, seeks to put in there that the person intentionally or negligently does those things. In other words, as I read it, the prosecution would have to prove not that the thing was not done, not that there was not damage to the reef, not that that damage may, in fact, be very considerable damage but that the person had the intention to cause that damage or to do that thing; or, and the other word, `negligently'—that the person did the thing which may indeed have caused damage, including considerable damage, but that they did it negligently. So, quite contrary to the government's claim that this section is being strengthened, in our view it is being weakened.

If I use the second example, the same principle applies. Section 38A of the bill reads that a person shall not use or enter a zone `for a purpose other than a purpose that is permitted under the zoning plan that relates to the zone'. Then there is a penalty—if the offender is a natural person or if the offender is a body corporate—of so much. Again, a person shall not `use or enter a zone for a purpose other than a purpose that is permitted'. A person shall not do those things. Yet the government is seeking, in our view, to weaken this legislation in a number of areas by putting in that the charge has to be accompanied by proof that the action was carried out intentionally or negligently.

It seems to me that here we are dealing with two very important principles which are in conflict. If one is dealing with many human interactions, I can see some sense in putting in the words `intelligently or negligently' because the consequences of certain actions may be partial, may be temporary and may be repairable. In the case of human actions in dealing with the environment, many of those actions will result in damage whether or not the action was carried out intentionally or negligently. Surely, the function of this act and the function of the amending bill, which would then become part of the act, should be to protect the Great Barrier Reef. The function should not be there to protect those people who carry out activities which damage the reef.

It seems to us—and I reiterate—to very significantly weaken this legislation if the prosecution has to prove intention or negligence. It is for those reasons that I would urge most strongly that this set of amendments, which seeks quite simply to maintain the act in its present form, in fact, is the set of words which will best ensure the protection of the reef.

In relation to the other change as to whether it be an indictable offence or summary offence, again, it seems to us that that, to a degree, weakens the legislation. However, it does expedite the processes by which such offences can be dealt with—and we have no objection to that. But this particular amendment which the government is seeking to put in, I think, puts very considerable hurdles in the way of a successful conviction. It may, in fact, lead to very significant damage occurring to the reef and no ability whatsoever on the part of the prosecuting authority to obtain any sanction or recompense against the person who carries out that damage.

Certainly, I urge the Senate very strongly to review very carefully what the government has claimed with respect to these words, because I believe that they mean the opposite to that which has been claimed by the government, and to maintain the act in its present form.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is not minded to accept Senator Coulter's proposed amendments 1 to 13 dealing with a person's intention when an offence has been committed because, amongst other things, it is contrary to the Commonwealth's criminal law policy. I think it is important to remember that the penalties in this legislation have been doubled.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter referred in his comments to the fact that what we are doing here is balancing two very important principles: the protection of a world heritage environmental area like the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park; and, on the other hand, the civil rights of citizens. The government believes it has that balance right and it is not persuaded to support the Democrats' amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: if, as a result of the changes which the government is seeking to make, the government were to find that damage was occurring to the reef, offences were being committed and a significant number of people were able to escape through one or other of those qualifiers—namely, that it was able to establish that the action taken was not intentional, or that the action carried out was not negligent, nonetheless causing significant damage to the reef—would the government then consider returning the act to its present form of strict liability?

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I quickly pick up the fact that as I understand it we are not talking about criminal offences anyway; we are talking about summary offences. So while the penalties may have been increased, there is always an option in the courts to look at the size of the penalty and take those other matters into account.

The example I gave earlier was of a speeding offence. If one exceeds the speed limit, one is guilty of the offence whether one did it intentionally or accidentally. However, if one were to go into court and say to the magistrate, `I was speeding, but I had a sick child in the car and I was taking that child to hospital. The road was clear', and all the other evidence is that it was safe to speed, I am sure under those circumstances the magistrate would in fact impose a lesser penalty. Courts always take those sorts of things into account.

But here one is providing a let-out. Simply by establishing that the act was not done intentionally or negligently one escapes entirely any penalty whatsoever. No mitigating circumstances can be taken into account. As I have indicated, there may indeed be very considerable damage as a result of these actions. I believe the government has not got the balance right.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a point of clarification, Senator Coulter mentioned these as summary offences. So that I can try to follow what he is talking about, does not 38(5) of the act say that an offence against subsection (4), which I thought was the one Senator Coulter used as an example, is an indictable offence?
—That has been modified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, could you put that again? I am always happy to have Senator Coulter's contribution, but maybe the officials can help with that clarification.

—In his contribution—this is a very minor point, but I am just trying to follow it through—Senator Coulter said that they were summary offences. I would like him to explain that to me because from my reading of subsection 38(5) of the act—for the very first time, I must say—it says that an offence against subsection (4), which is the one that Senator Coulter used as an example, is an indictable offence. Did Senator Coulter say that that has been subsequently amended? Would Senator Coulter explain that to me? I do not need the minister to explain it because Senator Coulter is making the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in front of me the explanatory memorandum dealing with this particular bill, and I will read from page one, which is under the general heading `General Outline'. The second dot point says:

SPEECH.PARA: -increase many of the penalties under the Act to ensure that they provide an effective deterrent, introduce the mental fault element into the relevant offences—
which is what we are talking about—
-change them from indictable to summary offences and revise

PARA.TAB: the waste discharge provisions to make them consistent (as far
as is appropriate) with the MARPOL Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reading from the government's own document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see what it says in the memorandum. I do agree with one point Senator Coulter made in his other argument. I think the explanatory memorandum is quite misleading, and I think he is right when he says that the effect of the proposed legislation is the exact opposite of what is said in the explanatory memorandum. I do not say that that makes it right or wrong, but I do agree with him on that. I see what the explanatory memorandum says, but I cannot see, again from a very quick reading of the bill, where that is put into effect. Perhaps the government's legal expert could clarify that for both of us.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I just indicate that we are going to oppose all of these amendments because we saw them for the first time only an hour ago. If Senator Coulter and the Democrats were serious about getting these amendments through, rather than just doing a bit of political grandstanding for their ever diminishing support base, then they would ensure that the relevant person on the coalition was aware of these amendments and had a view of them. Senator Coulter—from a party with seven senators, shortly to be reduced to about two, and representing about four per cent of the electorate—may not understand that parties like the Liberal and National parties, which represent 50 per cent of the Australian electorate and have almost 100 parliamentarians, do have a process which has to be gone through.

In case Senator Coulter is not aware—although I know he is—Mr Ian McLachlan is the coalition spokesman on environment matters, and I represent him in the Senate. I would have thought that, as a matter of courtesy, Senator Coulter or his office might have, at the very least, contacted my office and said, `Well, what is your view on these?' or `Are you aware of these things?' or `We're serious about getting these passed, so we want to come and argue the case with you,' or, better still, `We want to go and argue it with the shadow minister.' I know Senator Coulter has done that in the past with Mr McLachlan. Mr McLachlan and his office have not seen these amendments at all. I saw them yesterday, and I thought you interjected and said that they were distributed yesterday. As I recall, the Senate did not discuss this matter yesterday. It discussed only one particular item yesterday.

We have not had a chance to look at these amendments and they certainly were not terribly well explained by Senator Coulter when he spoke in support of them. With respect, I know that this is not in the portfolio of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). I think it is fairly clear from what she has said that she really does not understand the legislation. That is not a criticism; it is just a statement of fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you are a charming chap!

—You prove to me that I am wrong, Senator Crowley. I am happy for you to do that. It makes it very difficult for us if the relevant person does not see the amendments. Amongst the million other things that he and his staff have to do, they are ambushed with these sorts of things.

PARA.TAB: If the Democrats are serious about these matters rather than just pandering to their ever decreasing support vote, then Senator Coulter should really make us aware of the amendments and make sure we understand what he is talking about. Perhaps in that way you might get the legislation seriously amended. As I always say, the Democrats are not really serious about amendments. They are not too serious about real legislation, it is just a bit of grandstanding on their part. When there are only seven Democrats there is never any likelihood that any of their policies will be put into effect. I always regret that they encourage the government to up the ante in relation to taxation matters. If you are serious about the worth of your amendments let us know.

We will be voting against these amendments. I have tried to follow the arguments as Senator Coulter put them. As I understand it your amendments simply leave the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 exactly as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to those sections.

—With respect to those sections. The government is amending these sections to introduce an intention or negligence element. I agree with Senator Coulter in one respect that it does seem that the government's amendments do not do what its explanatory memorandum says they will do. They do the exact opposite. By your amendments you are saying that there should be a strict liability in relation to these offences. Whether a person means it or not they are liable. I understand that that is your interpretation of the original bill and that is what you want to do via your amendments which stop the government amending the legislation in this respect.

PARA.TAB: If I follow your argument correctly, I would think—and I have not had the opportunity to consult with Mr McLachlan—that as a matter of general philosophy we would be opposed to your proposal and we would support the government's attempt to remove that strict liability and make people guilty of what appears to be an indictable offence and dealt with summarily by penalties of 200 penalty points. I must confess that I am too far out of the law to remember exactly what that currently means, but in relation to the old bill it was around the $10,000 mark. I do not know whether gaol sentences are provided for because I have not read the 1975 act well enough.

Strict liability provisions in any legislation should be dealt with very cautiously and should appear very rarely. I wonder whether the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has looked at the Democrats' amendments. I can see that they return the act to what it originally was. I think the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would be quite horrified by these amendments. As a party that is supposedly gung-ho on civil liberties and the rights of the citizen, it seems to me quite amazing that you are putting an inanimate object, the Great Barrier Reef—I suppose you would call it a living object, magnificent though it is and protected as it must be—in front of the rights of ordinary people.

There are problems with strict liability. I repeat that I read the act for the first time a few minutes ago. I am not sure whether Senator Coulter has ever been on the waters of the barrier reef, but I have been there a number of times. From where I live, the barrier reef is some 80 kilometres away. Certainly in that area of the barrier reef there are no distinguishing features; there is just flat sea. You cannot see the reef under the water. I have always been amazed, when I have been out with skippers who know the area, how they can head for somewhere—no doubt they use a compass and, in these later days, satellites as well—and just from a feeling look around the sea and say, `This is where we are going.' They are very experienced people.

But there would be a lot of people, when they are 80 kilometres out, who quite innocently stray into an area. They may catch a fish or perhaps pull up a bit of coral. I am not sure whether coral is within the definition of mineral that is spoken about in one of the examples Senator Coulter used. People can do things innocently. They do not mean it. They do not intend it. If they had control over what they were doing, they certainly would not be doing it.

Senator Coulter will find that most people who use the reef are the greatest protectionists and the greatest environmentalists of it because they know its beauty, its value and its sheer wonderment. I often get the feeling that Senator Coulter's group thinks that people who live there, or go near there, or use it, or use it for tourism are just environmental vandals. Quite the contrary is the case. They are people who understand its value and who want to do what they can to protect it. But things do happen beyond the control of people.

There are some provisions of the Queensland criminal code that specifically exempt acts that occur beyond the intention of the party. I think they are sections 22 and 23 of the Queensland criminal code, but I am not sufficiently a constitutional lawyer to give the Senate a treatise on how that code would impact upon Commonwealth legislation. There are things that are done innocently, quite accidentally, without any malice, without even any thought and not recklessly. Under the government's amendments, if acts were done negligently, the people responsible would be caught. If there were just a sheer disregard for anything, if it were just willy-nilly stuff and people did not care, then, in a very broad way, that would come within the definition of negligence and so, under the government's legislation, they would be caught. The meaning of the word `intentionally' in the government's legislation is quite clear.

A person might move from one zone to another out on the reef. There is not a line drawn across the water; it is an expanse of water. If they happen to drift somewhere else without any malice, intention or negligence and they cause some damage, it seems a bit unfair and against civil liberties to put that person up for a fine, which used to be $10,000, because of accidental happenings. I suspect the fine is a lot more now and perhaps there is even a gaol sentence.

If I correctly interpret the government's original bill, its amendment and Senator Coulter's amendment, we would incline not to agree with Senator Coulter in any case because we think that citizens do have some rights and that citizens should not be thrown into gaol or fined very heavily for things which occur entirely by accident. So, on that basis, we would probably not have agreed with Senator Coulter in any case. As I said, we would not have agreed with him because the relevant coalition person has not had the opportunity of looking at these things.
