TALK.START.PARA: —I had momentarily forgotten the occasion of yesterday, when of course we did not sit except to hear senators speak on the condolence motion. The amendments were indeed circulated not yesterday but two days ago. They were circulated in the chamber and they were placed on every desk. I thank Senator Ian Macdonald for his perspicacity. Despite the fact that he says my explanations were not clear, he nonetheless was obviously able to follow the intention of what we are about. I am glad he agrees with me that this amendment does amount to a weakening of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Two questions arise out of that which I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry). Firstly, are there amendments which reduce the offences from indictable to summary offences? Secondly, how many cases have been brought into court in the last 10 years since this 1975 bill has been in place? Have the strict liability provisions, which have been in the law for the last 10 years, in any way embarrassed either the people who have been charged or the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in relation to those charges? Has strict liability created difficulties? If so, in how many cases has it created difficulties?

It is remarkable that here we have a bill which has been in place for 10 years and yet it is only now that the government is seeking to weaken these sections. I think we should have available to us evidence as to the efficacy or otherwise of the law as it has been used over the last 10 years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, this legislation does change the form of legal process—I am not sure of the exact terminology—from indictable to summary offences. In the process of doing that, because prosecutions would be handled as summary offences we are doubling the penalties that can be applied. In one case the penalty is being increased to $1 million. I am advised that that would be in the event of an oil spill. In relation to the second point that Senator Coulter raises, we do not have here details of previous proceedings under the act. We will research that for him, but I cannot give him that information at present.

—One question still remains unanswered. I can understand the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) not being able to provide precise details in relation to my earlier question about the number of cases, but the general question still stands unanswered. It is an important one.

PARA.TAB: This legislation has been in place for 10 years and it is only now that the government has chosen to amend it and weaken it not in terms of the sanctions or the penalties but in terms of the type of the charge and the qualifiers which have to be met before a charge can be made to stick. Has the authority in any way been embarrassed or placed in difficulty because of the strict liability provisions of the act that has been in place for 10 years? If so, in what way have those difficulties arisen? How do these changes make that situation better? I need to be convinced that what we are doing will not only protect the reef but also make the processes work better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst Senator Sherry is about to answer Senator Coulter's question, perhaps he could clarify his previous answer to Senator Coulter. Could he indicate to me the section of the amending act which legislates to the effect that the offences which were set in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 were indictable offences. Could he point out for my edification which section says that those offences and other similar indictable offences are now summary offences?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Macdonald's query, I can say that section 38M(1) on page 30 of the act, dealing with the prosecution of offences, makes reference to an indictable offence. On page 11, you will see that amendment 29, dealing with section 38M, repeals that.

PARA.TAB: In answer to Senator Coulter's question, I can say that we as a government have endeavoured to balance the rights of an individual. We appreciate the need to respect those rights vis-a-vis protection of the environment. That is where we believe you strike that balance, and you may disagree. That is the approach the government has taken. It believes it is an appropriate balance given the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will repeat the question in a different form. This act has been in place for 10 years. Does the authority have any actual evidence, as distinct from theory, that over that 10 years the application of this act has been unbalanced?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we do not. You can repeat the question in as many varied forms as you like, but you will get the same answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This seems to me to be fairly typical of the sloppy way in which the Labor Party runs the government and its legislative program. What Senator Coulter said—
—What is typical?

—I will get on to it; just listen. Your explanatory memorandum refers to amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act to, as Senator Coulter has pointed out, change the offences from indictable to summary offences. You have just told me that your amending bill removes section 38M, which is correct. Section 38M reads:

SPEECH.PARA: An offence against any of sections 38A to 38K . . . is an indictable offence.
You will remove that. You are saying that that then makes them summary offences, which I suppose is right. But if you have a look at section 38—not 38A—it happens to be fortuitously—

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 30A or 38?
—Section 38M refers to offences against the sections 38A, for `awful', to 38K, for `Keating'; I suppose `awful' and `Keating' ring together.
—Cut out the smart-arse remarks and get on with it.
—Senator Sherry is a bit sensitive today.
—No, I am not. You're just wasting time. You are being stupid as you usually are.

—If Senator Sherry is so clever, he should explain it to me sensibly. He should tell me how section 38(5), which says that an offence against subsection 4 is an indictable offence, converts that to a simple offence. The explanatory memorandum is typical of the Labor Party's complete incompetence in running anything. Perhaps he has a better answer because he is so smart. The one he gave to Senator Coulter is quite right. He wants section 38M repealed. That does away with the indictableness of 38A, for `awful', to 38K, for `Keating'; I say that in case Senator Sherry's hearing is not good. Unless it deals with it somewhere else—if it does, I ask him to point it out to me—it does not deal with how it converts section 38 from an indictable offence to a summary offence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Macdonald cuts out some of the rhetoric, we might get to the issue. There are two exceptions. One he has just pointed out to us—section 38—deals with drilling. The other one deals with waste discharge. Those two exceptions will be indictable under the act. Other offences will be dealt with as summary offences.

—Why, then, does the government's explanatory memorandum lead Senator Coulter—I do not blame him for it—and anyone else who reads it to think that all indictable offences become summary offences? Why is the government's explanatory memorandum misleading to the Senate?

—Because the explanatory memorandum is referring to those areas where we have increased the penalties. Where we have maintained the two circumstances for indictable offences, we have not increased the penalties in those areas.

—In all these cases, be they indictable or summary offences, is it not the case that, even if strict liability were left in, it is quite possible for the court hearing the case to take into account questions of intention and negligence? Would the courts very appropriately take them into account in determining where on the scale of penalties the sanction would fall?
—The short answer is that the courts could.

—It seems to me that the government has just cut the ground entirely from underneath its own case. It says it wants to put in these qualifiers so that it allows for those cases in which a person with no intention and negligence nonetheless causes some damage to the reef under one or other of these sanctions. It wants to let off such people.

PARA.TAB: The minister has just said that the court could take a very lenient view under these circumstances, even within the strict liability criteria in the act. I have to agree with Senator Ian Macdonald that it seems the government has been unnecessarily messy and is interfering with an act which has been in place for 10 years. The minister can point to no evidence which indicates that there has been harshness in dealing with people. Senator Macdonald has agreed that these amendments weaken the legislation. We have heard that the act as it is allows the courts to take into account mitigating circumstances. I cannot for the life of me see why, if the intention of this legislation is to protect the Great Barrier Reef, the government is seeking to amend it in any way. It should be left exactly as it is.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the people of Australia the activities of the Softwood/ Percheron group of companies and give voice to the frustration of the members of the association Pine Tree Register Inc., who are seeking some justice in relation to the way they have been treated by the Percheron group of companies. This group of companies is headed by a Mr Alfred Buchanan of Killara. It has been asserted that Mr Buchanan has behaved in a dishonest and fraudulent manner. It would appear that, because of his activities, investors have been robbed of literally millions of dollars. Despite all that, Mr Buchanan, I have reliably been informed, continues to reside in his Killara mansion.

PARA.TAB: The history of the Pecheron group of companies can be summarised as follows: approximately 23,000 people world-wide invested in this group. However, the vast bulk of them, some 17,000, are Australian citizens or residents. Even in my home state of Tasmania the estimate would be hundreds of investors. I have been provided with a list of 131 investors who have had their savings frittered away. These people invested their hard-earned money to the approximate value of $40 million in this group. The investments were made over a three-decade period between 1958 and 1987. The investments made and the contracts entered into concerned the sale, planting, tending and maintenance of pine trees and their ultimate cutting and disposal as timber. The trees were to be established on 52 separate plantations. In exchange for their investments, the investors had had returned to them by December 1991 the princely sum of $54,494.

The Percheron group of companies was the subject of an Australian Securities Commission inquiry. Before I go into that inquiry, I should indicate to the Senate that on 1 March 1989, the New South Wales Supreme Court, on application of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission, appointed a receiver of the assets of the 20 companies within the group and of the assets of the managing director, Mr Buchanan. The ASC report found that the growers' investments—the growers are referred to as the actual investors; they are the ones who put the money in for the plantations—were an unmitigated disaster because of the misrepresentations, deceptions and mismanagement practised by Mr Buchanan and those associated with him, the failure of the group's auditors to carry out their duties properly, the neglectful attitude of the New South Wales government authorities, in particular, the Crown Solicitor's Office and the Corporation Affairs Commission, over some 27 years, and to a lesser extent the fact that Westpac Bank was prepared to provide references for the group to potential investors, thereby encouraging or at least providing comfort to potential investors. The ASC also found that Mr Buchanan misapplied investors' funds, some of which found their way into a series of trust accounts administered by Standard Charter Bank in Hong Kong.

It also found that from at least 1982, and probably from at least 1975, the profit and loss accounts and balance sheets of the Australian companies in the group with balance dates of 30 June were not prepared as required by statute prior to 30 December in each year. Other findings were that the companies in the group did not hold annual meetings when required; profit and loss accounts and balance sheets were not presented at annual general meetings; records of minutes of some meetings of directors and of shareholders of companies in the group were false; information contained in annual reports of companies in the group, at least until 1985, were false; the accounting records of companies in the group were not kept in such a manner as to allow true and fair accounts to be prepared; and the financial statements of companies in the group did not show a true and fair view.

In the latter part of 1990, the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission approached the New South Wales Attorney-General with a proposal for special legislation to overcome legal problems involved in any liquidation of the group. The group's assets were to be pooled by the special legislation which would then allow Pine Tree investors to share those assets. Since this very detailed report, prepared by the Australian Securities Commission, came about—there are two volumes running into what I imagine would be about 700 or 800 pages—not much has happened. It is clear that, because of the terrible tangle weaved by Mr Buchanan and his associates, special legislation is required to give some assistance to these investors.

I want to make a request to the federal government to do something for the approximately 17,000 Australians who invested in good faith in this company. The legal difficulties surrounding this matter are based on the fact that individual investors entered into individual contracts relating to particular plantations. The problem was that, when you traced the money through, the money was not necessarily spent on the plantation for which it was designed. Therefore, it is no longer possible to trace whose money went into which plantation so that returns can be given on the basis of where the people invested. Therefore, in my view and in the view of the 17,000 or so investors from Australia, it would be appropriate that the Australian assets be pooled and shared out equally on a pro rata basis.

This is important because good, hardworking Australians invested their money in the hope that in about 30 years time, after their investment, they might have a little nest egg for their future. As an aside, investment in tree plantations is clearly something that this country should be encouraging to assist the industry and to avoid any further imports of timber into this country. We clearly have sufficient ground to grow and be self-sufficient in timber resources. I would have thought it would be appropriate for the government to send out a message that it is supportive of those people who would seek to invest in that industry.

Some of the assets of the Percheron group have been sold since the ASC report. I am reliably informed that, as at 30 September 1994, in excess of $1.2 million has been invested. Unfortunately, the funds cannot be released to the investors until the web is untangled. Really, the only way that this web can be untangled is by way of special legislation. The provisional liquidator of the group, Mr A.R.M. Macintosh, in correspondence dated 15 November 1994, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of special legislation, given the element of uncertainty as to which growers may be entitled to the proceeds of the sale of particular forests and the assumptions which of necessity will need to be made regarding allocation of trees it may be necessary to seek directions from the Court in relation to any proposed distribution to growers.

So we have a situation where very expensive applications will need to be made to the courts to determine how this money is to be spent. Later on, the New South Wales Attorney-General's Department wrote to the legal firm looking after the interests of the Pine Tree Register Inc. The letter, signed by the Director-General of the Attorney-General's Department, dated 16 January 1995, states:

The Attorney General has also had discussions with the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, to determine whether the Commonwealth would support special legislation at a national level given that there are a number of companies and other entities in the group which are resident or have their operations in other States—
that is, other than New South Wales—
or overseas.
The Commonwealth—
this is the important point—

has responded indicating that it would not support such legislation unless it was satisfied first, that there had been a conclusive judicial finding of misleading or fraudulent conduct on the part of the promoters of the scheme, and secondly, that no other lawful course was available to gain access for defrauded investors to the unlawfully obtained gains obtained by those who perpetrated the fraud.
The letter then goes on to say:

In the absence of Commonwealth support for special legislation at a national level and uncertainty as to whether the support of other State and Territory jurisdictions would be forthcoming, it is clear that national legislation is not available as an option to assist the investors.
Without the support of federal legislation, it would really be quite fruitless for the New South Wales government to seek to do it alone. The letter concludes:
The complexity of the Group's affairs and the means by which special legislation may assist investors have been exhaustively reviewed by the Attorney General.
That is, the New South Wales Attorney-General.
However, for the reasons outlined above, it is not clear that special legislation enacted by this state—
that is, New South Wales—
would be effective in assisting investors.

The federal Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has in effect said of that $1.2 million plus sitting in a trust fund that he will not assist these investors until, in effect, they have spent that money or until there has been a `conclusive judicial finding of misleading or fraudulent conduct on the part of the promoters of the scheme'. We have two volumes from the Australian Securities Commission that go into the dealings of this web of intrigue, chapter and verse, and it comes out with the conclusions I referred to in the earlier part of my speech. One wonders what more proof the federal Attorney-General would require.

PARA.TAB: We also had the findings of Mr Justice Powell in the New South Wales Supreme Court when the company was being wound up, which were in fact reported in the Sunday Telegraph of 14 May 1989. His honour made a number of comments about the conduct. The ASC in fact agreed with Mr Justice Powell's findings about the fraudulent conduct that had taken place in relation to the Percheron group of companies.

In the brief time remaining to me, let me urge the federal Attorney-General to revisit this issue. This is an issue that goes beyond party politics: this goes to the hearts and souls of 17,000 Australians who have invested their money in good faith. Given the advice of the official receiver for the companies that special legislation is required, I would urge the federal Attorney to revisit and to look at special legislation to protect the interests of those who invested their money in good faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today in the matters of public interest debate on behalf of a company in Queensland which I believe is suffering from a very unfair imposition of sales tax. Its competitors do not have the same imposition on them. The name of the company is Poly Recyclers Pty Ltd, which operates from a factory in Brendale in Queensland. It manufactures a soil retention device, a continuous garden edge, which is called `Enviroedge'. It is made from 100 per cent `mixed post-consumer plastic waste'; in other words, it is made from recycled waste plastic.

PARA.TAB: The principal of this firm, Tony Messina, is somebody who has invested considerable amounts of his own money—to the extent of mortgaging his own home—in developing this product, which I believe has social, environmental and economic benefits to this country. He has become very frustrated at being unable to get a response to his many requests to the Australian Taxation Office, through various government ministers and members, and also to a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), some of which I want to place on the record.

The problem he has with his product is that many other kinds of garden edging, made from concrete or timber or plastic which is not recycled waste plastic, do not attract the 21 per cent sales tax which his product does attract. The irony of this situation is that Mr Messina has used his considerable experience in the plastics industry to develop a unique product. I will read part of the letter which he wrote to the Prime Minister, as that may help the Senate to understand the concerns which Mr Messina has. He writes:
Over the past fourteen months . . . I have been experiencing untold frustration in my ongoing battle in relation to what I, and many others—

SPEECH.PARA: and I include myself amongst those—
regard as a very unfair tax on my new invention, ENVIROEDGE, a soil retention device which is manufactured from 100% mixed post consumer plastic waste.
Mr Messina writes of his own experience, and I think it is worth while for the Senate to hear just what it is he is contributing to this product. He writes to the Prime Minister:

PARA.TAB: I have been involved in the plastics industry since 1979 and am therefore quite knowledgeable where plastics are concerned. I know that plastics cannot be mixed when recycling to make similar products. Mainly for this reason it is claimed that plastics cannot be recycled. However, since 1989 I have been experimenting with plastics and have mastered a technique whereby all types of plastics can be combined, thus achieving a breakthrough which is a first in Australia and very possibly in the world. My revolutionary product, ENVIROEDGE, is proof of this, and there are many more products which can also be made, but which for now have had to be put on hold. I am able to do something with the one million tonnes of plastics presently ending up in landfill across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate can understand that here is somebody who has invested his own expertise, his own money, his own time, his energy, and certainly large amounts of frustration, in trying to compete in the marketplace—not with any advantage, but simply on a level playing field. He wrote to the Prime Minister in terms of his frustration as follows:

PARA.TAB: I have always regarded Australia as a level playing field. However I am sadly disillusioned in this case. I have had to mortgage my own home on this project. I have received no incentives from any government scheme. My banks—

SPEECH.PARA: I will not name them—
are ready to pull the plug on me if I don't repay my commitments to them.

What Mr Messina is asking for is not any kind of special treatment but simply equal treatment. He lists a large number of other products which are available free of sales tax through many distributors.

PARA.TAB: I have sighted correspondence and other communications from some of the large chain stores, who point out to Mr Messina that his product is obviously a very good one and they would like to stock it but the main stumbling block is the fact that his product attracts a sales tax imposition of 21 per cent whilst other garden edging made from timber, concrete or plastic which is not recycled does not attract the same sales tax penalty.

It seems to me that here is an Australian company which is seeking to do something about one of the most serious environmental pollutions that there is—waste plastic—and is contributing therefore to the environmental health of Australia, is seeking to create jobs and is offering a product which brings economic and social benefit, yet the manufacturer is being prejudiced in his ability simply to sell the product because of what seems to be a most unfair imposition of sales tax. It seems that government members such as Arch Bevis and Michael Lavarch agree with Mr Messina and with me, but we have not been able to get any movement.

I thought that it would be good to place before the Senate the plight of this company regarding its product. I gave notice of a motion this morning in the Senate to that effect so that we might understand what seems to be a quite ridiculous unilateral and unjust imposition on a product which ought to be available at least on the same basis as similar products are within Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is International Women's Day and I think it is very important that we focus on the plight of women in the community, where they have been, where they are going and what their achievements have been. It is also significant on a day like today to celebrate some of those achievements—not to go overboard in simply celebrating the achievements of some but to look also at the way in which this government has failed so many women in the last decade.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party's electioneering time and time again, election after election, always includes a promise to offer women a new deal—one of the many promises which have not been delivered by this government. At election after election, this is the regular promise and this is what a whole lot of women look at and say, `Well, maybe it will happen this time.' But we need to look at some of the examples of biases which still exist more than 10 years after sex discrimination legislation came into force. They include limited pay and promotion opportunities, risks to health and safety, and limited over-award and overtime payments. We have only to look at the newspapers today, on International Women's Day, to see how many of those women are doing very badly in the equality stakes, on the equality that this government has promised to deliver them.

Women as a group do not possess sufficient bargaining and negotiating skills and they are poorly represented in trade unions. In fact, if women were given an opportunity to indulge in some of these negotiating skills, they would be far more successful but they are being locked out, and that is most unsatisfactory. In 1991-92, 24 per cent of men negotiated pay rises compared with only 15 per cent of women employees.

Women remain part of a highly segregated work force and are mostly employed in the lowest paid industries such as textiles, clothing and footwear and finance and business. Women are over represented at the lower pay levels and under represented in positions of authority.

It is interesting to look at the record. In today's West Australian, a Labor state member of parliament, Judyth Watson, claims that a female worker is twice as likely as a man to earn less than $400 per week and a man is 10 times more likely than a woman to earn more than $1,000. This has come from a Labor member of parliament. In effect, she is saying that this government has failed miserably and the Labor government that was in office in Western Australia for a decade, until thankfully it was removed, has also failed women.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the party that endorsed Joe Bullock in Helena.

—That is exactly right, Senator Campbell. This is the party that trumpets loud and long about endorsing more women for safe seats. It had an opportunity in the state seat of Helena, when a male Labor politician retired. What did it do?
—What about Carmen Lawrence?

—Did it put a woman in that position as a candidate? No, it did not. It is interesting that the parliamentary secretary talks about Carmen Lawrence. `Cannot remember' Carmen: that is what she knows. People cannot even see Carmen Lawrence; they cannot even get an appointment with Carmen Lawrence. Do not trumpet her as the be-all and end-all. She is an unmitigated failure in Western Australia; an unmitigated failure in Health. So do not trumpet her loud and clear as being some wonderful thing. Carmen Lawrence is just a disaster.

PARA.TAB: Dr Watson, the Labor member of parliament, also asserted today that only 3.6 per cent of women had received more than $80,000 in superannuation compared with 22.4 per cent of men, that the average superannuation payout to men is around four times that paid to women, and that only 18.8 per cent of women aged from 55 to 64 were covered compared with 41.4 per cent of men. These areas indicate that progress towards equality has stalled and that the gender gap remains entrenched in society. The effect of this is to damage the esteem of women as a group and to place significant restrictions on the nation's productivity.

This government has to be held responsible. It ducks for cover at every opportunity. It does not mind holding breakfasts such as the one held this morning with Joan Kirner as the guest speaker. She was so political. She tried to claim credit for the Labor Party for everything when, in fact, reality dictates something totally different, as has been clearly stated by someone in the Labor Party who was prepared to be more honest and more frank about this subject than others.

Women's incomes from full-time employment are around 80 per cent of that of their male counterparts and women continue to earn around 20 per cent less than men, despite the concept of equal pay for equal work. They also miss out on the prestigious salary packages of male executives, who dominate the senior management levels of business at a ratio of 9:1.

Comparisons of male and female executive earnings also indicate the top 25 per cent of male executives earn in excess of $700,000 per year, while the women earning above that amount can be counted on one hand. In addition, the top 20 public servants, all male, earn between $500,000 and $137,000.

Women are very poorly represented in the Australian Public Service. That is where this government has had responsibility for far too long: 12 years and there is only one woman who heads a department and that is the Department of Tourism. At the very top levels of the Public Service, the percentage of female senior executive service officers ranges from 13 per cent to just three per cent of the total. There seems to be an unspoken expectation that women will not reach the highest levels in the public or private sectors and, as such, they are not granted access to essential training opportunities which might facilitate their further promotion.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, women are simply not being groomed for stardom.

PARA.TAB: This government once again talks long and loud about the fact that it has training programs for everyone under the sun, yet the government is failing women all over Australia. The government is simply not delivering the training and the mechanisms for women to succeed in an equal world. In the corporate sector, women managers comprise approximately 12 per cent of all managers. Even then, they are more likely to be called controllers or supervisors than to be given the more prestigious title of manager.

It would also appear that women have to choose between family and career, with most Australian female managers being single or divorced. As many as two-thirds of those women who have made it to the top have no children. Women comprise approximately 20 per cent of local government councillors, and there are a number of reasons for that. For example, women can stay closer to home and there is more time flexibility; in other words, women are more able to negotiate their own deals.

Representation by women in trade unions is very poor. Why has this Labor government not done something about that situation? By and large, the government is a captive of the trade unions, yet it does not seek to have more women promoted through the system. When you consider how far women still have to come in areas like maternity leave—according to the ACTU's assistant secretary, Jennie George—I would have thought that something would be done. Jennie George does not do anything; she just talks about it. There is a very wide gap between the rhetoric and the reality. Approximately 10 per cent of trade union positions are held by women. I would not have thought that Jennie George would consider that to be acceptable, but she seems to accept it; it comes from the Labor Party and the ACTU, so it is acceptable.

Award restructuring is desperately needed and should include aspects such as employer sponsored child care for workers with family responsibilities. This situation affects many people in the work force, and there has to be wide discussion within the community and here in the parliament. Businesses, for example, are suffering costs left, right and centre; costs that they can no longer afford. How do we cope with this requirement that is so badly needed?

Twenty-five per cent of full-time lawyers are female, and, of part-time lawyers, 54 per cent are female, but more men are employed as barristers and partners than women. In the field of accountancy, there is a downturn in the number of female managers.

Despite the Sex Discrimination Act, the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act and the Public Service Reform Act, the government is still unable to close the gender gap. In reality, the government has done very little. On Monday the government announced that a special team is to be established to investigate the reason why women are not making it to the top. Is that not fantastic? Let us have another inquiry, and by the time the next election comes, the government can say that there has been an inquiry to find out why women have not been successful. The investigation by a special team is another wallpapering exercise to paper over the cracks, with the government hoping to high heaven that women will not notice its inactivity. It should thrill women no end to know that the government is having another inquiry to solve all their problems. In reality, this government continues to ignore the plight of so many women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks by noting that, amongst the documents tabled today, is a quality of service bulletin from Austel which reviews the performances of Telstra and Optus. I will highlight a couple of things in that bulletin because they are relevant to the matter of public interest that I will be talking about today. The bulletin refers to quality of service. In the heading of the bulletin it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The proportion of faults cleared by Telstra within one or two days of notification remains stable at the national level, but declined for metropolitan customers whilst improving for country customers. Telstra's performance in answering calls to service difficulties continued to improve over the September 1994 quarter.
Further on in the bulletin is information about the restoration of service and service difficulties, and it is stated:

The decline in Telstra's fault clearance performance, noted in the previous quality of service bulletins, appears to have been slowed, with national results showing a stable performance over the September 1994 quarter.
Further on, it talks about the restoration of service and service difficulties. It says:

The decline in Telstra's fault clearance performance noted in the previous quality of service bulletins appears to have been slowed, with national results showing a stable performance over the September 1994 quarter. However, metropolitan business and residential customers continued to experience a declining level of service, particularly when compared to the September 1993 quarter results. This is a matter of concern.
Then it says:
Country customers experienced a slight improvement over the quarter.

I would like to see Austel try to explain this improvement to constituents of mine—Anthony Honner and his wife, Sue. They own a motel at Stansbury on Yorke Peninsula in South Australia, along with other businesses that they have. For nine years, they have had a long running saga of service difficulties with Telstra. For nine years with the one business they have had problems with the telephone service that was supplied to their motel.

PARA.TAB: I have a bundle of documents and letters that have been sent to me by Mr Honner. There are a couple of letters from 1986 but all the other letters were written during 1994. There were some 14 letters from Mr Honner to Telecom over that period of 12 months and 15 replies from Telecom to Mr Honner and still he did not get any satisfaction or correct treatment from Telecom with regard to the service difficulties that he was experiencing at his motel.

It culminated at the end of the year with Mr Honner writing to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Michael Lee. I think it is only right that I should quote some parts of that letter because it highlights the sorts of difficulties that Mr Honner had. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,

The attached exchange of letters between Telecom and myself, as owner of the Stansbury Holiday Motel, is but a short chapter in a long running saga with Telecom. The managers of our motel have thousands of pages of Telecom files and we have volumes of evidence to prove that we have been deceived by Telecom.
He then goes on to explain how his problems are synonymous with the CoT cases—the casualties of Telecom. I will not go into detail on that. Further on in his letter to Mr Lee, he says:

Despite a denial over nine years that a replacement of the old ARK exchange would solve our problems, and that operator error and quickly fixed faults were the cause, we find that with that replacement in October—
that is, the replacement of the exchange—
that our phone suddenly works and our motel occupancy reflects the good news.
So after nine years of denial by Telecom, we find that with the replacement of the exchange all of a sudden his faults are fixed and the phone suddenly works. He says:

As our telephone problems now appear to be solved, it is with respect to other Australians suffering the frustrations that we went through that I respectfully ask you to move to conduct a Senate inquiry into Telecom. There are no doubt many areas a Senate inquiry would want to look at but the evidence we could supply would relate to abhorrent customer relations, misleading information, monopolistic policies, document fabrication of the truth, denials of fact and an inability to admit to a fault which might be legally clever but which is morally wrong and most un-Australian. I am sure that the major benefits of an inquiry would be the identification of a structure in which a customer with a problem must navigate through a maze of managers in ascending order from state to state, department to department, each of which is insulated from the next, eventually reaching the manager of major disputes. No one in this line of command—including the manager of major disputes—is able to make a decision. Should one contact the general manager, he drops the customer back into the same category of management which still cannot make a decision. It is very much like a game of snakes and ladders. We had to deal with so many different Telecom personnel where the last one on the scene had no knowledge of the original problem or what their predecessors had done, and the repetitious nature of that work was a huge cost to Telecom which was ultimately borne by the subscribers and caused enormous disruption to our business.

That is a stark example of some of the problems that are being experienced by some consumers. In this particular case, after a period of nine years, but more particularly throughout the whole of 1994, this one consumer had difficulties which made it very difficult for his business to operate. In one of the letters he quotes how the occupancy rate of his motel dropped from 73 per cent to 38 per cent, much of which he said could be attributed to the difficulties that were experienced through their telephone exchange. He concludes his letter to Mr Lee by saying:

Telecom has not responded appropriately to its critics or its legitimately dissatisfied customers. It is very evident that they make token gestures of compliance with the Austel guidelines to keep faith at the top. What they do not do is resolve problems at consumer level. For nine years, our Stansbury Holiday Motel was plagued by problems Telecom refused to even acknowledge.

I have read through the details of the correspondence that Mr Honner has sent to me which consists of some 30 letters over that period of time. It is fair to say, if you were to read them in detail, that you can understand the frustrations that an ordinary businessman, or an ordinary consumer of Telecom, would find when they try to solve the problems that are confronting them, whether it be in a business or a private situation.

PARA.TAB: In the quality of service bulletin where people talk about one and two-day service and clearance difficulties, I guess that is the case. It is quite possible that the service record is very good for private consumers with only small problems which can be treated very quickly—power supplies and other minor matters.

When you look at the people who rely totally on Telecom—or Telstra as it is now—for the survival, smooth running and ultimate success of their business, maybe it is time that some of these issues, such as Mr Honner's, are highlighted here in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. Because of the very nature of the casualties, particularly of Telecom cases which have been going on for some time and are still going on, it is time that the Senate, and particularly the minister for communications whose responsibility it ultimately is, look seriously at these problems and give the answers that so many consumers throughout Australia require to the problems and difficulties that they are experiencing.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today on what I regard as a matter of public interest. It is to do with the Aboriginal reconciliation process in Australia. I picked up my copy of the Weekend Australian at the local newsagent in Subiaco on Saturday morning, went home and, as I do if I get the chance, sat outside and read it. I was very disturbed—in fact it ruined my Saturday morning—when I read an article by Christopher Dore headlined `Keating attacks Coalition "racism" `. It is a disturbing aspect of the debate on issues relating to indigenous Australians that, basically, if you agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) you are not a racist and you are pro-Aboriginal; if you choose to differ with the Prime Minister or his minister, or indeed on some occasions with the chairperson of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue, you are regarded as un-Aboriginal, un-Australian and against the process of reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: If we are to create a process, as all of us agreed when we passed the bill to support the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and if we are to create a reconciliation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians and the rest of the Australian community, then what is happening with the debate on Aboriginal issues in this parliament in particular, as it is reported in the media, importantly, is something that will militate against a reconciliation.

I have always strongly held the view—which was aptly put by our former leader Dr John Hewson in his letter to the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, when the reconciliation process was being established—that reconciliation can really take place only at a community level and even at a micro-community level between individuals, as individuals come to terms with the views of their black brothers and sisters, if they are Australians of European or other ethnic descent, or, if they are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Australians, with their own views in relation to their history, how they relate to Australia as a nation, how they relate to their local community. These are things that emerge within the hearts and the minds of the individuals concerned. They become part of the community, and they ultimately become part of the greater community and the greater Australian civilisation. That, for me—in my own, probably inarticulate, way of putting it—is what reconciliation means. We all become part of the so-called process in our own ways.

We have a Prime Minister who, last Tuesday, I think it was, in debating the second model of his land fund bill, held out a hand of bipartisanship to our leader, John Howard, and said, `We hope that you will support the government's mark 2 bill and that you will encourage your Senate colleagues to pass it as well.' When, two days later, Mr Howard spoke as he did—for a whole range of reasons, which do not need to be canvassed in this matter of public interest debate because they will be canvassed when the bill comes back to the Senate tomorrow or in the near future—Mr Keating chose, because he did not get what he wanted, a political device, to go feral. As deputy Liberal leader Peter Costello said recently, Mr Keating's going over the top, his going feral, his spates of that which he is well known for, seem to be getting closer and closer together.

I return to my Saturday morning, drinking my cup of coffee and reading the paper. An article reported Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, as speaking at the launch of the Canberra by-election campaign on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. The article stated:
In a stinging attack on Mr Howard and the Coalition, he accused the Opposition of "deeply seated prejudice against (blacks)" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things we did here yesterday was to pay tribute to our late colleague Senator Olive Zakharov, someone who speaker after speaker said was respected for the way that she in particular was able to carry on debate, carry on the most rigorous arguments. Often, as some of my colleagues and colleagues on the other side of the aisle said, Senator Zakharov came from the Left perspective and other colleagues came from the Right, yet she could always carry on debate based on the policy, based on the ideas, without rancour, without name calling, without accusing people or impugning their integrity or how they get to their views—in other words, with respect for other people's views, respect for other people's ideas.

PARA.TAB: Ideas do ultimately shift nations; ideas do ultimately shift civilisations. It is people who come to public life, more often than not, who are at the forefront of creating ideas, creating public policy and moving nations. That is one of our roles and some are very effective at it. But may I say that, when it comes to dealing with Aboriginal affairs policy in particular and reconciliation more broadly—firstly, achieving good policy and, secondly, achieving what is ultimately more important, that is, a building of nationhood, a building of reconciliation between black and white Australians—the sorts of remarks made by Mr Keating do nothing to solve that. There does need to be a respect in politics for differing views between opposing groups, for opposing sets of ideas on Aboriginal affairs.

It is absolutely outrageous to suggest that, in such a complex area where there are such huge challenges to overcome, the government or ATSIC could propose a policy solution and say that it is the final word. If people do not agree with it, they are called racist or anti-black or, as the Prime Minister says, they have deeply seated prejudice against blacks. Most Australians know that is just simply untrue and they share my view that it is very unfair. I have already said that it does little to help the reconciliation process.

We are here to work as the political leaders of our nation. The people have chosen us to represent them in the houses of parliament in Canberra, along with our colleagues in the state parliaments. I understand that every state parliament passed the resolutions about the need for reconciliation unanimously. If we are to proceed with any sort of unity of purpose, we have to work very hard to ensure that we do not fall for the trap of calling each other names and creating unnecessary and harmful division at the political level. We need to have vigorous debate about the myriad problems that almost seem intractable: how we legislate to solve these problems; how we act to solve problems; how we work with the states; how we work with local government; how we work with ATSIC; how we work with other Aboriginal organisations; how we solve the fundamental health problems that beset so many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians; and how we solve education problems. The whole process is not helped by name calling or by the vicious racist, in fact, McCarthyist slurs, mostly dished out by the Prime Minister.

We can have that sort of vigorous debate. We actually had it here during the committee stage of the debate on the land fund bill in the Senate. There was a very strong debate, mostly about the principles, the practice and its workability, and the government had very strong views on it. Senator Evans put those views most eloquently. I choose to disagree with many of his views, but the coalition actually accommodated some of the views. We put up amendments. The government said it did not like them. We sought a compromise: the very last amendment in relation specifically to finding out whether native title exists before land is purchased was a classic example of that. It was a massively contentious amendment but I demonstrate the point that, where there is rational, sound debate, where people do not call each other racists, or whatever, a way can be found through these things and hopefully we can come up with better public policy than we have had in the past.

I came to Canberra from Perth this week with the intention of saying that what Mr Keating has done is very wrong. It is not in the interests of anybody; it is not even in his own interests. It is not good for Australia to have a Prime Minister who will accuse his political rivals. In fact, these people may not even be his political rivals. He accuses anyone who chooses to disagree with his view on an issue: he calls them a racist and accuses them of having a deeply seated prejudice against blacks. Mr Keating, in his own heart, must know that is not true of the coalition. It is not true of any member of the Liberal or National Party; it is simply not true of one person.

I hope my remarks will improve the level of debate and create more respect. I genuinely respect the views of many of my Labor colleagues on the other side of the House, such as Margaret Reynolds, Senator Cooney and the minister himself on some occasions, although I do not want to go over the top. There is a whole range of people on the other side whose views are genuine. They think their policies will help to improve the lot of Aboriginal people. I hope they are right. I think they are wrong, but I do have a genuine respect for those views.

Therefore, I was horrified this morning when I tuned in to the House of Representatives to listen to the land fund debate, while I was in my office having a cup of coffee. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) serves with me on the Joint Committee on Native Title. He has strong views on these issues and I genuinely respect his views.

Mr Latham rose in the chamber to talk about the land fund bill but he basically spent most of his speech hurling insults at the coalition. Again, it did not really help the public policy debate, and it did not go to the guts of the amendments that we have moved or our motivations for moving them. During that debate he referred to me, and I will quote his comments, which he was forced to withdraw, from the Hansard green. The member for Werriwa said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the truth of the matter was made known by Senator Campbell, the Chair of the Senate committee, one of the patronising Western Australian rednecks in the parliament, a genuine barbarian when one examines his views—

Mr Latham was asked by the Speaker to withdraw those remarks and I am happy to say that he did. I invite Mr Latham, the member for Werriwa, to examine my views. I invite him to examine everything that I have said, from the day that I got involved in public life in the late 1970s or early 1980s, on Aboriginal affairs policy. Let him examine the thousands of pages of transcript that have been produced as a result of my chairing that Senate select committee. I had a lot to do with drafting Aboriginal affairs policy in Western Australia, as the chairman of the policy committee of the Western Australian Liberal Party. Let him examine my involvement in Aboriginal affairs over the last 15 years that I have been involved in politics.

PARA.TAB: I ask Mr Latham to go through all of those public documents, to look at my views and to say, `Yes, Senator Campbell disagrees with me.' When he analyses my remarks, he will see that I also have a deep commitment to achieving a better life, more hope for and reconciliation with Aboriginal people. Mr Latham is a member of the New South Wales Labor Right, which is not noted for its compassion about anything except winning. I guess he would say that about the right wing of the Western Australian Liberal Party, so we might be in the same boat there. However, I suspect that both Mr Latham and I are committed to very similar outcomes. We just differ on how we get there. We are probably also both very committed to winning the next election but I am sure that when it comes to Aboriginal affairs there is that commitment. I ask quite seriously, quite genuinely, that we put aside this unhelpful name-calling. Mr Latham knows that we are not racists. He knows that we are not barbarians and I invite him to assess my public utterances on these matters going back 15 years. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to raise some specific issues that require obvious review within the Department of Employment, Education and Training in the Northern Territory. In the Sunday Territorian newspaper of 5 March there is an article entitled `Jobless walk out of atomic war game.' Under the heading `Training course kills off people', it states:

PARA.TAB: A group of the Territory's long-term unemployed were given the job of deciding who should be killed off after a nuclear war as part of their training for work.
The exercise in decision-making was called Atomic War.
The course was sponsored by the Federal Government's Department of Employment, Education and Training.

SPEECH.PARA: Further on the article says:

PARA.TAB: It gave participants the task of deciding who of 15 tourists sheltered underground at Coober Pedy in South Australia should be allowed to live after the holocaust.
Food and water was supposedly short and eight had to be eliminated so the others could survive.
The tourists were listed as including a mentally-handicapped Jewish child who enjoys his pets, aborigines and a beautiful Irish catholic waitress from a dubious background.
There was also a Vietnamese woman who grew up in the Vietnam War in a ghetto, a catholic priest, an Australian nun and a trainee nurse from New Zealand.
Another exercise made the jobless deal with a hypothetical crash landing on the moon.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular article then goes on to highlight the concerns of the three remaining participants in that course who, in order to comply with their course criteria under their entitlements to newstart, jobsearch or formal training and to receive their allowances, were under a threat that those very allowances would be suspended if they did not attend the course. I am surprised at the comments by the northern Australia manager for DEET, Elizabeth Tchacos, who defended the course. The newspaper article says:
It was designed to help the long-term unemployed develop their social and inter-personal skills and the figure showed it was a success, she said.

How can it be a success when the only three remaining participants were the very three course participants who went to the newspaper and described it as a degrading and demoralising course in which to participate? Very obviously, this course needs to be thoroughly investigated, both as to its cost and effectiveness, and with regard to the aspirations of the participants.

PARA.TAB: Let me also highlight another case that has been brought to my attention by a constituent in the Northern Territory. It relates to a course that was carried out during the Christmas vacation period: an advanced word processing course set up by CES. The constituent who wrote to me described this particular course as one that was run for six weeks full-time for eight hours per day. My constituent went on to list a whole series of grievances with the course: the non-attendance of lecturers, students being more knowledgeable than lecturers in a competency based computer course, lack of availability of material, the relevance of the material provided, and assessment on topics not covered.

I went to the material that was supplied to me and I looked at the statement of attainment. It was put out over the imprimatur of the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training, with the official government stamp, with the date, with the signatures of both the course tutor and the course coordinator, certifying that my constituent had successfully completed six weeks of an advanced word processing course at the Northern Territory University. My constituent complained about all these various issues that I mentioned. He complained about the fact that for the first two weeks the literature had not arrived, and about how the literature was extremely out of date when it did arrive and, to quote him, `we were told to virtually ignore it because of this reason'.

And this is important: there was an assessment record that was required to be signed off daily with the candidate's signature and the assessor's signature, with an assessment given and a description of the method of assessment. The certificate was issued despite a number of the various courses not being fully participated in. My constituent has written across the top of one page, `I did not complete the highlighted competencies for which I have been assessed.' When we look at three specific competencies, we find that the first is `phone for an interview': method of assessment, observation; assessment, C; assessor's signature given, but candidate's signature not there. The second one was `attend a job interview': method of assessment, observation; assessment, C; assessor's signature, but no candidate's signature for participation. Thirdly, there was `handle a rejection for a job hunt': method of assessment, observation; assessment, C; assessor's signature, but none for the candidate's participation.

I find that disgraceful, and I find it an issue that obviously needs to be looked at in detail. I call on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Warren Snowdon, who happens to be the federal member for the Northern Territory and who happens to push these courses in the Northern Territory, to review the relevance of these training courses. Come the next estimates committee I will certainly be asking questions about the number of courses run, about the costs that they have incurred, about the consultants that have been appointed and their qualifications, and about the number of students that have been required to participate in a repeat situation.

The atomic war course, which asked the jobless to decide who should be killed off after a nuclear war, absolutely staggers me. I find that strangely ironic, given Mr Snowdon's credentials as coming from the Socialist Left of the Labor Party, with a strong commitment to the anti-nuclear area. The area that I have highlighted from the constituent who wrote to me was with regard to a Hospitality Horizons course. That constituent describes it in the letter to me as, and I quote his words, `As far as I am concerned this course was a total farce'.

This highlights the concern that many people would have about the relevance of these courses. I do not think the department can hide behind anything in these areas. I wrote to the director of the department in Darwin on 24 February, with the complaint that I had received. I have not to date received any acknowledgment nor reply to the problems and the issues that were raised in that area. When a Labor government participates through DEET in offering these sorts of courses, it is time we looked carefully at the outcomes of the various courses of this nature that are run, to see whether they are just mickey mouse courses that do nothing but keep people engaged in activities rather than containing relevance that can help them get out of the dilemma of being long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that Graham Richardson and Peter Barron have made it crystal clear that they do not know of any deal involving Mr Packer and Mr Howard and the nominal Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, has conspicuously and predictably run for cover, do you support the Prime Minister's outrageous allegations of a secret deal—yes or no?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The evidence that matters about this particular arrangement is the evidence that is on the public record. The evidence on the public record is completely sufficient to make the point that the Prime Minister has been making. As to any additional evidence that we have that is not on the public record, of course we are not going to compromise sensitive sources of information any more than you would compromise your sources for the leaked Finance document. We can't disclose and we won't disclose them, but the point can be perfectly well made without relying on any evidence of that type.

PARA.TAB: The evidence on the public record is in fact in five parts. Let me just go through it to remind you of it. In the first place there have been absolutely consistent statements since 1987 by Mr Howard that the existing cross-media rules are, in his words, `highly questionable'—or unnecessary or unjustified or out of date or irrelevant or in need of review—statements made with absolute consistency on the public record and repeated by him, as he says, privately to Mr Packer because, as he said, he said nothing different in private to what he said on the public record. Secondly, it is Mr Howard's stated preference—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question does not relate to assertions of policy positions. The question is about the assertion by Mr Keating that there was a secret deal done between Mr Howard and Mr Packer. What the minister has been asked is: what is the evidence of that secret deal, will he acknowledge that there is in fact no evidence and will he now apologise on behalf of his Prime Minister?

—Speaking to the point of order, what Senator Evans is clearly outlining is the substantial body of evidence that indicates there has been conspiracy that has led to cooperation between these parties and that is effectively relevant to the question.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is clearly relevant.

—I was asked about the evidence; I am stating the evidence. Item one of that evidence is the consistent statements that I have mentioned by Mr Howard. Item two—and the body of evidence has a cumulative impact—is the stated preference of Mr Howard and the opposition for the Trade Practices Act to ensure what they describe as the necessary degree of competition. He stated that in 1987 and he has been stating it ever since—not just as one possible way of addressing the monopolisation issue but as the way of addressing the monopolisation issue. Mr Howard said in 1987:

ANSWER.PARA: In our view, such matters are best left to the operation of the Trade Practices Act to prevent abuses flowing from concentration of ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I ask you to draw the minister's attention to the question because he is evading the question. The answer is yes or no.
—Order! It seems to me that the minister is building up an answer to the question. I am not in a position to judge—

—That is exactly what I will be doing for the remaining two or three minutes of this answer. The evidence is devastating when you put together these separate components of it. So there is that commitment to the Trade Practices Act—not as one among many ways of attacking the question of monopolisation but as the way of doing it, and repeated by Mr Costello yesterday in his ABC radio program in exactly those terms; and if I had time I would quote that at you, too.

PARA.TAB: The third piece of evidence is the clear and unequivocal statements on the public record by Professor Allan Fels, the chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, that the Trade Practices Act has no bearing on questions of cross-media ownership. He says, `The Trade Practices Act was designed to limit concentration of ownership of any particular market, but newspapers and television have not been regarded as separate markets, so Mr Packer would effectively be treated as a new player in the newspaper market.' In other words, there is no substance whatever to the suggestion that the Trade Practices Act could possibly address the policy matter that Mr Howard says he is hanging his hat on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is a point of order.
—I raise a point of order!

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He could not hear me.
—I heard you perfectly well, and I was trying to draw Senator Evans's attention to it. There is no need to call into the loudspeaker like that. Now, state your point of order.
—Mr President, on a point of order—
—Order! There is a point of order already before the chair and I have called Senator Herron. Senator Abetz, be seated.
—Thank you, Mr President. Senator Evans has made three points so far but has not attempted to answer the question. I ask you to draw his attention to the relevance of his answer.
—I have told the Senate many times that I am not in a position to dictate how a minister answers a question. If it is broadly relevant to the area of the question, it is relevant.
—Mr President, it is not merely broadly relevant; it is specifically relevant, because all these things are elements on the public record that point to the reality.

PARA.TAB: The fourth element on the public record is Mr Howard's answers to a series of doorstop questions on 6 March when he was asked five times in a row whether he regarded it as undesirable to prevent the simultaneous ownership in a particular capital city of a major paper and a major television station. He would not and did not answer that question. Of course it is on the public record, but it is a devastating account on the public evidence.

The final piece of evidence on the public record is the failure to produce any kind of a policy, or even promise to produce a policy, before the next election on what this anti-monopolisation commitment would mean in the context of cross-media ownership. The truth of the matter is that Mr Howard knows he is giving a very clear message, Mr Packer knows the message he is receiving and, between the two of them, they know what they have cooked up. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted to ask whether the minister is going to hand back his practising certificate, if he thinks that what he has just told us has got anything to do with allegations of a deep throat inside the Packer organisation.
—What is your question?

—My question is this: now that we know that Mr Keating's decision to publicly embarrass and humiliate the Singapore Prime Minister was not just an undisciplined outburst but was a carefully planned and premeditated strategy to escalate his own personal war with Kerry Packer, will the minister—who has at least some passing appreciation of the diplomatic protocols and niceties—make it clear that he does not condone the Prime Minister's outrageous behaviour? How does Mr Keating's crass and utterly insensitive conduct assist Australia's push into Asia?

—There are no diplomatic protocols or niceties involved in that, any more than there are when I stand on doorsteps next to Warren Christopher—or anyone from any other country—and he answers questions that are put to him about domestic policy issues. The truth of the matter is this: John Howard knows the message that he is giving to the Kerry Packers of this world. Kerry Packer knows the message that he is getting from the John Howards of this world. They can very comfortably read each other. It is a very mutually advantageous situation.
—On a point or order, I submit that this is an open and shut case of relevance.
—You can't submit anything. Come to your point of order.

—Would you mind? I am just making it. I do not expect you to understand it, but I think the President is capable of understanding what relevance is about. The fact is that the question was about the grossly insensitive and crass behaviour of the Prime Minister in Singapore. It has got nothing at all to do with what Mr Howard or Mr Packer might think. It is about whether Senator Evans, as the foreign minister, thinks that is behaviour that ought to be acceptable.
—Order! It was a supplementary question, and the whole thing must be taken into account.

—I am indebted to you, Mr President. Not only was it a supplementary question but it would have been out of order if it had not related to Mr Howard. I have already answered it by saying that that kind of practice is universal around the world. If you come out of a meeting and you are asked questions about a domestic issue, you answer them.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case, against the background that I have described, that Kerry Packer, Mr Howard and their respective acolytes have denied there is a deal. But as the Prime Minister said, in the immortal words of Mandy Rice-Davies, `Of course they would, wouldn't they?'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. As the minister would be aware, it is International Women's Day and 20 years since the first UN conference on women. Can the minister inform the Senate of the progress Australian women will celebrate today?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear an interjection from across the chamber that `this should not take long'. I am very pleased to say that is wrong; it will take quite a long time. In the time allowed, I will not be able to run through the achievements for women over the last 20 years, and in particular the achievements for women since this Labor government has come into office.

PARA.TAB: One of the greatest achievements of this government has been the introduction of the sex discrimination legislation in 1984 and, interestingly, in the same year, the introduction of Medicare—an extraordinarily great achievement on behalf of women because, of course, they had the problem of paying medical bills. In that same year we introduced the equal employment opportunities programs, particularly for the Public Service; and we have seen since then the establishment of the affirmative action legislation and agency to promote opportunities for women in the private sector and our tertiary institutions.

The other great program that I think we should never forget is the national education program for girls in Australian schools. We have seen the number of girls participating in school to year 12 go from about 44 per cent to over 80 per cent in the brief time that that has been in existence. That, I think, is probably one of the unspoken or unrecognised great achievements, because the benefits accrued by those young women will be with them all their lives.

We have also had a very dramatic change in the participation of women in the work force. That, of course, is the decision that women are making in the community, and I presume that part of it stems from their much better education and better opportunities as a result of that education. We now see something like 42 per cent of women in the work force, and we have introduced a couple of changes to very much assist them. The first and most important is our child care program—the increase from 46,000 places when we came into office to about a quarter of a million places now. There is quality with the accreditation program and the places are affordable with the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. At the same time, under ILO convention 156, we have introduced changes in the industrial relations legislation for workers with family responsibilities—and, of course, many of those are of direct and obvious benefit to women.

So, indeed, the achievements for women, under this government and certainly over the last 20 years, are very significant indeed. I think it was important at lunchtime when a number of the women in caucus met with a lot of school girls to take up the challenge of reminding them not only of the remote history but also the immediate history, things that are forgotten very quickly—achievements by this government, on behalf of women, that people sometimes do not even recall because they quickly come and quickly go in the minds of many.So I am delighted to have the opportunity today to put this on the record yet again. There are many other things, including domestic violence, for example, and the achievements there, that I do not have the opportunity in the time allowed to spell out in detail.

I do want to say in closing that last year, when I reported on the International Year of the Family and Australia's response to the United Nations, I made a proposal that out of the International Year of the Family a goal that the world, including Australia, could set itself would be that all the world's women be literate by the year 2000. We know what a change it would make to the health, the opportunities and the children of this world if women were literate. I note that many other people are calling for the same goal, including Mrs Clinton.

I believe that is a challenge we should take. It is easily measurable, it is not an outrageous expense and it would make a huge difference to the lives of women—a huge difference, to be able to read, to be able to participate in the information and education, to be able to pass that literacy on to their children. The evidence is there that, if the women are literate, in one generation the world's children will be literate. It is a challenge that I intend to push. I am delighted to see more and more support coming for it. I believe that it will be an excellent outcome from this government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Less than 48 hours before the meeting of the Reserve Bank board, the Prime Minister declared that he did not think further interest rate rises were necessary. He said that to the background of Australia's rate of inflation rising again, growing concerns about excessive wages growth and in spite of warnings from the Governor of the Reserve Bank and Syntec that Australia's loose budgetary policy and huge current account deficit make Australia hostage to the international financial markets. I ask: why did Mr Keating intervene in this way; why does Mr Keating always put his short-term political interests—in this instance, his desire to delay interest rate rises until after of the New South Wales election—ahead of national considerations; and is it not time that the Prime Minister, for a change, showed some national leadership?

—It is not a matter of short-term political calculation; it is a matter of calculation as to what is in the interests of the house owners and purchasers of this country and other people who are wanting to invest funds and need to borrow for that purpose. It is obviously in everybody's interests if interest rates can be kept as low as possible for as long as possible. Everyone acknowledges that.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that if some further stimulus has to be taken out of the economy in the present circumstances we prefer to do that by means of fiscal policy rather than further monetary policy. We have said that and we have made a very clear commitment in the context of this particular budget to a further acceleration of the deficit reduction program in order to achieve exactly that.

Of course we have not ruled out, and could not responsibly rule out, the possibility of further interest rate rises in the future if the economic situation demands that. Hopefully it will not be necessary. Hopefully sufficient stimulus has been taken out of the economy by the monetary policy route as a result of the decisions—the courageous decisions, but the necessary decisions—that were taken by the Reserve Bank in consultation, as always, with the government, in the latter part of last year.

It is our hope that that will not need to be taken any further, but of course we have to just wait and see. Nobody believes that it is necessary to act immediately, as the occasional commentators coming out of the woodwork, covering bets, earning their salary, earning their pay, I suppose, by making predictions, keeping everyone on their toes. That is fair enough. We understand the way the world works in that respect. But if we can possibly avoid it, it is very much in the interests of the whole economy.

Senator Hill, you have to ask the question, and you can tell me the answer in your supplementary question: are you going on the record right now to say that interest rates should be increased by the Reserve Bank board at its next meeting? Is that what you are saying? If that is not what you are saying, what sort of a question are you asking me? Do you think interest rates should go up right now? You do not think they should go up now. Thank you, Senator Hill. You just want to have it both ways. You are a hypocritical load of rubbish on this, as on everything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Hill asked the question, not Senator Evans. The answer that Senator Evans' was giving towards the end when he was raving and ranting was not relevant to the question. Australia already has the highest interest rates in the OECD, the second highest real interest rates, and Senator Hill asked whether or not those interest rates are going to go up. Senator Evans has refused to answer that.
