—Your point is made. I was wondering who was asking the question and who was answering it.
—Mr President, I raise a further point of order. In that exchange I heard an unparliamentary term go across the table and I think Senator Evans should withdraw it.
—I certainly did not hear it. If it appears in the Hansard, I will have a look at it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has obviously missed the point. The point is that the only answer that the government had in the late 1980s to the current account crisis was to push interest rates up, and it pushed them up to the extent of the worst recession in 60 years. So far in answer to this crisis all we have seen is the same policy—push interest rates up. The government has done it twice already and all of a sudden, just before the New South Wales state election, just before the board meeting of the Reserve Bank, the Prime Minister says it is now unnecessary. Do you seriously expect us to believe that there is no relationship between what the Prime Minister said and the imminent New South Wales state election?

—I have answered that question already. No responsible government could play with the lives of Australian business and Australian householders in so trivialising a fashion. That is not what we are about. We are about responsible economic management.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that official interest rates will continue to be adjusted as appropriate to reduce the risk of the economy overheating 12 to 18 months out. That is the policy we have been adopting now for the last six to 12 months and that is the policy we will continue to adopt.

We hope very much that that will mean that there will not be any necessity for rates to rise further but, if it does mean that interest rates do rise further, the situation in the economy as a whole is such that we can be very confident—as the Treasurer has said, as the Prime Minister has said and as I have said—that interest rates will certainly not need to rise to anything like the same extent as they have in past cycles.

TALK.START.PARA: —They already have.
—That is not the case. If there is a bit of time, let me respond to that interjection by saying this: the official cash rate and three month bill rates—(Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The minister would be aware of reports that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has condemned the action by the opposition, particularly its environmental spokesman, Mr McLachlan, in copying sensitive Aboriginal documents. Is the minister aware of reports that Aboriginal women have been betrayed by Mr McLachlan and the opposition in providing some of these documents to the media and other politicians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a considerable amount of outrage expressed both within the Aboriginal community and, I might add, in the broader Australian community, about the actions of the coalition in this matter. But there is one—
—Is Sean McLaughlin a man or a woman?
—I just wanted to get that interjection into Hansard. There is one aspect of the honourable member for Barker—
—Answer the question.

—Just listen and I will. There is one aspect of the honourable member for Barker's actions in this matter that has been overlooked in this debate to this point in time which I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate, and it is as a result of a fascinating interview that the shadow minister for Aboriginal Affairs gave on the Murray Nicoll program in Adelaide yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The outrage of Aboriginal women—and it has been widespread—at the coalition's actions is understandable. But it comes as no surprise to me or to anybody else who has been in public life in the Northern Territory for some time. Senator Tambling, of course, knows what I am referring to.

I heard Senator Campbell speak today on a matter of public interest. I listened to him expressing outrage that the coalition is constantly being condemned by people for being less than sensitive about Aboriginal issues, particularly those issues that go to the heart of Aboriginal spirituality and their sacred beliefs. I hear what you say, Senator Campbell, but I have to tell you, as well intentioned as you are, that you are constantly let down by senior members of your conservative party. Who from the Northern Territory would be surprised at this action?

I well remember, Senator Tambling—and you know what I am talking about—the current Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, when he was Minister for Lands, ordering the bulldozing of a sacred site in Alice Springs against the Northern Territory's own laws—not the Commonwealth laws—the Northern Territory's own sacred sites act. He did it knowingly and he did it willingly.

Everybody talks about Max Ortmann, a minister of the Northern Territory government, and his attempt to strangle a journalist. Uncharitable people have suggested—not me—that he was doing it on behalf of us all. Others have actually said that it was the only worthwhile thing mad Max did in his entire parliamentary career. I do not agree with any of that, but do not forget, Senator Tambling, what Max Ortmann's first national television debut was. You know what I am talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question.
—I am answering the question.
—You are digressing a fair way.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As I recall the question, it was something to do with: are you aware of concern? We have had about two minutes of tirade on Mr McLachlan. Now we seem to be getting more odium heaped on a former Northern Territory politician. Surely none of this can be relevant to the issue of whether you are aware. I would have thought the answer to that was yes or no.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the incident that I am about to refer to, as Senator Tambling knows, directly related to treatment of Aboriginal women by coalition politicians. I am about to get to it.
—That may be so, but you are digressing fairly widely. I would ask you to try to get back onto the point of the question.

—The point of the question was the insult and injury done to Aboriginal women in Australia. The first foray of Mr Ortmann, Senator Tambling's colleague, on national television was at a public meeting in Alice Springs which was broadcast across Australia.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have just directed Senator Collins, in effect, to get to the point of the question. The question had nothing to do with Max Ortmann or Northern Territory politics.
—You don't know.

—What, I do not know what the question was? I just happen to be listening to it, which is obviously more than you were doing. If you had listened to the question you would have some idea what you are talking about. The question had nothing to do with Northern Territory politics. He was simply asked whether he was aware of a matter involving South Australian politics at best. You have already told him to answer that. You should not allow him to flout your rulings.
—Order! Senator Collins assured me that he was getting back to the point and I accepted that assurance.

—To alleviate the concern of the opposition, I point out that I will get this on the Hansard record after question time. It is well known and of no surprise to me the attitude of coalition representatives in relation to this matter—I was replying to what Senator Campbell said during the public interest debate at lunch time. I can understand Doreen Kartinyeri's hurt and so can all Aboriginal women across Australia. I believe that her hurt and outrage is shared by all women, not just Aboriginal women. This is what she said—the woman who handed over these documents—on AM this morning:

ANSWER.PARA: I feel devastated. I feel absolutely wrecked and ruined. Ian McLachlan has betrayed Aboriginal women. He has betrayed me.

He does not discriminate on the basis of race. He treats all women with contempt. He has treated his own shadow minister with contempt. Ian McLachlan has had for two months documents relating to Aboriginal women's business, the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs and the South Australian issue. Chris Gallus told radio in Adelaide yesterday that the first she knew that he even had the documents was when he handed them over to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in the House of Representatives. It is unbelievable. She disassociated herself from Ian McLachlan by saying that the first time she saw the documents was when they were handed by Mr McLachlan across to the minister. She was responding to a question linking her to his actions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister also inform the Senate of the view of the commission in relation to the release of the documents by Mr McLachlan.

—The commission is outraged as we all are. I am waiting for an apology from the opposition—that is what everyone is waiting for—and particularly from the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. She said on Adelaide radio yesterday that she did not even know that her colleague on the frontbench had these documents for two months. She did not know that he was spraying them across the landscape to lawyers and journalists. The honourable member for Barker, Mr McLachlan, did not talk to his colleague from South Australia and shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs who is, as it happens, a woman. In her words, the first time she knew about it was when he handed them across to Mr Tickner in the House of Representatives yesterday. As I said, the one thing you cannot accuse Ian McLachlan of doing is discriminating on the basis of race. He treats all women with contempt, including his own shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs.

—My question is directed to Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and relates to the Port Hinchinbrook development at Cardwell in North Queensland. I draw the minister's attention to article 2 of the World Heritage Convention which says that scientific and aesthetic values are the determinant of world heritage values in natural areas. Is the minister aware that incremental approvals are being sought and/or given for this project? These include the mangrove clearing, dredge spoil ponds with no environmental impact statement and a permit to build a breakwater wall. Does the minister agree that incremental approvals do not reflect an appropriate assessment of world heritage areas, which require a whole project approach? Will the minister assure the Senate that the total effect of this development on world heritage area values will be used as the method for assessing any permits given by the Commonwealth?

—Before answering Senator Woodley's question, I preface my remarks by pointing out that permits and approvals for this particular project are the responsibility of the Queensland government. My role and that of the Commonwealth is to protect the world heritage property. I can assure Senator Woodley, as I have when he has asked me a number of other questions in relation this project, and other senators that I am taking that responsibility very seriously.

PARA.TAB: The world heritage proclamations made on 15 November 1994 require the developer, Mr Keith Williams, to obtain ministerial consent before commencing any activity which may damage the proclaimed area of the Hinchinbrook Channel. I can inform Senator Woodley that Mr Williams has recently sought my consent to undertake three activities: the construction of two breakwaters, dredging a marina access channel and implementing a foreshore management plan which includes the construction of an artificial beach.

My department will advise me on any potential impacts of the proposed activities on the proclaimed area. I have made it clear to Mr Williams and to all other interested parties that my responsibility with regard to this development is to ensure that it does not damage the adjacent world heritage area. The evaluation of any requests for consent will bear this in mind and will be based on the best information that can be available.

The department is seeking to contract consultants to assist with this impact assessment. The consultants will review the plans for the proposed works, seek advice from relevant experts, review literature and prepare a report which will summarise their findings. Every attempt will be made to minimise the time taken without compromising in any way the quality or thoroughness of the assessments that are required. I will not be giving consent to any one of these activities without considering the impact of the other two activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Before Australia signed the Uruguay Round of GATT, my request for a full environmental, economic and social impact assessment of the new trade regime on Australia was dismissed. At the same time, figures of between $2.5 billion and $5 billion a year were confidently being announced as expected benefits to Australia, including over $1 billion a year in agricultural exports. Was it not misleading to omit the impact of the huge, increasing value added imports to Australia which were inevitable under the new trade arrangements and which have blown out our trade deficit by over $906 million for January this year? Has the government commissioned a full social, economic and environmental impact assessment of GATT and now APEC? If not, why not?

—In the case of Australia, the overwhelming balance of benefit in the Uruguay Round is in Australia's interests. That does not mean that there are no downsides, but the overwhelming balance of benefit is positive for Australia. That is predominantly an economic benefit. But it is true that we have to look at the wider aspects of its implication as well. There is no doubt that, to the extent that it generates extra jobs, it is a significant social benefit. To the extent that the Uruguay Round reduces agricultural subsidies and improves the efficiency with which land is used in other countries, it is in that way and others, including the establishment of a trade and environment committee under the new WTO, of environmental benefit.

PARA.TAB: The figures of the benefits to Australia from the Uruguay Round are not figures that have been manufactured or concocted. The Australian analysis done, for example, by the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics is broadly unchallenged, but the international analysis by, for example, the OECD reinforces that view. They are of the same order. Certainly both say that Australia is one of the significant beneficiaries.

With regard to the question of Australia's reductions in tariffs, Senator Margetts on several occasions has laboured under the misapprehension that Australia has reduced its tariff because the Uruguay Round required us to. That is not the case. It never was the case. Nobody but her ever thought it was the case. Australia made unilateral decisions to reduce its tariffs as a matter of domestic economic policy. That was passed before the outcome of the Uruguay Round was known and is more than sufficient to meet all the requirements the Uruguay Round imposed upon us in terms of the big changes. We made three or four specific changes that went through with the legislative package with regard to orange juice. In relation to dairy, we made a commitment that we would put an equal support arrangement in place.

So the big changes in relation to import regulation in Australia, import barriers in Australia, the removal of quotas and the reduction in tariffs were decisions made—Senator Margetts is entitled to disagree with them—but they were not Uruguay Round driven changes. They were domestic economic policy driven changes, which I support and which I think are being reflected in significantly enhanced efficiency and competitiveness.

But that is a matter for debate. Senator Margetts has a different view, which of course she is entitled to have, but those changes do not relate to the Uruguay Round. If they did, I would not apologise for them because I think they are changes in Australia's national interest. People have to realise that the importers are Australians too. The people who are buying the products and who say, `These are the products I want at the price I want to pay for them,' are Australians. The beneficiaries of these imports, including the people who are getting jobs putting in place the capital equipment that is coming in, are Australians. The people in the factories and on the farms using those products at cheaper prices are Australians. The people getting the benefit of lower prices for clothing are Australians.

The people who advocate high tariffs are nearly always the same people who are anti-indirect taxes, and tariffs are as regressive an indirect tax as you can find. They are in many ways more iniquitous than the GST. Therefore, it is entirely inconsistent for the people who I remember were opposing indirect taxes in the 1993 budget to be advocating higher tariffs. I do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens are fully and painfully aware that the government went far beyond its requirements under the Uruguay Round of GATT. What I am asking is whether or not the sacrifices made by such industries as the fruit juice industry, egg producers and so on as a result supposedly of gaining all these benefits will in fact be assessed in their totality and when and whether the government will do a full impact assessment instead of just relying on some vague assurances. We know the government is not interested in the social and environmental impacts but, even on economic grounds, when will the government do a full study on the impacts of its changing trade policies?

—I do not know where this furphy that the downsides were not included in the assessment of the Bureau of Agricultural Resource Economics comes from—they clearly were. We could have the whole of the Australian bureaucracy applied to analysing for a year all the changes that were made in the 1,200 pages of the Uruguay Round and their environment, economic and social implications for Australia and for other countries. It would add nothing to the sum of knowledge that we have. There are pluses and minuses in all changes. It was a negotiated outcome. It was not an outcome dictated by Australia to the rest of the world, but we are significant net beneficiaries.

PARA.TAB: Those benefits are flowing in terms of increased sales. There is the potential for our rice growers to sell hundreds of thousands of tonnes of rice to Japan, which is a significant benefit. Anybody who does not want that to happen should go to Leeton and explain to the rice growers and the workers in the associated factories why they should not get access to that market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to claims made by Michael O'Connor from the forestry union yesterday when he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Everybody knows that on March 25 there's a state election . . . and to have New South Wales not have any logging coupes released before the 25th of March quite clearly smacks of them attempting to support their mate Bob Carr.

I also refer the minister to similar comments made by caucus chairman, Jim Snow, who went as far as to describe cabinet's decision as a cop-out. Have not Mr Snow and Mr O'Connor simply confirmed the real reasons why cabinet reneged on Senator Collins's agreement with the New South Wales government to release between 33 and 35 forestry coupes in that state?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to this is terribly straightforward. I wish Senator Brownhill would listen to what is being said by government spokesmen; I wish he would listen to what I say now. Coupes were not released in New South Wales because that state government, unlike other states, simply had not provided information on the values contained within the relevant forest compartments and the extent to which those values were adequately represented in existing reserve systems.

PARA.TAB: Instead of providing the information that had been requested, New South Wales simply asked the Commonwealth to endorse its forestry assessment and regulatory processes and release all nominated coupes on that basis. That was not a tenable position for the Commonwealth to be able to respond to. Although they sought to be treated differently, the Commonwealth has not been satisfied that these New South Wales processes are adequate to protect forest areas and therefore will not consider accrediting those processes.

Notwithstanding the representations and the noises made by Jim Snow, the forestry industries and unions and others, we will not consider accrediting these processes until further assessments are completed. Preliminary analysis by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories of the data provided by New South Wales agencies on existing reserves indicates that many forest types are significantly under-represented in the reserve system. That test of representativeness was applied equally—

TALK.START.PARA: —At least my practice was not confined to that, unlike yours. That test was applied equally to all states. The Commonwealth has not been bullied into treating New South Wales any differently. That is exactly the way the issue has been approached. It has been approached systematically and carefully. We would love to have been in a position to respond in an even-handed way with New South Wales, as we did with the others, in order to avoid the cheap and vulgar shots that we are getting from you and others like you. The truth of the matter is exactly as I have described it.

—I would have to say, seeing you are representing the Prime Minister, pigs diddle! Why did not Senator Collins raise the government's concerns about the nature of the information the New South Wales government was provided with. There were nine telephone calls with Mr Souris, the minister in New South Wales. Why were not those concerns raised at the meeting held with the Commonwealth and state officials in Sydney on 13 and 14 February? Why were those concerns omitted from the letter from Roger Beale, Associate Secretary of the PM&C, in early March to the state's unions and the industries that requested more information on coupes from other states but not from New South Wales? Why did not you release the compartments in Glenbog and Tantawanglo state forests in New South Wales which have already been assessed by the Commonwealth's own inquiry and agreed to as being available for logging under the south-east forests agreement signed by Michael Lee and George Souris. You were reneging on another deal. Sign up and you don't do the job right. You can't tell the truth.

—I have been accused on occasion of not contributing to raising the tone of debate in this place to quite the extent that it might otherwise have been possible, but I do not think I have ever contributed anything like `pigs diddle' to the debate. But I must say I am minded to do so in response to that supplementary question. It is a supplementary question which simply fails to have regard to the truth of the proposition that I put to you. The information that was put to us by the New South Wales government was simply not of a kind that made it possible to make any kind of assessment of the value of the compartments concerned or the extent to which their values were represented elsewhere. If that information had been supplied instead of a political position being taken by the New South Wales government of not being willing to cooperate in any other way than to say, `Our processes are sacrosanct and our processes are not, and should not be, subject to scrutiny,' and if the New South Wales government had responded in a more cooperative way and a less political way, it might have had a better result. (Time expired)

—My question, which will probably be a little less colourful, is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to recent calls for the government to ensure that people who have been responsible for war crimes are not able to enter Australia as migrants or humanitarian cases. Are these concerns warranted? What is the government doing to ensure such persons do not enter Australia?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for his question which raises an issue which the community has some concern about, and quite rightly so. With the increase in local armed conflicts since the end of the Cold War, we must be on the alert to ensure that people who have been involved in major breaches of human rights do not enter Australia.

PARA.TAB: In this respect, the Australian government shares the concern of the community that these criminals may try to enter Australia as migrants or humanitarian entrants. In doing so, they would not only undermine the harmony and democracy of our culturally diverse society but also deny justice to their victims.

The government has been continually addressing this issue. We recently made a number of changes to enhance migration processes. These changes go to both the processes overseas to protect our offshore programs as well as to processes domestically to ensure that allegations against individuals in Australia are, and can be, dealt with effectively. I will go to some of these enhancements.

Firstly, when people apply for migration or refugee status offshore, their names are matched against a warning list known as the migrant alert list so that people of concern to authorities are brought to the attention of the relevant posts. That system has been strengthened in recent weeks to provide for a better identification mechanism. Secondly, to ensure that this system is working efficiently with state-of-the-art technology, an outside consultant has been commissioned to review its name-matching techniques. Any further action will be taken on the recommendations of that report.

Thirdly, as well as what I have already mentioned, a standing interdepartmental working group has been established to achieve and maintain a more active and systematic approach from government agencies to identify potential entrants responsible for human rights abuse. It will do so in a number of ways, including through the coordination of the systematic identification of situations involving the widespread and gross abuse of human rights as well as the collection of details for possible inclusion on the migrant alert list of high profile figures thought to be responsible for such war crimes.

Fourthly, we have also enhanced processes to ensure that all allegations about the possible entry into Australia of people who have been alleged to have committed major human rights violations will now be referred to a central point within my department. That point will be responsible for the examination of any relevant material held within the department; for organising inquiries through other agencies and departments; for contact with the complainant, if necessary, to obtain further particulars; for undertaking or coordinating an assessment of the claims; as well as the quick briefing of senior officers and relevant ministers as appropriate. I can assure Senator Chris Evans and the Senate that, just as the government has been concerned to take action to prevent the entry into Australia of people involved in organised crime, we are whole-heartedly committed to protecting this society from anyone who may have been involved in war crimes internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer the minister to the latest national survey of business expectations by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which once again demonstrates the failure of both the government and the minister to provide any real support for small business in this country. Is the minister aware that the survey has revealed that the federal government's measures to slow the economy have had a regressive effect on small business? In fact, two-thirds of small businesses do not expect conditions to improve. Why has the minister failed to implement measures to protect small business from the regressively high interest rates of the Treasurer, Mr Willis?

—This is the first time in two years that a Liberal member of the Senate has asked me a question about small business. I congratulate Senator Calvert. It has taken two years for a Liberal senator to ask a question about, and profess an interest in, small business. This is unlike Senator Boswell, who has occasionally asked me a question and shows genuine interest.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. This preamble to the minister's answer is entirely irrelevant. The coalition would certainly not express its concern for small business by asking this bloke questions about small business. You will not get a straight answer, because he does not know what he is talking about.
—Order! The last point had nothing to do with the point of order. I ask the minister to get on with his answer.

—I thought my remarks were quite pertinent because of the lack of interest by Liberal senators. However, I point out to Senator Calvert that only last Friday we had a meeting of the National Small Business Forum, which represents over 30 organisations of small business and industry groups in Australia. At that forum, we had an hour's discussion with the Treasurer about issues such as interest rates, fiscal matters in the budget, the FBT and a range of other issues which small business is interested in. It was a very open discussion. We also dealt with issues such as franchising and so on. All of those discussions were very constructive. As a result, we were able to take up a number of issues, as we have in the past.

PARA.TAB: Senator Calvert should recognise the work of those small business organisations; there is a very constructive atmosphere. At the end of last year the National Institute of Accountants raised with me its concerns about interest rates and their impact on small business. As a result I asked the institute to conduct a survey of its members. That survey was published in January of this year. It showed that the accountancy members who were surveyed, representing about 80,000 small business accounts, had a genuine concern about future rises in interest rates. I discussed that matter with both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, and those issues are obviously going to be discussed in the budget context.

Also at the discussion last Friday the Treasurer made it very clear that we do not want to raise interest rates to any level above what is absolutely necessary. He also pointed out that if you do not want to raise interest rates, you have to look at fiscal measures, and that includes the cutting of government expenditure and tax matters, without committing the government to any particular outcome. He made it very clear to the small business community that its interest in maintaining interest rates at the lowest possible level will require other action by the government. That was accepted by the members of the small business groups present.

I say to Senator Calvert that this government has a very close working relationship with the Small Business Forum in Australia and has a very close dialogue with those organisations, which are not interested in the ideological baggage or warfare that senators opposite may want to go on about. Small business wants a specific working relationship with the government where it can raise issues of concern and where we deal with them in a practical and open manner. As a result, we get good outcomes. The Small Business Forum is now acting as the major conduit of information to the government on small business issues. One thing is for certain: Liberal senators opposite have no idea, not a clue, about the practical workings of small business. I suspect it will be another two years before a Liberal senator asks a question on small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his attempt to answer my question. Minister: could you give a glimmer of hope to the two-thirds of small businesses in Australia that do not think things are going to improve?

—What the Senator Calverts of the world want to do with economic policy is spend more money, reduce taxes and balance the budget. You have the same view about interest rates. You want to keep interest rates at low levels; at the same time, you do not want to take any action on the fiscal side. All you want to do is go around espousing an irresponsible populist policy. People realise that there have to be adjustments from time to time. This government has made modest judgments to keep an ongoing growth level in this economy. If we keep growth in this economy at around four per cent, that is the best thing we can do for small business, and that is what we are aiming to do.

—In view of the importance of the forthcoming international meeting in Berlin in late March and early April on strategies and agreements to address the greenhouse problem, I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Foreign Affairs: which departments will be represented in the Australian delegation to the Berlin meeting? How many people will be drawn from each of these departments, and who are those people? Will other non-departmental advisers be included? Has the government formulated the material that will be put before the meeting, and will this material be exposed to parliamentary scrutiny before it is put before the eyes of the delegates of other nations?

—I just happen to have the information to hand that Senator Coulter has asked for. I am happy to give it to him. I welcome his interest in the convention. It is, after all, one of the most important meetings on this year's international environmental agenda, and it is one in which we obviously have a major interest. My friend and colleague Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, and an outstanding representative of his country on this and other matters, will, as you would expect, lead Australia's delegation to the conference.

PARA.TAB: Officials making up Australia's delegation will be drawn from the whole range of departments dealing with climate change matters. Credentials for the delegation are yet to be finalised, but planning is proceeding on the basis that those departmental representatives will come from Foreign Affairs and Trade, DEST and the Bureau of Meteorology, Industry, Science and Technology, Primary Industries and Energy, Attorney-General's and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau.

Consistent with existing practices in relation to international environmental negotiations, the delegation also includes a representative of the state governments and representatives of business and industry groups, environment and conservation groups and the ACTU. I understand that a range of business and public interest groups with interests in these negotiations will also be present in the margins of the Berlin meeting. I should perhaps add that the opposition spokesman on the environment, Mr McLachlan, of recent notoriety, has asked to join the delegation at his own cost. The government will endeavour to accommodate that request.

As to the last question, Australia's position and approach to the Berlin meeting is currently being finalised. As in all previous cases involving international negotiating sessions under the framework convention on climate change, this process does involve full consideration by cabinet of Australia's negotiating position and full consultation with interested parties.

Consultations, accordingly, with the states and non-government organisations have been arranged by my department for next week. This will be followed by cabinet consideration before Australia's negotiating position and the detailed delegation brief are finalised. Senator Coulter should be confident that as a result of this extensive process the full range of Australia's interests will be represented in the position Australia continues to take in these negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask the minister to tell the Senate plainly: has the government changed its trade liberalisation policy within the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum? Is it true that, despite the Australian government's clear rejection at the Seattle and Bogor meetings of APEC ever becoming a trade block, there are now new elements emerging in Australia's position leading up to Osaka? Will the minister clarify our objectives within APEC, surely a centrepiece of Australia's foreign and trade policy, and confirm that Australia is not stepping back from the comprehensive trade liberalisation we have supported from the beginning of APEC?

—I think Senator McMullan has already answered a question recently on this subject. I repeat for the record: there is no change in Australia's basic position, which is one of unequivocal support for multilateral trade liberalisation on a global basis, with anything we do in APEC by way of trade liberalisation agenda matters contributing to that larger objective. It is absolutely the last thing on our minds, and always has been since APEC was formed, that it should constitute any kind of trade block engaged in either defensive or offensive trade war with other countries or other groupings, like the European Union.

PARA.TAB: There is an argument, of course, as to how best the Bogor objectives might actually be achieved—whether it is best done by way of simple unilateral liberalisation on an MFN basis, with or without some associated process of negotiation, or whether rather that longer term objective, and global trade liberalisation, might best be achieved by building up on a sequence of preferential trade agreements, perhaps using existing building blocks that already operate in this way within the APEC region. Australia has not excluded the possibility of that being a way towards reaching the larger objective, but our preference is—I think it is probably fair to say, and as the Prime Minister has recently said—for an approach which does not in any way compromise, even in a transient basis, the MFN principle.

I should say, though, so that it is clearly understood, that the notion of getting to the larger objectives on a free trade agreement route would necessarily have to be consistent with GATT article 24—it could not be put in place otherwise—and it would need to be a free trade agreement with a difference. It could not just be the kind of preferential model we have had in the past, unaccompanied by any simultaneous commitment to unilateral liberalisation as against the rest of the world, because to go down that particular path would be to be erecting, arguably, defensive barriers.

The only basis on which I think you could justify it would be as an interim measure designed essentially to exercise some obvious leverage against other trading nations outside APEC in order to get them to participate in a full international round. I think there is a very strong case in fact to be made for proceeding earlier rather than later to a new WTO GATT round on a universal basis as the best way of squaring all these circles and meeting our various objectives.

That may be an unrealistic objective in the short to medium term, but it is certainly an objective that we should retain in the longer term. I think in practice the way forward is not likely to prove to be through that FTA mechanism, qualified as I have described, but rather through some more obviously and consistently MFN oriented position; but I do not think anything that we are doing as these negotiations proceed should be seen as, in any way, compromising on the fundamental principles to which we have been committed from the outset.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the week Senator Knowles asked a rather tendentious question, if I can put it in those terms because it was based on extremely outdated information, about payment of casual staff at the Lodge and Kirribilli, but let me give her a response notwithstanding.
—The Auditor-General's report was only tabled last week.

—The Auditor-General's report on which she based that question may only have been tabled last week, but the matters with which it dealt were in the public prints last August and were attended to and fixed by the government back in July last year.

PARA.TAB: The answer in detail is as follows: the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet recognised early last year before the matter was raised in the press in August that there were unintended taxation and superannuation concerns about the longstanding procedures then in place for the payment through the petty cash system of casual staff at official establishments. As from late May 1994, in the case of the Lodge, and 1 July 1994, in the case of Kirribilli House, all casual staff have been employed under contract and paid through the department's salary system which picks up, as you would expect, the tax and superannuation aspects. The department since that time has been meeting its statutory obligations in relation to casual employees at the Lodge and Kirribilli House.

The Australia National Audit Office review, to which Senator Knowles referred, noted that there was no intention to defraud the Commonwealth, that action had been taken by the department to rectify the situation and that the department had agreed with and implemented the further action recommended by the audit office. Under those circumstances, I think you can put away your handcuffs, Senator. There does not seem to be much prospect of criminal action being successfully taken against the Prime Minister or anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March, Senator Harradine asked me a question with regard to industrial relations. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator Robert Ray—On 2 March 1995 Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following Question Without Notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine—I ask a question about a decision which I believe will cause great exploitation to workers. It may be the most massively problematic decision in the industrial history of Australia. My question is to the minister representing the industrial relations minister, Mr Brereton. I quote from the Australian this morning:

The Industrial Commission yesterday did something entirely foreign in its 90-year history as an interventionist body: It formally abdicated its role as the central mechanism for workplace negotiations in this country.
By its own hand, the commission had redefined employer and employee relations in the labour market, ruling no legislative power exists to force parties to the negotiating table.

I ask the Minister: why did Mr Brereton this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald say that certainty was restored to the bargaining process and responsibility would lie with the parties concerned, when many non-union and union workers are unable to get their employer to negotiate? Is it not a fact that the decision means that it is a dead-set certainty that those workers will be kept trapped in the safety net well below the average wages and working conditions that are contained in the EFAs?
In my reply I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:
The protection for workers provided by the safety net of award wages and conditions should not be undervalued.

The objective of the Industrial Relations Reform Act was to encourage enterprise bargaining. The Government's reforms ensure that employees can participate in enterprise bargaining with the certainty that award wages and conditions are protected by the `no disadvantage' test.

The award safety net was also strengthened as part of the reform package. Key minimum employee entitlements were incorporated, based on Australia's international obligations in relation to a minimum wage, equal pay for work of equal value without discrimination based on sex, parental leave and protections in relation to termination and redundancy.
The Government's legislative reforms also enable periodic safety net adjustments determined by the AIRC to maintain its relevance.
The Opposition evidently regards such protections as a mere "matter of detail."

Further, it is not true to say that union and non-union workers who wish to negotiate an enterprise agreement with their employer under the Government's legislation have no means to get their employer to negotiate.

Workers in unionised workplaces have access for the first time to protected industrial action when they are seeking single business certified agreements, because the Government recognises that the ability to take industrial action is an important part of an enterprise bargaining system with the parties themselves taking responsibility for their own industrial relations outcomes.
In non-unionised workplaces, if workers want to negotiate and employers do not, workers can pursue an EFA and seek the Commission's assistance through conciliation.
Or workers can seek an order from the Commission that employers meet and confer with them, and take other steps which are compatible with bargaining in good faith.
Or workers can ask a relevant union to seek an order on their behalf—a possibility which the Asahi decision leaves open, where employees wish it.
Or workers can join a union, which can seek such orders and/or notify a bargaining period and take protected industrial action for a single business certified agreement.
In the Asahi case the workers did not wish to pursue a claim or join a union or take protected industrial action.
That was their choice and the decision demonstrates that the system is robust and flexible enough to encompass all options.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March 1995, Senator Panizza asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . considering the Sex Discrimination Bill was passed in part to prevent discrimination against married people, why will he not seek further exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act so Austudy can be paid to the students in that category?

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to Senator Panizza's question. Up to 31 December 1994, one of the grounds for independent status for the purposes of Austudy was marriage. This criteria contravened the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 as it discriminated against those students who were in a de facto relationship and those who were single. However, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner had granted an exemption from the provisions of the SDA until the regulations could be amended, and no later than 31 December 1994.

PARA.TAB: The government decided to amend the regulations to bring the scheme into compliance with the Sex Discrimination Act by removing marriage as a ground for independence. This was done by the making of regulations on 6 December 1994 to come into effect on 1 January 1995. On 9 February 1995, the Senate passed a motion disallowing the regulations tabled by the government to bring the Austudy regulations into conformity with the Sex Discrimination Act 1995.

The Senate's action also removed the regulation which provided for the preservation of independent status for those students previously granted independence on the grounds of marriage. In moving to disallow the amending regulations, the Senate understood that the 1994 Austudy regulations would be revived, thereby re-establishing marriage as a ground for independent status for the estimated 2,200 students affected.

Advice from the Attorney-General's Department is that the disallowance has not achieved this effect, because the Austudy regulations are still inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act. The effect of such inconsistency is that section 26 of the Sex Discrimination Act renders inoperative the revived regulations, and the Austudy scheme should be administered on and from 9 February 1995 by disregarding the revived regulations. Therefore, notwithstanding the carriage of the disallowance, students under 22 years of age who subsequently apply for Austudy cannot be granted independent status solely on the basis of being, or previously having been, married. I point out that the government remains committed to the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Denman this day, relating to International Women's Day.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say to start with that there were no notices of motion from the other side recognising that today is International Women's Day. In her answer, Senator Crowley left out a whole lot of women. She was happy to talk about the government's record, but she failed to talk about women in the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: Women in the Public Service is a domain over which the government has total control; it has control over how many women will be represented. When you look at that area over which it has the greatest influence, its record is not all that good. In fact, its record is pretty dismal after 12 years in government.

There are 231 senior women executives at the branch head level in federal government, 47 at divisional head level and only seven at the top rung. There is only one female head of a department, and that is the tourism chief, Ms Helen Williams. At the starting level of the senior executive service, 18.3 per cent are women. At the middle rung, it is only 12.4 per cent, and at the top, it is only 8.5 per cent.

If we look at the government departments rather than overall government bodies, the number of women in senior positions is far fewer. Some departments do less well than others. Barely nine per cent of the SES jobs in DFAT are occupied by women, and only six of Australia's 77 head of mission positions are occupied by women. Many of those are `jobs for the boys' for people who have left the benches here. There have been no jobs for the women. Did Sue Ryan get a job overseas? No. They have all been jobs for the boys.

Across the Public Service only 16 per cent of SES jobs are occupied by women. Women account for 48 per cent of permanent APS staff, but the proportion of women in administrative senior officer positions and in senior executive streams decreases as the classification increases. No wonder the minister did not put anything about this in her answer. The government has had 12 years to do something about it and it has done very little.

Did the minister talk about the government's record in superannuation? No. Why not? Because, as far as women in superannuation go, its record is appalling—appalling. It was the coalition who first put into its policies the idea that women who go in and out of the work force ought to have a retirement savings account. Who stole that idea? The Labor Party, but it only gave that to them for two years.

What else has this government done? It has done nothing about dealing with superannuation and with the way it is dealt with in divorce. The government has put that in the too-hard basket too. So it has not dealt with the issue of superannuation or with the fact that women go in and out of the work force and have problems with superannuation. Now, with compulsory superannuation, many women are facing the fact that administrative costs chew up most of their superannuation. So that is the government's record on superannuation.

What else did Senator Crowley not talk about? She did not talk about the carers. They are mostly women, thousands upon thousands of women, day in and day out—and I think once before in this chamber I said this—who labour for 26 hours a day—and I ask Hansard not to change that this time to 24 hours, as it did last time—looking after people, in particular those with dementia but also young people and other people in families with disabilities. The vast majority of those carers receive little or no help from Labor. Current respite care arrangements are inflexible, inaccessible and inappropriate to the widely varying needs of carers. The trade union dominated industrial relations system has been painstakingly slow in recognising the dual responsibilities of many women as both unpaid carers and valuable members of the work force. Senator Crowley did not talk about the government's record in that area either.

Another group Senator Crowley did not talk about was rural women. She did not talk about the promise—what was it?—that there will be no new taxes before the election. What did rural women have straight after the election? They had an increase in petrol excise. That affected them getting into town, delivering their kids to school and going to after-school events and meetings.

Senator Crowley also did not talk about the tardy response of this government to the drought—and who were affected by that? Many, in fact most, rural women were affected by the government's tardy response. That is the record she should have talked about. This government has failed women; its record is poor.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I only want to make two points about Senator Crowley's answer. It is the story we see here so often: suggest a good idea by way of amendment, and it gets taken over and owned. That is what has happened here this afternoon with two particular issues. I want to reclaim the record here.

PARA.TAB: The first issue is the government's record on industrial relations and women. It was the Democrats and the Greens, as I recall it, who insisted on an amendment for the department to collect statistics so that we could monitor on a yearly basis the affect on women of enterprise bargaining. I recall very clearly that we said, `Don't ask us to wait for 10 years and then tell us it's not working.' That was not the government's record; that was our record. I am not aware of much else that the government has done for women with respect to industrial relations. The second issue is that Senator Crowley talked about carers' leave—
Senator Reynolds interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Reynolds, work and family. Let us look at carers' leave. The government opposed that. Here was one opportunity to do something concrete for women as carers—and the government's official submission was opposing that.

PARA.TAB: Those are two facts which need to be restated in this debate, just before we gloss over and accept the record without question. I do not say that the government has an appalling record. But I do say, `Don't claim to have taken action as though you initiated it, when you really had to be pushed into it.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is International Women's Day. I think I rose to speak on the same taking note of an answer last year because again the opposition wanted to say, `We would do it better.' It really saddens me because I think we are missing the point when the opposition, the Democrats and everyone say, `We have done this. We could do better. You have pinched this from us.' We are missing the point. We, as sisters, should be saying, `We have done a lot of things, there are a lot of improvements, but we still have work to do.' Let us work together and not stand here saying, in the old boys' network style, `Mine's bigger than yours.' That just defeats the whole purpose of the day. Today is the day that we should be recognising the contribution that women have previously made.

PARA.TAB: Seeing that we are into point scoring and politics, let us have a go. Senator Cooney just reminded me of the hard work that Senator Ryan had to put into get the reporting provisions within the affirmative action legislation. All that she wanted to do was to have a report each year on how companies were fulfilling their affirmative action commitments. Who fought tooth and nail against this? Who acted as if this would be the end of Western civilisation as we know it? I will give you one guess: the opposition. I am not saying that my female colleagues in the opposition led that fight, but I am saying that their male counterparts certainly did.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were fifth columnists.

—They are very tough words; I am not sure that I would be quite so harsh. I think it is important that today we as women in this parliament and, I would think, feminists in this parliament are very conscious of this. Let us not get stuck into these traps of wanting to say that we have done more than you. We have done a lot. We have been in government for the last 12 years and we have done a lot on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Before we came into government we saw the removal of the Office of the Status of Women, as it now is, from the Prime Minister's office, where it was under Gough Whitlam, to a junior minister. The junior minister involved was a very committed minister and all credit goes to him for the work that he was able to do. But we saw this devaluing of importance of the Office of the Status of Women. It was moved to a junior ministry. Since we have been back in power that has gone back to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and that gives it clout; it gives it power.

It is very important that these sorts of things are reflected upon. Today should be the day for remembering and recognising the hard work of those who have gone before us in this place. Yesterday we had the condolence motion for Senator Zakharov and the recognition of her contribution. The recognition of Pat Giles—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dame Margaret Guilfoyle.

—Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, certainly. The recognition of Susan Ryan and Ruth Coleman: the recognition of those women in this place is something that we should be looking at but we should not be getting into this sort of argument.

PARA.TAB: However, I cannot resist finishing today with a quote from Bronwyn Bishop, who is not known for being a feminist. When there was the last leadership debate in the Liberal Party she said that she would not be a contender in the leadership stakes this time `because I don't think the parliamentary Liberal Party is yet ready for a woman leader'. The Labor Party has proved that it is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Calvert this day, relating to small business.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I would like to thank my whip for standing aside and letting me ask the question. I was very enlightened to hear the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction say that it was the first time I had asked a question about small business in two years. I find that hard to believe.

PARA.TAB: I was enlightened by the minister's answer. I was very pleased to find out that, after consulting small business, he found they are concerned about increases in interest rates. That was basically the answer: that after consulting with small business they are concerned about interest rates. I can enlighten him. They are concerned more about other things than interest rates. I think another thing they would be concerned about would be the wages break-out that is building up in the community.

As our leader pointed out recently, after being through `the recession that we had to have', small business—all businesses in fact—has virtually had only five minutes in the sunlight. This survey points out that one in five small businesses expect conditions to worsen over the next quarter. That is something that this government should be totally ashamed of because we know—everybody knows—that small businesses are the major employers in this country. They are the ones that employ the people. That is the reason.

There is another thing that is happening with small business. More now than at any other time in the seven years I have been in parliament small businesses are ringing my office and telling me their concerns about the economy and how their businesses are going. I had two people in my office last Friday. I have had numerous phone calls. My local paper has reported today that one of our department stores, A. J. Connor, an old family company which has been around for a long time, is in a little bit of trouble. There are other businesses, furniture businesses, which are having some trouble. When I look at the paper I can understand why.

For example, a person who has a general store that sells petrol, hires videos and has a small garden centre would be what you would class as a small business. Our local newspaper put together a list of the sorts of things that they have to put up with. Sure, a lot of these are state government impositions, but I think every state government imposes similar types of impositions on small business.

If you happen to be in that category, the state government requires you to have a verification of your weights and measures and weighing and measuring instruments. You have to have a licence to keep dangerous goods. You have to have planning approval for the construction of your shop and you have to have a licence to sell petroleum. You have to have a factory registration, a shop registration, a retail tobacconist registration and a business name registration. You have to have your hoardings and signs registered. You have to have a second-hand dealer's licence, a public vehicle licence and a rental business registration. You have to have a permit to purchase specified substances and a licence for purchase of restricted pesticides. On top of that, you need a certificate of competency and a country store medicines licence. The local government requires you to have a licence to operate food premises and food premises registration. That is just in the local area.

When we look at the Commonwealth, of course, we see that on top of that the Commonwealth requires you to pay fringe benefits tax. You have to be registered as a group employer. You have to have a licence for public exhibition of music video clips, and then you have to have another licence for copyright music. You have to also have a licence for public performance of protected sound recordings. You have to have a tax file number, and you have to pay the superannuation guarantee levy. On top of that, you pay income tax, company tax, fuel tax and payroll tax.

If the minister is fair dinkum about helping small business, why doesn't he get out there and start to cut a bit of this red tape and start to help small business instead of just saying, `Look, we have been consulting with small business, and they are worried about interest rates.' They are worried about a lot more than interest rates: it is the red tape and the taxes that this government is imposing on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the comments made by my colleague Senator Calvert. The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), in his response to Senator Calvert, sought to make the cheap point that nobody on the opposition had been asking questions about small business.

PARA.TAB: Let us set the record straight. Senator Calvert, prior to his entry into the parliament, was the mayor of the city of Clarence and had a very strong reputation there as being supportive of small business. Since his entry into the Senate, he has continued in that role of defending small business. In fact, before he came into the parliament he was a farmer, and that would have to be the very essence of small business in this country. As for me, having run a small legal firm employing half a dozen people or so, I have an understanding of small business as well.

What experience does the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction have in employing his own capital, in employing staff whom he has to pay every single week and in ensuring that the budget balances within the business? That is what the concern of small business is.
Senator Woodley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that Senator Woodley should comment about Tasmania. One of the points I was going to make—and I may as well get on to it now—relates to Tasmania. The national survey of business expectations undertaken by ACCI showed that for firms with fewer than 1,000 employees—that is, amongst the overwhelming majority of firms—conditions are becoming more difficult. I say to honourable senators—and Senator Calvert and Senator Newman would know—that there are virtually no employers in Tasmania that employ more than 1,000 employees.

PARA.TAB: As a result, in this survey all the businesses in Tasmania are categorised as small businesses. If we talk about companies like the zinc works at Risdon, North Broken Hill in Burnie and Gold Mines of Australia on the west coast in Queenstown, we find that they employ unless than 1,000 people. When you go through all those businesses you then find that two-thirds of them are saying, `Things are grim for us.'

For Tasmania that unfortunately means virtually every single business enterprise is suffering. Why are they suffering? It is because of the financial incompetence of this government forcing up interest rates. I notice that the minister has come back into the chamber. He might like to tell us what the nominal interest rate is that small business has to pay on its loans and overdraft facilities. Let us see how well acquainted the minister actually is with the problems of small business—the red tape associated with putting in your employee superannuation returns and PAYE tax and all the other problems that small business has to face every single week of the year.

As I have indicated, not only is small business the heart and soul of Tasmania but the whole body of Tasmania's economy. Within the total Australian economy there is no doubt that small business is the heart and soul. It might not play as major a role as it does in Tasmania, but it is by far the largest employer of people within this country. Small business is the area where there is greatest potential for growth in employment and job opportunities for the young.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woodley this day, relating to development at Hinchinbrook Island.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to tell the Senate that members of the community in North Queensland, including residents of Cardwell, are still concerned about the development at Oyster Point. PARA.TAB: I am also concerned.
