His name is Dr Robert Morris, and his qualifications include a PhD and a doctorate in science. He commented on many areas of significant degradation around Cairns and on the Great Barrier Reef. In particular I want to record Dr Morris's comments about Oyster Point. In speaking about the danger of dredging in these areas, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide even a modest boat access into Oyster Point from deep water would require a channel 4m deep by 20m wide for a length of at least 800m. This would produce at least 64,000 cubic metres of dredge spoil. With the present active sedimentation, maintenance dredging could produce a further 20-30,000 cubic metres of dredge spoil annually. The greatly increased turbidity induced in the coastal waters and inshore reef areas will certainly further degrade the local marine environment, but it is the disposal of the dredge spoil which can cause the greatest damage.

The developer plans to use some of this dredge spoil for site filling, but most of it will be placed into spoil dumps near the coast. Water from these dredge spoil dumps will then be discharged back into the Channel. From the results of the `natural experimentation laboratory', which has been established on the east side of Trinity Inlet, each of these dredge spoil dumps on the edge of Hinchinbrook Channel, and the landfill site, could quickly become a major source of highly toxic, metal-rich acid leachates which would devastate the local marine environment of the Channel, not to mention their potential impact on the reef.

The Senate can understand my concern in asking Senator Faulkner—I was pleased with his answer—about the incremental granting of permits to do small parts of the work which is contemplated in the channel at Oyster Point. It is of great concern to many people. If it means that the decision to dredge the channel will be arrived at by a series of small decisions, the concern we have is well-founded.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill, you have only 21 seconds to take note of an answer, unless Senator Schacht is kind enough to extend the time for this debate by just a few minutes.
—Yes, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day, relating to forest management.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make just a couple of very brief points, and I thank the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) for allowing the time for debate to be extended. Senator Gareth Evans said that the coupes had not been released in New South Wales because the `state government, unlike other states, simply had not provided information'. I have been in touch with the minister in New South Wales, and he has advised me that at no stage was there any request for further information or any suggestion that insufficient information was given, not at the ministerial level nor at the officer level. The minister in New South Wales had nine phone calls with Senator Collins, and Senator Collins obviously did not raise these issues. Why didn't he?

PARA.TAB: This is really all about jobs. In one of today's newspapers there is an article headed `Sawmill shuts in chip row'. One of the concerns is that the Commonwealth government is now trying to take over the sawlog industry. The Commonwealth government knows nothing about it, and it is trying to take it over by de facto means.

The other thing that Senator Evans did not answer and I think he still needs to look at is the fact that the Glenbog and Tantawanglo state forests have already been assessed by the Commonwealth in its own inquiry, and it has been agreed that they are to be made available for logging under the south-east forests agreement, which was signed by Michael Lee and Mr Souris. Surely, if the federal government has already signed off on them, they should have been released. Why have they not been released? The government has released only a couple in New South Wales, and it is obviously doing this as a political stunt.

I will repeat this question to the minister: why were the concerns that he mentioned today omitted from the letter that Roger Beale, the Associate Secretary of PM&C, wrote to the state's unions and industry. They requested more information from other states but not from New South Wales. Basically, I think it is a political stunt to try to help Mr Carr in New South Wales. The government here stands condemned for that because it is all about jobs; its about people; it is about kids; it is about people making their payments on machinery. I thank you for the extension of time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Today an urgency motion relating to greenhouse was lodged by Senator Coulter and a matter of public importance relating to International Women's Day was lodged by Senator Knowles. Senator Coulter has agreed to withdraw his urgency motion to enable Senator Knowles's matter to proceed. Although Senator Knowles's matter of public importance was not lodged strictly in accordance with the guidelines, I have accepted the letter which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: Recognising on International Women's Day the achievements and contributions of women within our community and the progress achieved by women in the quest for true equality.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

—I start by thanking Senator Coulter for his graciousness in deferring his matter of urgency until a later date. Today is International Women's Day—a day when all the world can celebrate the achievements, endeavours and contributions of women. In Australia, women have made a vast number of achievements, gradually wearing away at the establishments and the prejudices which have held them back over a great length of time.

PARA.TAB: Many of these women are everyday people whose names will not be immortalised in history. They are average women who have worked hard all their lives to help themselves and others to be the very best they can be—whether it be in employment, education and general learning, sport, academia, the arts, or any other field. There are also women whose names are now synonymous with the progress, achievement and endeavour of women. I would like to take a moment to reflect on some of their achievements.

From the days of the early suffragists, Vida Goldstein, Rose Scott and Catherine Helen Spence, who fought for the recognition of women against all odds, women have certainly come a long way indeed. In the last 10 years alone we have seen many achievements. For example, we have seen a federal government department headed by a woman for the first time. Sadly, as Senator Patterson said not so long ago, there is only one federal government department headed by a woman, and that is the Department of Tourism.

We have seen the first female Speaker of the House of Representatives. Janine Haines was the first female leader of a federal political party. Mary Gaudron was the first woman to be appointed to the High Court of Australia. Macquarie University became the first Australian university to appoint a female vice-chancellor—in 1987. Flight Lieutenant Williams and Flying Officer Hicks became the first female pilots to graduate from the Royal Australian Air Force. The first female station leaders of the Australian national Antarctic research expeditions were appointed. Deirdre O'Connor became the first female Federal Court judge and the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The list goes on.

In other areas which are probably not so well known we have women who are presidents, national presidents of political parties and federal directors of political parties. We have women as leaders of political parties, such as Joan Sheldon and the recently elected leader of the Liberal Party here in the Australian Capital Territory, Kate Carnell, whom we hope will be made the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory tomorrow.

We have female state presidents of the Liberal Party. For example, Vicki Chapman is a current one in South Australia. There are many female state ministers in the governments of Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, South Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania.
—And Tasmania. It is very significant that those women are playing a major part.

PARA.TAB: But that is just a sample of those achievements. An abundance of women writers come to mind, such as the late Dame Mary Durack, Elizabeth Jolley, Kath Walker and many more. There are athletes such as Cathy Freeman, Melinda Gainsford, Kathy Watt, Shelley Taylor Smith, Nicole Bradkje, Heather McKay and Michelle Martin. The list goes on. There are women in the media. A list of those who have achieved great heights would have to include people like Michelle Grattan, Pru Goward, Ellen Fanning and Jana Wendt.

The entertainment industry has been very well served by the likes of Judith Durham, Kate Ceberano, Wendy Matthews, Grace Knight, Jenny Morris, Debra Conway and Dame Joan Sutherland. When it comes to leading designers, we cannot walk away from people like Judy Done, Maggie Tabberer, Carla Zampatti and Liz Davenport.

Much recognition can be given to women in celebration of today's International Women's Day. I regret that the progress women are making towards true equality in the public and private sectors is not moving in the leaps and bounds I would have hoped. Progress seems to have become somewhat stagnant.

We need look no further afield than Australia when it comes to the issue of income imbalance and other aspects of the gender gap between males and females. In Australia, the incomes of our top female executives and public servants are far apart from those of the male executive. I view this as great cause for concern. We do not even need to take the top executives into account. In fact, average weekly total earnings for full-time adult women were around 79 per cent of the earnings of their male counterparts, according to data provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the period August 1994 to November 1994.

The interesting thing we need to look at is that, in comparing all earnings, including part-time and full-time earnings, women's income is 66 per cent of men's. In the December quarter of 1975—20 years ago—prior to the introduction of all federal equal opportunity legislation, females were earning 65 per cent of male incomes. That is only one per cent less than it is today. I believe it is therefore abundantly clear that little has changed in the past 15 to 20 years if we can improve by only one per cent.

International Women's Day 1995 is an appropriate occasion to remind the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of his 1993 promise to offer Australian women a new deal. This promise seems to be offered by the Labor Party at every election, yet the ABS figures are proving that nothing is really happening in terms of achievements in earning capacities in particular. We still hear phrases such as `stuck on the lower rungs of the corporate ladder', `the status woe' as opposed to the status quo, `glass ceilings' and others which imply that some indescribable force is actively preventing women's incomes from climbing to a level that would put them on an equal footing with their male counterparts.

Of equal importance is the fact that these limitations hamper economic growth and productivity and inflict a certain amount of physiological and psychological damage on women as a group. There has been a spate of newspaper articles on the issue in recent times, particularly following last year's debate on the value or otherwise of installing a quota system to entice more women to seek a career in politics. It is interesting that the Labor Party started with 50 per cent, went to 40 per cent and has now lowered it to 30 per cent. It is still having difficulty with that. That purely and simply reflects the fact that it is not easy to come about and that the quota system is unfair and unjust. Many women simply do not want it, because they do not want to indulge in what will end up being reverse discrimination against men. That is what will happen with a system such as the one that was proposed last year.

It has been reported that females are more likely to be called controllers or managers as opposed to the higher status title of director. The glass ceiling closes over once women reach an income of around $40,000. Graduate entry level men receive a higher starting salary than women with similar qualifications.

On 25 January this year the Financial Review put all of this information into a far better perspective by giving concrete examples of top male and female earnings with a report on executive women's incomes. In that report it was stated that the highest paid woman in Australia, the Haytesbury Holdings chair, Janet Holmes a Court, was earning $1 million per year and that she was closely followed by the national managing director of Nutri-Metics, Imelda Roche, on $900,000.

In the Public Service the top ten female incomes ranged from $237,000 to $800,000 for the High Court Justice to $170,000 for the Deputy Director of the New South Wales Education Department. By stark contrast, a survey of male executive salaries published by the Independent Monthly last October listed 25 male executives whose earnings were in excess of $700,000, while a list of the top 20 public servants, all of whom were male, earned between $500,000 and $137,000. This highlights so much of what is wrong and where action has not followed the rhetoric. In the corporate sector, two studies by the ABS conducted on businesses in 1984 and 1992 showed that the number of women as a percentage of total managers rose by only one per cent.

So it is a day on which we can certainly celebrate the achievements of many women who have achieved in spite of what has gone on around them. I still reject wholeheartedly the concept of quotas to artificially bring women into top management positions in the Public Service or the private sector, as women themselves do—because they want to get there on merit and merit alone. But it is tragic that, 15 to 20 years down the track, with much legislation brought in, women are still finding it difficult to achieve. They are the ones that we should be concentrating on to make sure that they do achieve.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, according to this piece of paper in front of me, as a public matter of public importance we are recognising on International Women's Day the achievements and contribution of women within the community and their progress towards true equality. One might be tempted to think that this is an MPI encouraging us to acknowledge the nice achievements, the great successes. I notice that Senator Knowles nods. I have read the intent of her words. She would not, for example, like to list under the achievements and contribution the negative achievements of women—for example, the women who have committed a crime or the fact that women in this parliament are taking their place in the traditional abuse, parry and thrust of debate in here. One could say, `Women have achieved a whole lot. They have come all the way to parliaments and they are able to play the game in a tough way like anybody else; that is an achievement, I suppose.'

PARA.TAB: Do I take it from Senator Knowles nodding by affirmation that we are here to describe the successes and achievements which we regard as pluses—the fact that women do not now live in the kind of abject circumstances that they did 101 years ago, when women in South Australia were campaigning strongly for the family and for a political voice, a place in parliament that would enable them to argue the case for improved conditions for women and for families?

We have come a huge distance in the last 100 years and certainly since International Women's Day started, early in the 20th century. We have also come a long way in the last 10 years. I read some of those achievements of women over the last 10 years into the record during question time today. We also have a long way to go; no-one denies that. The achievements are that we have changed the climate of our society about women. The successes of and opportunities for women are vastly more, vastly different and vastly better than they were 10, 20 or 30 years ago. I thank Senator Knowles for the litany of women she put on the record. As she says, there are many more one could contribute. I certainly believe that some of those we should acknowledge are the women's advisers, both political and community advisers, who have been appointed by government over the last 20 years or so.

I do not believe we can overlook the contribution of Elizabeth Reid, appointed by the Whitlam government—in particular, the tough task she had to withstand a barrage of abuse about her insufficiencies and the pointlessness of her position. I think with great courage she actually moved the climate for achievements of women well beyond `if women did it it was deviant' to `if women tried and achieved, that was a perfectly proper and appropriate way for women to behave'.

I also recognise the contribution of Beryl Beaurepaire, I believe appointed by Malcolm Fraser as the first national women's advisory committee adviser to the government. I believe her contribution is something that is well worthy of commendation and remark. I also say that it is a matter of despair to her and a lot of Liberal women over the years that their own Liberal parties were very slow in advancing the cause of women at anything like the pace those committed women, for example Beryl, really wanted to achieve.

If I said on the record, `Women earn somewhat less than men,' people would say that that is a measure of women's failure to achieve. If I said, `Men do less housework than women,' no-one would regard that as a measure of men's failure. It may well be, indeed, that it is. It may well be that if we are progressing towards true equality we will have a time when both of those statements urge the same response of unsatisfactory measurement of moving towards true equality.

I also believe that one of the most important things this government has been doing, apart from its specific achievements, is moving further the clear understanding that a climate where opportunities for women and achievements by women, either government supported or community supported or individual efforts, is something the community wants to encourage. It is not any more an oddity for women to achieve in a whole lot of areas where even as recently as five or 10 years ago we had extraordinary fights and ridiculous claims about what would happen if women became pilots, came into parliament, wanted to borrow money from a bank or any of those things. There are still reports of very stupid, ignorant responses to women breaking through in all of those areas. Mostly, I think, those responses are now disparaged by the community at large.

Recent polling of women in Australia produced some very clear evidence that today's women recognise that there are lots of things still to be achieved, but they are very clear that their lives are much better and they are much better off than were their mothers and grandmothers. They very clearly would say, and did say, that they do not want to go back there. They do not want to live the tough lives that their mothers and grandmothers did, but they do want to, in the contemporary time, fight for achievements and goals of their own. Since I have been elected to the Senate, I have made it my business to promote orders of Australia for women and to encourage women to nominate all those silent or unrecognised women achievers in our society. If we can continue to do that, maybe we will get wider recognition of the huge achievements of women, particularly those that are not necessarily in the parliament or in the public domain.

I will correct some of the figures that Senator Knowles gave about women's earnings. Those figures, I think, are not quite accurate. In relation to pay equity, when the Labor government came to office in 1983 female average weekly ordinary time earnings represented 79 per cent of male earnings. In August 1994 that had changed to 84.2 per cent of men's earnings. There has been a significant improvement. To suggest that 65 per cent has become 66 per cent is another inaccuracy. I urge Senator Knowles to check those figures. They are not comparing apples with apples.

There has been a considerable increase in the earnings of women. But quite clearly, for a variety of reasons, some of which Senator Knowles alluded to—women are more often in part-time work and women are still in lower paid areas—women's earnings are not 100 per cent equal with men's. It is important that we recognise that there has been quite a significant achievement of nearly five per cent over the decade or so that the Labor government has been in office—nothing to be complacent about but certainly something to be accurate about.

On International Women's Day I think it is important that we not only look at the achievements for women within Australia but also recognise the challenge for women around the world. The difficulties we face in Australia, I think, are sometimes importantly measured against the challenges for women in other countries. If, say, 500,000 women around the world die each year from childbirth and related causes, very few of those women die in Australia. Many of them die from poverty, malnutrition and neglect in Third World countries. Something like 14 million children die from easily preventable causes each year around the world. These are matters of great anguish and concern for women.

I would hope that on International Women's Day, when we do look at the achievements and recognise how far we have come and how the climate for women and equality between men and women, the most civilised and preferred option, has advanced very much, we must also realise that if we look beyond our borders there is still a huge challenge waiting for us, particularly on behalf of women.

I made the point during question time that we could very usefully have a goal, coming out of the International Year of the Family and certainly today, that all the women in the world be literate by the year 2001. That would be a splendid achievement for women. It is not an unmanageable goal and it would certainly be of great benefit to the families around the world. It would, according to the Cairo conference, be one of the best ways to manage the world's population—a decision made between men and women equally and not unequally, as is very much the case currently.

I believe that in setting an international goal like that we can address the challenges for women in Australia and at the same time embrace the challenges for all women on this International Women's Day. In particular, I recognise the importance of assisting our daughters and nieces to understand what has been achieved for them so that they can take it on from here. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to support this matter of public importance. I guess for women like us in the industrialised world in places like Australia this time represents a high watermark of our achievements.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important that we reflect on the debt we owe those women who have gone before us—women in Elizabethan England who fought to maintain their hard won independence in the face of proclamations forbidding them to meet together to babble and talk and ordering men to keep their wives in their houses; the campaigners of the 18th and 19th century who not only wanted political and educational equality for women but also spoke strongly against the domestic subjugation of women, referring to women as `abject domestic fixtures' and `domestic breeding machines'; the American Christian and Quaker women who fought against black slavery, restricting their opposition to unostentatious prayer when they realised they had another fight on their hands, in the words of one, `to fight to get our male brethren to take their feet off their necks because they were constantly being reprimanded for not doing the womanly thing'; the suffragettes; the first women trade unionists in the early part of this century; and the feminists of the 1950s and 1960s who sought to place the liberation of women in an economic context. We have made progress and to these known and unknown women we owe an enormous debt.

I am not going to name a list of women who have made wonderful contributions. There are so many of them and I think they are so inspiring to all of us. I thought I would talk about Australian women generally because I think their great achievement is in surviving—surviving massive social change which has seen their entry into the work force in huge numbers, has seen them have to draw on their reservoir of skills and talents to find the way to balance work and family, has seen them take on the double shift, and has seen them take the primary responsibility for maintaining social cohesion at the same time as they have taken on full-time paid work in many instances.

I think there are a couple of questions that often occur to me about the future of some aspects of society and community life which are raised by the notion of the progress we are making. I often wonder, when I see the voluntary capacity of the generation of women which is my mother's, the way in which they contribute to society visiting hospitals, doing the morning teas after funerals—those sorts of things—unasked, unacknowledged, unrewarded in many senses in terms of economic contribution, what is going to happen to that aspect of social cohesion when they are not with us and when most people my age are in paid work of some kind or another.

We have made a lot of progress, but I do not think we have challenged sufficiently that core issue, that notion of paid and unpaid work, particularly in the case of women's work in the home, and the notion of a voluntary contribution and the economic value that we should ascribe to that. Of course, that requires us to do something monumentally difficult like saying, `Excuse me, boys, you got the national accounting system wrong when you wrote those definitions all that time ago. We actually don't believe that the only things which are of economic benefit are those which are productive and for which money exchanges hands. We can recognise intuitively a whole range of other things which make a contribution and which ought to be acknowledged.' That for us, I think, is a huge challenge but it is one that we must continue to undertake. We should not just accept definitions without questioning them when we think of the context in which they were created.

The terms of the matter of public importance talk about the quest for true equality. I guess some of the signposts, if you want to look at the progress, are some comments from early suffragettes. There is one I particularly like, from a woman in the late 1800s. Men were saying that women really would not want to be too involved in politics, particularly in economics and the framing of a budget, because they might forget to put the chops on and they might bear rickety children. I cannot help but reflect with a wry smile on how 90 years later, with my having a treasury and finance portfolio, I don't even remember chops, chicken and pasta and all the rest of it. I love having an opportunity to think about budgets and other matters financial. Interestingly enough, it is in that sector that great opportunities are being opened for women. We are seeing a huge increase in the number of women who are making a career in financial planning.

That leads me to make some comments on women in small business. I was talking recently to a woman entrepreneur who had returned from a visit to South-East Asia, where, she reported, women surprisingly enjoy far more prominent roles in business than they do in Australia. She suggested that one contributing factor to this might be because the military has a very different role in Asian countries and men, seeking fame and fortune there, choose that route as much as business, leaving more room in business for women to prosper and grow. It is a curious thought that women prosper under military dictatorships: that is not a solution to the gender imbalance that I am putting forward. But we do need to ask why women here have not had the opportunity for the same success as men have.

If you look at small business, women now own 31 per cent of Australian small business and they are very successful in those businesses. Research by Professor Alan Williams of the University of Newcastle shows that businesses owned by women are more profitable and are profitable sooner after start-up than businesses owned by men. However, women's businesses tend to grow at a much slower rate than those of men, and there are a whole lot of reasons for that but predominantly it is access to finance—

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot to do with capital injection.

—Yes, and that is part of access to finance. But other studies show that women have superior business survival skills, that they are better managers of staff than men, that they are more flexible, that they are more able to adapt to changes in the business environment. It has been suggested, though, that women are less keen to take risks in business than men and it could be that women enter businesses for different reasons than men. Women appear to place more emphasis on security, independence and flexibility rather than raking in huge profits. If you look at the reasons why they go into business, women rank financial gain fourth, whereas men put it as the second most important reason for going into business.

PARA.TAB: Women are still disadvantaged though because, when they arrive at the very beginning of their small business careers, they arrive with less wealth because women's incomes on average are two-thirds those of men. They have had less capacity to generate wealth, less opportunity for career advancement than men in the same age bracket, interrupted career cycles, less opportunity to amass superannuation savings, et cetera. Nevertheless, I think it is worth pointing out just how well women are doing in small business.

On the issue of women in parliament, which has been touched on by previous speakers, I do not think it matters that we have different approaches. For the Labor Party, quotas are an approach that is totally legitimate. The opposition wants to say it should be based on merit. The Democrats say, `Okay, participatory processes have meant that we have ended up, we think, with approximately equal numbers of men and women representing Democrats in our parliaments, and we have delivered three female leaders.' I do not think it should be a matter of, `Our system works better than yours,' because we all have different starting points but we want to get to the same goal. We each have something to contribute in the solution to that.

But while we are making good advances in getting more women into parliament, we are not doing so well in the cabinet agenda, and that is where I want to see us doing so much better. I want women in equal numbers in cabinet having an influence on the agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us your preferences and we will get them.

—You have got only one woman in shadow cabinet; it is going to be a big jump. We need women having an influence on the agenda, because women in this country have to do more than settle for the periphery. We cannot say, `Thank you, Mr Prime Minister. We'll have a little bit of money for child care.' We have to challenge the assumptions and make really meaningful structural changes. That is what we need. One woman in cabinet, government or opposition—no matter how good she is—really cannot achieve that on her own. We need the critical mass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to congratulate Senator Knowles, a Liberal senator, for moving this motion today and giving us the opportunity—
—We congratulate you for being the only man in the debate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of interjections.
—Yes, but they are coming from your side, Senator Hill. I am trying to protect you.

—As I said, I thank Senator Knowles for giving me the opportunity to join in this debate as the only male who has either been game enough or been given the opportunity to congratulate Australian women on their achievements on this important day of celebration.

PARA.TAB: I say that because I think it is important that the achievements of women—the progress that has been made in terms of political rights and opportunities and also the economic progress—are recognised not only by women but by men as well. It is an enhancement to our nation as a whole, and I would like to see more men get on their feet and recognise these achievements.

There is no doubt that there have been enormous gains in economic opportunity, in political status and in respect for women as individuals, and I am pleased to have the opportunity to applaud those gains. However, I also recognise that we are still far from achieving a position of equality. Women are still disadvantaged in many areas compared with men. The government, which on occasions such as this likes to give itself credit for many of the recent achievements, should recognise the distance that still has to be covered to achieve something like true equality.

Listening to Senator Kernot quoting from the suffragettes caused me to think for a moment that perhaps I should quote from less enlightened men of the past just to give some indication of how far society has advanced in a relativity short period of time. I reflect just briefly upon the words of the Hon. J.A. Stirling some 100 years ago in the Legislative Council in South Australia—and, of course, last year we celebrated women obtaining the franchise in South Australia.

He engaged himself in the debate. He was one of those men who was somewhat uncomfortable about the prospect of women being given the vote. He said, `Giving women the vote would create family friction leading to the downfall of the family and family values and, ultimately, the economic prosperity of the colony.' He went on to say that he could not see that there was much point in giving women the vote because `a wife's view of certain issues could be expected to be similar to that of her husband's and, therefore, it would simply be a duplication of the vote.' Perhaps the worst thing he said was, `Nature itself acts as an impediment to women's participation in the parliament.' I would be too embarrassed to quote further. I mention that because, although we still may have a way to go, considerable progress has been made, and that should be recognised.

I could mention also those who have been the heroes of the women's movement, but I will not do that because I think there are so many who have never been recognised and who probably deserve just as much recognition. There is no doubt that our society, through our system of awards, still does not adequately recognise the role of mothers, the role of home keepers and the enormous role of women in voluntary community service. I will not spoil it for the many hundreds of thousands of those who deserve to be mentioned and will not be by recognising, as I said, those who have received so much credit in the past.

In the last few minutes that I have, I want to put back on the agenda some of the issues that are causing me continuing worry in this area. I do not think the Labor government has recognised that the recession it induced through incompetent economic policy cost Australian women an enormous amount. I do not think the Australian Labor Party recognises what Hugh Mackay talks about as the new underclass in Australia that developed out of the growing gap between the rich and poor as a result of Labor's policies and that that new underclass so much includes Australian women.

The Labor Party failed to recognise that not only was it the case that so many women lost their jobs—women being the easiest group to lose work in a recession because so many are still in part-time employment—but it was also the case that there was an enormous strain placed upon women when husbands lost employment and families had no breadwinner for a very long period of time, which placed incredible stress on children as well. That is a responsibility that Labor ought to recognise. At a time when we see Labor economic policies very much going down the same path that we saw in the late 1980s, the government should be reminded of the consequences of incompetent economic policy, and particularly the consequences to women.

Just remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are more than 627,000 children in one-parent families in this country, with 84,000 having a female head. Of these one-parent families, 36 per cent of the parents

SPEECH.PARA: have been unemployed for a year or more, with the average duration of unemployment being 61 weeks. The Labor Party should also recognise that although the number of women in employment has risen—as I said a moment ago—it is part-time employment where women have made gains. Some appreciate that opportunity, as that is the type of employment they want, but for many there is no other alternative. Women have been treated in an inferior way, having inferior opportunities to men in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Labor should also recognise that women's work is all too often still concentrated in areas of less skill and lower wages. In this country average wages for women remain lower when compared with those of men. On average, women's wages are still just over 80 per cent of men's wages. That is something that should not last forever. All parties should commit themselves to seeking to overcome this through sensible economic policy, in particular.

Labor should recognise that, under its record, the long-term duration of unemployment of women increased from 67 weeks in 1984 to 112 weeks 10 years later. That is not a proud record for Australian women. Also, Labor should recognise that policies in relation to retirement income are still inadequate. It is time that some of these serious matters were addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intending to praise Senator Hill for speaking in this debate, but I am afraid in the latter part of his presentation he spoilt it by delivering the standard rhetoric that we get in this place—from both sides, I might mention. I am pleased that Senator Knowles has brought forward this particular debate this afternoon because it is to focus beyond these walls. It is not an opportunity for political point scoring, which, of course, is something that we spend most of our time engaged in, as I suppose is the nature of our work.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles made it quite clear that we are debating the achievements of and contributions made by women within the community, and the progress achieved by women in the quest for true equality. So, in actual fact, very few of those women are able to speak within these walls or, indeed, within the walls of the other place. It is entirely appropriate, as previous speakers have been at pains to do, to focus on the positive and to leave the political point scoring to another day, as no doubt we will.
I guess it is not every day that I agree with Senator Knowles; I agree with most of what she said, but we do have a difference with quotas. We will have to debate that a little later.

Today, as International Women's Day is being celebrated across the country, it is important that we do remember all women throughout the country; that we do not just look at the high-fliers. While we obviously have great admiration for many of those high-fliers who are speaking in various forums today, it is very important that we recognise ordinary Australian women who are out there in the work force, in their homes, in the community, as carers and as volunteers. It is so important that we say to them, `International Women's Day is for you.' It is not just something that is for women who can afford to go to special breakfasts in aid of very good causes to which the bulk of the profits will go. It is not just for women in parliament to wear suffragette colours. It is not just for—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you had been in the school sports carnival.
—I thought you might not have recognised it.
—I thought you had come first in the race.

—No, sorry. Today is a day when we can congratulate all Australian women for what they do in struggling through in various situations of adversity, as Senator Kernot put it so effectively. I would just give a few facts that I think are important on an occasion such as this, but I point out to Senator Hill that they will not be political point scoring facts. As to women as carers, 67 per cent of all principal carers are women; 64 per cent of women carers care for a person in their main home or residence. The highest representation of women carers is in the 35- to 44-year-old age group—and that is 77 per cent. That is, 77 per cent in the 35- to 44-year-old age group in many instances are forgoing or certainly compromising other elements of their lives and ambitions by virtue of their caring role. It is of those women I would like to make special mention and to recognise and praise their contribution.

PARA.TAB: For all age groups up to the 70- to 74-year-old age group, women are more likely than men to have been the principle carer in the household. The labour force participation rate for female carers is 41 per cent compared with 59 per cent for all women. It is important today to identify just what would happen in Australia if even just for one day, perhaps for International Women's Day, all those carers who essentially are volunteers and all those volunteers around the country were to say, `We're not going to work today; we're going to force governments to recognise precisely the value, the economic worth, of our voluntary contribution.' Of course, we all know that those volunteers and carers would not stop work for an hour, let alone a day. They know the very dramatic impact that that would have on old people, sick people, young people and children. It is quite impossible to even imagine such an eventuality. But it is important for us to pause and think, `Gosh, what would happen if every carer and volunteer in Australia were to say, "We will not work today"?' It would serve to bring home the message to governments of just how much we rely on volunteers. So it is of those women who are achieving so much that I make special mention.

I would also make mention of changes in the level of qualifications of Australian women. Something that is not generally recognised, not generally known, is just how much women in the last 10 to 15 years have benefited from changes in education, with the corresponding percentage change in qualifications. As we all know, the modern world demands much more in the way of qualifications, so I would give these statistics because I think they are very important. In higher degrees, the percentage increase between 1986 and 1991 was 92 per cent—that is, women achieving a higher degree. Of women achieving a bachelor degree it is 93 per cent, and it is 90 per cent achieving another form of diploma qualification. That is particularly important to record as an achievement because, again, it is not easy to do the double shift—that is, to work at home and in the work force—but it is even less easy to do the triple shift, which many women are doing, by studying, doing work outside the home and also keeping the work in the home going. So I would pay tribute to those women.

I would also record the changes in the level of qualification for indigenous women within the same period, 1986 to 1991. The policies of government—and I said I was not going to be political—are reflected very much in these statistics that I am giving here. In regard to higher degree qualification of indigenous women, the percentage change has been 237 per cent. I know we are dealing with small numbers, and that can change the effect of percentage impressions. But I think this is an enormous change in the pattern of indigenous women gaining qualifications, and it should be recorded on International Women's Day 1995. In regard to a bachelor degree, the percentage change is 297.1 per cent; and in regard to other qualifications, 212 per cent.

Today the government's status of women committee took the opportunity to talk with about 70 young women from colleges and schools in Canberra about how the world has changed for women since 1975, because as we celebrate International Women's Day in 1995 we look back to how the world was in 1975. The exchanges that we had between those young women and members of the government caucus women's committee were very revealing in terms of young women recognising how much the world has changed but, indeed, how much more has to be done. In concluding, I would like to acknowledge the fact that Senator Knowles brought this matter of public importance to the chamber and I thank her for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rising to associate myself with the matter of public importance raised by Senator Knowles today:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising on International Women's Day the achievements and contributions of women within our community and the progress achieved by women in the quest for true equality.

Sometimes, unfortunately, some members on the other side forget that women's issues did not start with the Labor Party winning the federal election after a long period of Liberal government at the federal level. When one looks at the history of the Liberal Party and, in particular, at the formation of the Liberal Party, one sees that women played a crucial role in the formation of our great party.

PARA.TAB: When Sir Robert Menzies founded the party in the mid-1940s he had the support and financial backing of an organisation called the Australian Women's National League, a very powerful organisation with a large number of members who were in influential positions in organisations throughout Australia. It was originally formed in the early 1900s as an independent women's organisation with the aim of informing women about political issues. However, by the time the Liberal Party was established it had become the main political party for women interested in non-Labor politics, with over 40,000 financial members.

It is generally considered that in the mid-1940s the league had no equal in Australia and its members were renowned for being highly motivated and well trained in electoral matters. So they were women who were active in their community, active politically, who actually played an enormous part. Sir Robert Menzies said at the founding of the party:

SPEECH.PARA: Women are unquestionably destined to exercise more and more influence upon practical politics in Australia. There was a time when they were thought to stand aside, exercising only passive influence. That has gone.

From the formation of the Liberal Party the importance of women was clearly recognised. I will not go through issue by issue the administrative level and the organisational level of the party and the role that women have played there. Senator Troeth, one of my colleagues here in the Senate, has played a senior role in the Liberal Party of Victoria as Country Vice-President and she is just one example of the many women who have played very senior roles in our party throughout the years.

PARA.TAB: If we are celebrating women's achievements and we look at the achievement of women on the conservative side of politics, we see in the number of firsts a long history and a long list of achievements. The first woman elected to any Australian parliament was Edith Cowan in Western Australia. At a federal level women from the conservative parties have also made their mark. The first woman to become a federal member of parliament was Dame Enid Lyons, elected to the House of Representatives for the United National Party. She went on to become the first female federal cabinet minister, serving in the position of Vice-President of the Executive Council.

The first government whip in a Westminster-style parliament was Senator Annabelle Rankin, later Dame Annabelle Rankin. The first woman to serve as a member of a federal cabinet and have portfolio responsibility for a federal government department was my predecessor, Senator Margaret Guilfoyle. Her ministerial portfolios included education, social security and finance. The first female member of a state cabinet was Dame Florence Cardell-Oliver. In 1947 she was appointed the first minister for health, supply and shipping in a Liberal Western Australian government.

The first female state president of any major political party was Mrs Joy Mein. The appointment of Senator Margaret Reid and Senator Sue Knowles as opposition whip and deputy whip respectively in 1987 represented the first time either house of the federal parliament had two women in these positions. So we have a long history of women in our party playing significant important roles in its formation and in its parliamentary life.

Moving aside from that and looking at the role that women have played in the community, I think back to the stories my grandmother told me about her aunt. My grandmother was orphaned and her aunt reared her. My old aunt was single and wanted the licence of a hotel. In those days one had to be married to get a licence of a hotel, so she did that and had the marriage annulled three days after she got the licence. I was only four when she died. I wish she had lived a little longer so I could have got to know her, but I wonder whether her influence has not rubbed off on me through my grandmother.

We have taken many significant steps towards improving the lot of women since the days when my aunt had to take that drastic step. But all too often these advances that women have made have been achieved despite rather than because of government policy. The runs are on the board, but we should not kid ourselves that the innings are over. Women in this country still have a long way to go before we arrive at real and lasting equality.

I outlined earlier today in taking note of an answer given by Senator Crowley that the Australian Public Service has a long way to go in appointing women at senior levels. As I said, across the Public Service only 16 per cent of Senior Executive Service jobs are held by women.

Despite women's achievement in the private sector as well, we still have a long way to go there. While women make up 42 per cent of the Australian work force, they occupy less than three per cent of senior management jobs and directorships. This is really despite the existence of government programs that Senator Crowley referred to earlier today in her answer.

Women have demonstrated that they can thrive when the shackles of the male corporate culture pervading most realms of business and government are absent. We see this most clearly in small business. Senator Kernot expressed her reasons as to why women may have succeeded in small business. It may be that women have succeeded in small business because, as I said, they are not shackled by the sorts of structures and male corporate culture that pervade business and government. It should come as no surprise, especially since Senator Kernot outlined it, that a massive 70 per cent of small businesses are run by women and they have been successful in that area as well. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make five brief points in the five brief minutes I have. The first is to say that on International Women's Day I wish that, instead of giving recognition to women's achievements, we simply give recognition to women. What we want is not necessarily a cooption of women into the achievements that our male dominated society values but to see a transformation of our society so that all human beings are valued for the contributions they already make.

PARA.TAB: The second point relates to that, because putting women in power is not the same as empowering women. We should give power to women where they are in our society and community today and not necessarily put so much emphasis on incorporating them into our structures. I think it is a matter of justice that there should be 50 per cent representation in all spheres of society if we have a healthy society. However, we must recognise that the role of women in today's world is far more important than the place that they gain in society's patriarchal structures.

At the Earth Summit in Rio there was a paper submitted on women's development, and Australia's contribution was to say that we would appoint more women as leaders because we recognised that women around the world do 60 per cent of the work in environmental care with 30 per cent of the resources. A very respected friend of mine, Elaine Horne, who is a teacher, a mother and a worker for social action within the community, said to me, `Christabel, why is Australia saying that it will put more women in positions of power? Why don't you give me the power and the resources that I need to keep doing the work I am already doing where I am? Why do you want to take me up some kind of bureaucratic ladder to give me authority?' I think it is a very valid point.

The third issue I want to raise is the very tragic thing which happened yesterday in terms of the recognition of women and women's spirituality, and that was the fight that arose over the handling of the women's secrets of spirituality belonging to the Ngarrindjeri people. I want to tender, on International Women's Day, an apology to the Ngarrindjeri women for the male sacrilege that took place.

I do not want to lay blame anywhere because I believe this is an inevitable part of the structure if we have a male minister for Aboriginal affairs and the handling of materials is so male oriented that it gets into the male hands of a shadow environment minister and is distributed precisely against the wishes of those people. We have done the women a grave injustice. I want to register my deepest apology to the women and to make a plea for the respect and the recognition of women's spirituality all over the world, including this country and, in particular, for Aboriginal women's spiritualty, which they are only just venturing to share with us as part of the reconciliation process.

The fourth point I want to make is that feminism has been suggested as having three stages by the author Ivone Gebara. The first stage is to recognise the historical oppression of women. The second stage is to work for gender balance. The third stage, which is the most important, is to work for a transformation of our society so that all injustices in our structures are addressed and so that patriarchal and hierarchical structures are changed so that women and their contribution in our world today are recognised and embraced.

I want to close with a description of what a new feminine paradigm would mean. It is one which needs both men and women working together, because if men do not devolve some of the power that they have accumulated over the last 5,000 years, the world will not be a better or richer place. The feminine paradigm emphasises process and interaction and a transformational reform of our structures. It is based on these key ideas: direct democracy, respecting the interconnection of all life, creating a synthesis out of adversarial positions, transcending old definitions of left and right and searching for common ground and the good of the whole.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! The discussion on the matter of public importance is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debate on the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Bill (No. 2) 1994 was interrupted, the minister at the table indicated to me that the part of the explanatory memorandum that dealt with changing indictable offences to summary offences related to only those sections of the act where the penalties had actually been increased. I seek the guidance of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) on whether 500 penalty units equates to $10,000. Looking at item 6 of the schedule on page 4, which deals with amendments to subsection 38, I ask the minister whether the note relating to a body corporate which suggests that the penalty will be five times the maximum fine is an increase in penalty. If that is the case, does the advice given to me previously about indictable offences being converted to summary offences only still stand? That is, does the comment in the explanatory memorandum relate only when there have been increases in penalties?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the committee would be helped enormously if you would care to put those questions again. I am sorry to do that, but the officials who are here to assist in answering those questions were not in the chamber at the time. I am not sure that I could faithfully recreate your question. —That is an increase in penalties. I asked previously which indictable offences are being converted to summary offences. TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to section 38 the penalty remains the same.

—I will summarise what has happened so far. We have an act which has been in operation for 10 years and has apparently worked well. It has worked so well that for 10 years the government has not sought to amend it. Secondly, the government can produce no evidence that the present act has not been effective in relation to the damage to the reef and the ability of the authority to take action against those who have damaged the reef. Thirdly, the opposition agrees that the government is wrong in its claim that the amendments strengthen the act and that, in fact, the amendments weaken the act. Fourthly, the government agrees that the factors of intention and negligence would be taken into account by the courts even if the strict liability of the present act were to stay unchanged.

PARA.TAB: Finally, we must draw the conclusion that, taking all these factors together, the government is deliberately weakening the act without a need and with no demonstrable benefit in terms of the rights and protection of people and those who offend against those sections which the government seeks to amend. One is left rather confused as to why the government is doing this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will clarify what I said before. I previously indicated that the coalition was not going to support the first series of amendments because we really had not had sufficient notice of them and had not considered them. I then went on to say that, for my own part, having listened to the debate and contributed to a minor extent, I would not have thought we should support the amendments even if we were going to consider them on their merits. Since that time, Mr McLachlan, the coalition member responsible for this legislation, has had the chance to consider the amendments. Mr McLachlan agrees with my substantive comments—that is, for the reasons I have mentioned previously in the debate we will not be supporting these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the committee that I was called away earlier during part of this debate on the Environment, Sport and Territories Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and was not able to contribute. For the benefit of the committee, and particularly Senator Coulter, who has circulated these amendments, I will put on the record the government's position.

PARA.TAB: Amendments Nos 1 to 11 proposed by the Australian Democrats relate to the degree to which a person intended to commit an offence or the degree to which they were negligent in allowing an offence to occur. The bill proposes that a person must intentionally or negligently commit an offence. Senator Coulter's amendments to the bill propose that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act remain unchanged.

The effect of accepting the amendments proposed by Senator Coulter would be that a person who, for example, innocently strays into a restricted zone of the marine park with no intention to commit an offence could only defend their actions by claiming that they had made an honest and reasonable mistake. That is a defence not always accepted by a court. The prosecution would be required to prove only that the offence had occurred. If the act is amended as proposed in the bill, the prosecution would be required to prove that the person intentionally or negligently committed the offence. Senator Coulter's amendment to the bill would be contrary to the government's policy with regard to offences, with significant penalties under the criminal law.

Senator Coulter's amendment No. 12 falls into a slightly different category in that it seeks to remove the definition of intentional damage from proposed section 38J, which relates to waste discharge in the marine park. If that proposed amendment to the bill is made it will allow a person who recklessly discharges waste into the marine park to avoid prosecution, which is, I assume, the reverse of what Senator Coulter intended to achieve.

The bill proposes a new section 38L for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act which relates to the liability of owners, operators and masters—that would be of vessels, or aircraft or platforms—for waste discharge by other people. This allows the prosecution of owners, operators and masters in circumstances where they were not directly connected with the commission of the offence but knew or expected that the offence would occur.

Finally, Senator Coulter's amendment 13 proposes to change the circumstances where owners, operators and masters could be prosecuted for the offence committed by others, even though they may have no knowledge of the commission of the offence. It is for these reasons that the government will not be supporting the amendments that have been circulated in Senator Coulter's name. I thank honourable senators who have contributed to the debate.
Amendments negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief contribution to the debate on amendment 14 which has been proposed by Senator Coulter. I thank him for revising the wording of his original amendment in relation to the protection of the world heritage values of the marine park and the adoption of the precautionary principle in the making of management plans. As I have said in this chamber on many occasions, the government is committed to the protection of the world heritage values of world heritage areas. Senator Coulter's revised amendment makes explicit what I think was implicit in the bill—that management plans should protect world heritage values.

PARA.TAB: The precautionary principle is embodied in the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment. The Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, signed by the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments in 1992, includes the commitment that policy making should be informed by a number of principles. One of those principles is the precautionary principle. The amendment put forward by Senator Coulter is therefore broadly consistent with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

The definition used is from the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment. I do not know how that quite fits with some of the comments Senator Coulter has made in the past about that particular document, but the definition used is from the IGAE. It is also effected in the National Environment Protection Council Act 1994, and I will not repeat the same political point that I made just a moment ago. I indicate to you, Mr Chairman, that the government will accept the amendment in its revised form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some points in relation to this amendment. Although the Greens support the amendment by the Democrats, we have some concerns. One is that the meaning proposed in IGAE section 3.5.1 does not adequately reflect the urgency of the need to apply this principle. I had to smile when the minister referred to that, because he would be well aware that the Greens have the same kinds of concerns about the IGAE as the Democrats have previously expressed.
—I noted your smile, Senator.

—Yes, I am sure you did. The reason we are raising this is that the definition in 3.5.1 allows for careful evaluation to avoid serious or irreversible damage but includes the loophole of `where practicable'. The other concern we have about it is that, where there is not the political will within the government and the bureaucracy to act on it, it may fail to take environmental protection seriously.

PARA.TAB: So, in supporting the amendment, I also urge that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority takes the principle to heart and puts in place a long-term strategic and integrated approach that will provide the area with the protection it deserves. I do not know whether the minister wants to comment on that or whether Senator Coulter has taken that into consideration, but it seems to me that that loophole—where there is not the political will to actually abide by the precautionary principle and to establish the very needed protection for our marine environments—is very dangerous.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the government is supporting the amendment, so the amendment will go through. Again, I just wanted to reiterate that, whilst I and the coalition are inclined to support the proposal, because it seems to make sense, for reasons I mentioned earlier, in not having had the opportunity of considering it in-depth and seeing whether it has repercussions in any other way, we will not be supporting it. We simply have not had the opportunity of going through it in any detail, but it will obviously go through in any case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly respond to the point Senator Chamarette made. I say to Senator Chamarette that I am very confident, as I always have been, that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority will take seriously its responsibilities and its responsibilities under the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 19, omit proposed subsection 46C(1), substitute the following subsection:
"(1) An ordinary search or a frisk search of a person under this Part shall be conducted by:
