DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994AUDIT (TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 February on motion by Senator Sherry and from 7 February on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate in the Senate is a continuation of that which took place two days ago and it relates to a package of bills which replaces the Audit Act of 1901. The Audit Act was one of the first acts passed by the federal parliament. It demonstrates the importance that the early members of this parliament placed on the question of accountability and audit.

PARA.TAB: In my previous remarks, I took the opportunity of outlining the fact that these bills recognise many of the reforms that have taken place, particularly in enhancing the role of accountability. I was surprised that, in a sense, they have moved backwards rather than forwards in two areas. I pointed out, for example, that in 1989 the mandate of the Auditor-General's office was far wider than that which is provided in this bill. I also drew the Senate's attention to the constant battles that this Senate chamber, in particular, has had with sections of the bureaucracy over the mandate of the Auditor-General's office in relation to his power to audit Commonwealth instrumentalities.

I drew honourable senators' attention to the fact that we did have notable victories. I can name three statutory type corporations: the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the National Rail Corporation. The Senate believed that essentially the Australian National Audit Office should have the prime responsibility for auditing these sorts of organisations.

I then noted that the Auditor-General at the time, Mr Taylor, for whom I have a great deal of respect, pointed out that the proposals with the limited mandate do miss the opportunity to set the standard of public accountability and model arrangements for the operation of a modern Australian National Audit Office which would serve not only the parliament and the government but also the community well into the 21st century. Without such a mandate, the parliament and the community would be the losers.

I believe that the bill in its present form will be subject to extensive amendment and change as a result of the processes of this chamber and probably a more fuller review than what has taken place in the past. I issue a warning that in its present form it demonstrates parliament's complacency, which can lead to a dulling of our capacity to perceive certain problems in public service areas. In this case, according to the bills as they stand at the moment, the Australian National Audit Office had resourcing difficulties imposed upon it because of its lack of a meaningful mandate.

While the bill establishes the Auditor-General to be the sole auditor of all Commonwealth-owned bodies, which in effect reverses a trend to permit private sector auditors to perform certain audits, there are two exceptions. I wish to deal with those two exceptions: government business enterprises and statutory marketing authorities.

I reject the assurances that were given by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) some time ago, when he believed there was little to be gained by subjecting GBEs to performance audits by the Australian National Audit Office. The Hon. Kim Beazley indicated that he believed the discipline to be efficient is imposed through the focus on targets and related performance measures.

A further reason submitted by the government is that the government believed it had taken other steps to further improve the accountability of the GBEs, or government business enterprises. I take this opportunity to respond to those statements. Firstly, the government has failed to outline—certainly in the press statement—those measures which would further improve the accountability of GBEs without the mandate of the Auditor-General extending his performance audits into those areas. It is incumbent on the minister at the moment to list them because, after all, they were statements in a press release and this is the appropriate opportunity for the minister to respond and categorically list the measures that have been taken.

Apart from that, unless there is competition or independent scrutiny—we have to acknowledge that the independent scrutiny of the Australian National Audit Office is more comprehensive when we look at other issues, such as the social responsibilities of GBEs—there is no necessary assurance about the tightness of the performance measurement indicators of a GBE. They can be set fairly easily. Further, while technically the audit committee of the parliament may request a performance audit, there is no assurance that such a request would be effective. Given what I would call the dulling of the parliament's capacity to look at some of these issues, we have to be somewhat concerned about this issue and, in short, the restriction of that mandate.

I call upon the Senate to restore the mandate of this package of bills. The Auditor-General should be reinstated for performance audits as the external auditor of the statutory marketing authorities and as the external auditor of all government business enterprises and all companies that the government has a controlling interest in.

Last year, I introduced into this chamber the private members bill entitled Audit (Auditor-General an Officer of the Parliament) Amendment Bill 1993. The bill passed through the Senate. Its purpose was to ensure that the appointment of the Auditor-General would rest with the parliament, not the executive, so that the Auditor-General be seen to be not only an officer of the parliament but also independent of the government. I remind the Senate that the Auditor-General is an independent auditor of government operations. The office has historically stood somewhere between the parliament and the executive.

The audit office fulfils a most important function in scrutinising how government bodies conduct themselves. But this operation has not been free of problems. There is an inherent conflict between the desire of the executive government and its bureaucracies to operate free of restraints and, to some extent, accountability and the desire of those who provide the wealth for these operations—the citizens of Australia, who are represented by this parliament—to remain fully informed of what the government is doing.

While the current bill, together with the coalition amendments, if adopted, will go some way towards meeting the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its original report No. 296, one essential missing element is the Auditor-General's being an officer of the parliament. I fail to see that my private members bill, having passed this place with the support of the parliament, fails to get up in these tranches of amendments.

I also draw the attention of honourable senators to a media release dated 22 June 1994 by my colleague the federal member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who was previously a respected chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. At the time of making this statement, he was secretary to the shadow cabinet. The honourable member for Bradfield said that the new legislative package would fail to ensure the necessary independence of the Auditor-General and would not provide the Auditor-General's office with the full protection of parliament. I concur with my colleague's remarks. Apart from the mandate, the second problem I have with the package is the refusal to recognise the concept of being an officer of the parliament. It goes fairly close to it in terms of audit committees, but the opportunity for complete responsibility has been lost.

While the government reforms strengthen the independence and role of the Auditor-General in that he will be much more closely responsible to the parliament through his remuneration being set by an audit committee, et cetera, it will tend to diminish the role of the Department of Finance. I must take this opportunity to congratulate the Department of Finance. Together with the Auditor-General's office, it is a clinical department that is responsible for, and has achieved a great deal in, improved accountability. Officers of the Department of Finance have largely been instrumental in bringing this bill to account. In a number of areas, we have to recognise that they are the servants of the government of the day. We cannot challenge them in terms of what is or is not in the bill.

The way that some of the issues have been dealt with is of symbolic significance. Unfortunately, they will not have the bearing that they should have, unless they are suitably amended in terms of the Auditor-General's independence. I also remind the Senate of the editorial of the Canberra Times of 22 June 1994, which demonstrates very clearly that appearances are also very important.

I remind the Senate that, when I was a member of it, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts identified five reasons underlying the National Audit Office problems at the time. One of them is parliament's complacency. Another is that the office fell between the two stools of the legislature and the executive with neither apparently willing to take responsibility for the condition of the office as much as it should have.

There was also a lack of mechanism, allowing parliament to assume responsibility for the office. I acknowledge that this has improved as a result of some of these measures, which hopefully will be passed today. There was previous overemphasis on the economy of operation of the audit office rather than on re-appraising the contribution it has made to effective and good government. Again, we should pay a tribute to the very positive leadership of John Taylor, who came to head the office without a lot of experience in the audit area. He showed fearsome independence and did a lot to bring the audit office into the modern day era.

My time is drawing to a close. The Auditor-General must be not only freely independent in controlling these sorts of activities but also seen to be independent. For that reason, I drew the Senate's attention to the editorial in the Canberra Times. I believe that constituting the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament would contribute greatly towards this objective. I remind the Senate that many senators have short-term memories.

Last week, in order to try to restore that mandate, because I was fearful that there were not too many amendments coming up, I took the unusual step of presenting to a Senate committee a submission from a senator, myself, when it was inquiring into this package of bills. I did so because I was a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for over 16 years and served at the forefront of a great deal of public sector reform—reforms that were initiated basically through those parliaments. During those years I was naturally very closely involved with the work of the Auditor-General and in the issue of the reform of the Audit Act of 1901. So it was with a degree of reluctance that I made a submission. I was pleased that I did because it has certainly borne fruit in drawing attention to the problem of mandate. We now have many amendments which seek to pick up these problems.

I pointed out that there were weaknesses inherent in the bill that were not fully addressed previously and that these matters had to be addressed. So I urge the Senate to look carefully at the amendments that have been put forward—and not only by the Liberal Party. I understand there is an amendment moved by the Democrats in relation to whistleblowers which, I know, addresses the situation in the whistleblowers committee. Some aspects of that legislation were contrary to the report of that important committee, headed by my colleague Senator Jocelyn Newman. But my time has expired. I urge my colleagues to pass the bills appropriately amended. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one major aspect of this legislation, the Auditor-General Bill, which I would like to address, and that is the audit mandate. That is a matter to which Senator Watson has just briefly referred and, indeed, a matter which he brought to the attention of the Senate finance and public administration committee in a submission. I would certainly like to support the comments of Senator Watson and stress the seriousness and the unacceptability of attempting to restrict the Auditor-General's mandate, as this bill does in clauses 14 and 15.

PARA.TAB: There is a glaring inconsistency in the Auditor-General Bill 1994 in relation to the stated intention as set out in the explanatory memorandum to clauses 14 and 15, which deal with Commonwealth authorities and subsidiaries and set out in relation to that the scope of the Auditor-General's power to undertake performance audits. Specifically, clause 14, subsection (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General may conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth authority that is a GBE—
a government business enterprise—
or any of its subsidiaries, if:
(a) both Houses of the Parliament, by resolution, request the audit; or
(b) the responsible Minister requests the audit.

This clause reflects the government's intention to restrict the performance audit mandate in relation to government business enterprises following a government indication that it considered there was little to be gained by subjecting GBEs, whether they were companies or statutory authorities, and their subsidiaries to performance audits. The Auditor-General's report No.43 of 1993-94, entitled Parliament's right to know, at section 2.9 states that the government's response to report 296 concerning the performance audit mandate of the Auditor-General is inconsistent. Report 296, entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the people and parliament, was the work of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which inquired into the Australian National Audit Office. That report was tabled in 1989. The Auditor-General's report No. 43 goes on to say:

The Government accepted the Committee's Recommendation that the Auditor-General continue to have responsibility for performance audits, but, in fact, reduces the performance audit mandate by suggesting that in the ordinary course of events there is little to be gained by subjecting government business enterprises, whether they are companies or statutory authorities, to performance audits.

Clause 2.10 of audit report No. 43 goes on to list seven major points which this government decision to exclude government business enterprises from performance audits ignores. The report states further that, no matter how commercial GBEs may be, they owe their existence to parliament. However, proposed provisions of the Auditor-General Bill 1994 have diminished access to information about their operations and activities, particularly to their public interest responsibilities. The Auditor-General stated quite clearly that he believed that GBEs would not be subject to the full range of necessary accountability requirements in the future as a result of this legislation. The exclusion of GBEs from performance audits unless there is a ministerial request or following a resolution of both houses of parliament, as provided in clause 14(2) of the bill, is described as `an unwarranted step backwards'.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, the Auditor-General's report No. 43 states that, in the light of recent events in some states, the decision to exclude GBEs from performance audits could expose ministers to potential allegations of attempts to avoid the operations of GBEs being subject and exposed to external review. At section 217 the report also states that this legislation is `against the trend outlined in various state government initiated reviews'. It cites the Queensland Electoral and Administrative Review Commission and the Western Australian Royal Commission into the Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in 1992, the well-known royal commission into the nefarious WA Inc. of the then Labor government. The royal commission recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: All public sector bodies, programs and activities involving any use of public resources be the subject of audit by the Auditor-General.
The Auditor-General, in the report Parliament's right to know, stated:
I ask the Parliament to consider the implications of this current package of legislation for its future ability to scrutinise the conduct and performance of individual GBEs.

He went on to recommend that the parliament amend the Auditor-General Bill to provide the Auditor-General with unfettered authority to undertake performance audits of all Commonwealth owned and controlled agencies, authorities, companies and their subsidiaries of whatever legal form.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's position has been the subject of a great deal of discussion over a long period of time. The reason is obvious: the Auditor-General' role is crucial to the process of accountability of governments to the taxpayer through direct reports to the parliament. This independent reporting to parliament is necessary for accountability and transparency and is fundamental to democratic government.So, while this bill is allegedly designed to strengthen the role of the Auditor-General, clauses 14(2) and 15(2) will, in fact, weaken it, and that is a very sad state of affairs.

The recent refusal of the National Media Liaison Service, the infamous government propaganda arm, the scurrilous aNiMaLS, to provide access to or enter into discussion with the Australian National Audit Office is the most recent and obvious obstruction by the executive arm of government. If anyone ought to be subject to investigation by the Auditor-General, it ought to be this disgraceful propaganda arm of the government. Of course, that body is fully funded by the taxpayer, to the tune of $1.5 million in 1994-95.

There are also implications for the states which may have been overlooked in the process of developing this federal legislation. Since report 296 was tabled in 1989, several states have moved to expand the powers of the state auditors-general and have relied very heavily on Commonwealth legislation and resources for leadership in effecting reforms at the state level. The reason is quite simple: the Commonwealth has resources available to it across a wide range of portfolio areas which the states simply do not have. The auditors-general are well known to each other and monitoring systems overlap the states and the Commonwealth by means of a series of performance indicators.

Given the lack of comparable resources available to the states, it is highly likely that moves to restrict the mandate of the federal Auditor-General will be adopted very rapidly by the states. Again, that is a backward step, particularly because state government business enterprises represent a much larger proportion of the state economies than do Commonwealth government business enterprises in relation to the economy overall.

The impact at a state level is much more direct on taxpayers than at the federal level. The state GBEs—for example, electricity and water boards—use public money and charge a wide range of fees directly to the consumer or taxpayer. The degree of insulation for the taxpayer from the federal GBEs arises from their very nature—shipping lines, telecommunications facilities, airlines and so on—but citizens are not so insulated from the activities of GBEs at the state level.

The pooling of resources does become an issue if the Department of Finance has its way and succeeds in its attempt to pull the Auditor-General's mandate away from areas which the department does not want examined. The concern is that the states will adopt similar restrictions in the same way that they embraced the expanded roles, identified in report No. 296, with much more significant consequences for the state economies. I understand that there will be further addressing of these issues of performance audit mandates in the committee stage of the bill, but I certainly want to add my comments in support of the proposed amendments to clauses 14 and 15, which will be moved during that committee stage.

I refer to evidence given by Professor Finn to the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee investigation of this particular piece of legislation. He raised concerns about clause 34 of the legislation. As it is structured, clause 34 is one about which he says, `I would counsel no parliament in this country ever to accede to.'
Senator Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome my colleague's support for those words from Professor Finn. I also agree with his comments in that regard. Paragraph 34(3)(f) of the Auditor-General Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: any other reason that could form the basis for a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed.

Clause 34 deals with those circumstances under which the Auditor-General must not include particular information in a public report. Professor Finn says that this particular part of clause 34 takes out any ground of public interest privilege in a court. He believes that this is another backward step as regards this legislation because it gives the Attorney-General absolute discretion to give an exclusive certificate. Once that is given under subclause 34(3), the reporting procedure that is countenanced in consequence results in the information not going to any arm of government other than to the executive arm.

PARA.TAB: The conclusion Professor Finn reached in the evidence he gave to the legislation committee was that clause 34 is far too far reaching in what it can exclude. He believes that there is no need for the clause to be so embracing to protect the legitimate interests of government. I simply add my concern to that which was raised by Professor Finn in the hearings of the legislation committee.

Again, I hope that in the committee stage of this legislation there will be some account taken of that evidence by Professor Finn and an appropriate reaction developed to it. If we are going to protect the role of the Auditor-General and if, as has always been intended, the Auditor-General is to be responsible directly to the parliament for the public accountability of government instrumentalities, then this is a clause that needs very careful consideration. They are the two areas I wished to address in relation to this legislation—clauses 14 and 15, to which I referred earlier, and this clause 34. I trust that the Senate will take my remarks into account in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on this package of bills relating to audit requirements, including the Audit (Transition and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1994. First of all, I will express my concerns in relation to a particular government business enterprise that people have heard me talk about before and, in speaking of that, I will express my concerns about some of the legislation that is before us today.

PARA.TAB: Accountability to parliament is at the heart of the Westminster democratic system. Parliament appropriates funds to the executive government and the ministers are accountable to parliament for the conduct of their portfolios. In theory, then, a government business enterprise like Australian Defence Industries, of which the minister is the `owner', is accountable to the parliament via the minister. The case is not the same, of course, for private sector firms such as the Submarine Corporation. There, the government negotiates and signs a contract. The firm is then bound by the terms of the contract, and the government is accountable to parliament for the contract it signs and for ensuring that its terms are faithfully executed. The firm itself is governed by relevant law.

In practice, government business enterprises have been allowed a great deal of freedom. The argument goes that if they are to operate as business enterprises they must be allowed to operate as closely as possible to private sector firms, without restrictions and the bureaucracy of the public sector. They can appeal to the commercial-in-confidence argument. They are bound by relevant law. That is, of course, unless you are dealing with bodies such as Australian Defence Industries, which claims that it is exempt from certain state and federal laws because it is defence related. This means that the government's investment, or taxpayers' money, is effectively removed from parliamentary scrutiny. The ADI experience makes this crystal clear.

As noted, private sector contractors are even further removed from public scrutiny, nor would existing laws allow the type of scrutiny applying in the public sector. After all, the firm is owned by its shareholders and not the taxpayer. But a firm like the Australian Securities Commission can sign a big contract with the government. ASC derives a massive proportion of its income from the government. The argument that the minister is accountable for the contract does not hold much water when the contract itself is commercial-in-confidence. The audit office report makes it clear that it was denied access to ASC records.

I point out here that a public company, which is totally subject to normal commercial situations, does at least have an annual shareholders meeting. Shareholders have a vote and if the board is not doing the right thing the shareholders can vote to overrule or throw out their board members. We do not have that luxury with government business enterprises as they exist.

The problem is that allowing government business enterprises to operate as much as possible like other firms has removed large sums of taxpayers' money from effective parliamentary scrutiny. ADI is 100 per cent government owned, but we are told that estimates questions cannot be asked. Other means of scrutiny are blocked by commercial-in-confidence arguments. If anyone doubts that, they can look at the Hansard and see examples of where I have been refused access to information in that regard.

Private sector firms like the ASC receive large sums of taxpayers' money—in this case, billions of dollars. There is even less direct accountability because of its private ownership and even the contracts it signs with government are secret. This makes ministerial accountability excessively remote.

It is clear that the executive government is doing its best to evade accountability to parliament, yet there are some major disasters on the public record to show that this policy, even neglecting the theoretically and arguably idealistic framework given above, is fraught with danger. Three obvious cases are the State Bank disaster in Victoria, the State Bank disaster in South Australia, and the WA Inc. disaster in Western Australia. The first two cases of disasters were the direct result of the hands-off approach by government. The banks, government owned, were given boards largely comprised of private sector business types and were told to behave like business. They were told that government would not meddle. Governments did not meddle, the boards did what they did and in the end the taxpayers of both states had to pick up the tab. Governments were held responsible by the voters.

The WA case was even worse. The government itself acted like a private sector concern, propping up impending disasters like Rothwells and indulging in all sorts of questionable conduct. These cases are the end result of a philosophy which disconnects parliament from government involvement in commercial activity.

The four bills being debated today replace the Audit Act and together form part of an important and complex set of arrangements to modernise and standardise financial accounting, reporting and ethical requirements applying to Commonwealth bodies. The stated aims of the legislation are laudable and appear to justify the care and attention that have been expended on them over what I understand is now a period approaching six years. It is unfortunate, however, that there are not many people in this place who know the details or who can accurately give you a briefing in relation to the details of these bills.

A central feature of the bills is that they enhance the capacity of the parliament to scrutinise the affairs of Commonwealth entities by bringing together in one or two key documents the minimum accountability requirements applying to all Commonwealth bodies. Apart from the impact on the Australian Public Service, the principal bill will replace the disparate accountability mechanisms spread throughout the Audit Act and numerous enabling acts establishing Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies. The lines of accountability are, it is claimed, to be more clearly drawn and easier to keep up to date.

It is somewhat disappointing then that the present proposals suffer from at least one of the defects they are supposed to remedy. That defect is that the parliament has not yet had the opportunity to look at all the relevant pieces of legislation and the associated instruments, finance minister's orders and finance regulations, as a complete package. Moreover, the legislative package is, in itself, still incomplete.

A fifth bill is still in preparation to create the necessary linkages to the Commonwealth Authorities Act 1994 and a number of Commonwealth entities whose enabling legislation is not presently subject to part 11 of the Audit Act. My understanding is that it will apply to at least 40-plus bodies whose status at this time is yet to be determined. Ideally, all five bills in draft versions of the relevant delegated legislation should have been available to the parliament to consider as a total package. The reason for this is largely self-evident.

However, given that the present proposals form only part of the process of accountability, it is also worth noting that the failure of the government to present a comprehensive blueprint also leaves unanswered a number of broader questions about the accountability of specific entities under the new arrangements. My concerns here, as I mentioned before, partly stem from a particular interest in the activities of Australian Defence Industries Ltd—a government business enterprise within the portfolio of the Minister for Defence.

Given past difficulties in attempting to extract timely and detailed information on ADI from the minister, I am interested in how the new bills will apply to ADI. Yet, on examining the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill and the explanatory memorandum, it is not clear to me that Australian Defence Industries will even be covered by the financial accounting and ethical requirements to be established under the three substantive bills in this package. Perhaps we are to assume that ADI is one of the as yet unnamed 40 or so bodies which are to be the subject of the yet to be presented fifth bill in this package.

Australian Defence Industries is, however, only one example. On the government's own admission, there are at least 40 other bodies of uncertain status under the proposals as presented. These are certainly matters which could and should have been addressed by the government in any of the relevant explanatory memoranda or the minister's second reading speech. In relation to government business enterprises generally, it is also of concern that the government does not appear to support the extension of all the basic elements of its own preferred system of accountability, as outlined in the bills, to all government business enterprises. As things stand, GBEs not funded through the annual appropriation bills are generally able to escape the estimates committee procedures.

As the provisions of the Auditor-General Bill stand, GBEs can be subject to performance audits only in exceptional circumstance; that is, at their own request or with the agreement of executive government. This is not good enough. Whilst GBEs continue to use public money and owe their existence to the parliament, they must remain fully accountable to the people's representatives. The package as presented, at least in respect of some Commonwealth entities, is an incomplete response to the parliament's requirements.

I would be interested to know why these matters could not have been handled differently and which government bodies are to be the subject of the further transitional bill referred to by Senator Faulkner in his second reading speech on the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1994. If the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) is able to mention that in his speech now, I would be grateful. If not, I will be asking those questions again in the committee stage of this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it four bills—the Financial Management and Accountability Bill, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, the Auditor-General Bill, the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill—and is debating those four bills together. There has been a number of speakers in this debate. On my count there have been four speakers from the opposition and one from the Democrats and we have just heard from Senator Margetts for the Greens (WA). So we have had a fair spread of viewpoints across the spectrum represented here in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I will start by thanking and congratulating the speakers for the constructive way in which they have approached these bills. Indeed, a constructive approach has typified the story of this legislation throughout its quite long history. This legislation has not arisen recently; it arose from consideration entered into some time ago.

This legislation has involved consideration by the Joint Committee on Public Accounts in a report that it has prepared, views that the government holds about the role of the auditor and the Audit Act, and a series of considerations including considerations by a Senate committee hearing last Friday in which witnesses from the New South Wales Audit Office, our own audit office, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office, and so on appeared and put their views. A range of written submissions was put, too.

What I think binds all of the parties in a common purpose here is that these bills are about a quite important function in any government—the role of the auditor. There ought to be a huge degree of cohesion between all of us as to how we perceive that role and how that function is carried out because the auditor audits the books for the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth's instrumentalities and the auditor ought to be like Caesar's wife—beyond reproach.

All of us have a common endeavour to find a broadly consistent approach to that and I think, in truth, we have succeeded almost entirely, but not quite, in doing that. So for people outside of this place who may see debate at a superficial level in here being fractious and divisive, this is a true occasion in which the chamber, from all perspectives, has endeavoured to find a common view and therefore address the overall issues of independence, prestige and importance that the auditor brings to public life in Australia as a modern democracy. A lot of people have put a lot more time into this than I have, and I congratulate all of them on behalf of the government.

There are a couple of points that I need to refer to in addressing the general debate. In the second reading debate on Monday, Senator Gibson, I understand, quite rightly pointed out the constitutional dimensions of the bills as they represent the operating framework for Commonwealth financial administration. As I said in my address to Senator Coates's committee on Friday, these bills are the product of the accumulated experience of 94 years of Commonwealth financial activities and it should be recognised that, while the bills are being sponsored by this government, they have not been drafted merely for this government; rather their benefits will continue to accrue to future governments, future parliaments, and future auditors-general in clarifying and strengthening their respective roles and functions in the field of Commonwealth financial affairs.

There are, as the speakers in this debate have pointed out, a handful of provisions in the bills where the legitimate interests of the players do not mesh. Nevertheless, the government has gone a considerable way in seeking to achieve a genuinely workable balance of those interests. In the wake of the valuable work done by the Joint Committee on Public Accounts in its comprehensive analysis of the proposals last year, the government accepted 28 of the committee's 35 recommendations concerning the bills and has already incorporated the necessary amendments. Compared to the present framework, these bills will deliver for parliament, the audit office, the executive and, ultimately, the taxpayer major improvements in public sector financial accountability and control.

It would be in no-one's interest if those benefits were delayed any longer than necessary. However, if these bills do not pass in the current sittings, they could not sensibly be made to commence operating until the start of the 1996-97 financial year, because they will need to have passed into law before the drafting of the 1995-96 budget appropriation bills. As the budget bills directly integrate with the financial framework, they cannot be drafted to anticipate that a new FMA Act will be law.

I caught the tail end of Senator Margetts's speech where she posed a question to me. My understanding of that question is that Senator Margetts wants a list of those CAC bodies that are not covered under section 11 and those that would be embraced by this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I want to know whether ADI is covered by this bill or the next bill.
—My advice is that ADI is covered in these bills. On that basis, I commend the legislation to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bills in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
Debate resumed from 7 December, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add "but the Senate:
(a)notes that the Pharmacy Agreement, whic h is the subject of this Bill and which is to take effect from 1 April 1995, is still being negotiated by the Government;
(b)notes that this is far from being the only instance of the Government legislating in anticipation of a set of circumstances which are still to be resolved; and
(c)condemns the Government for its continual treatment of the Parliament as a rubber stamp of executive action".

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 [1995] amends the National Health Act to give legislative effect to a new pharmacy agreement between the government, the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia. The amending bill replaces the essential pharmacy allowance for pharmacists in rural areas with two separate allowances. It stops grants to pharmacists who close or amalgamate their pharmacies as part of pharmacy restructuring arrangements. It also provides a new professional allowance to qualifying pharmacists for the performance of specific activities not directly related to the supply of pharmaceutical items. As well, it replaces the existing Pharmacy Restructuring Authority with the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority. The new authority will make recommendations to government on applications for approval to supply pharmaceutical benefit items, to pay allowances to pharmacists in isolated and remote areas and to pay allowances for specific professional services.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that the new agreement, due to take effect on 1 April, has not been signed. The government is taking legislative action in anticipation of an outcome. The current health insurance legislation is another example of such conduct, and the administrative establishment of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority last year proceeded in advance of the parliament's approval. I think it is incumbent upon us to make a point of this, because we need to highlight the government's arrogant treatment of parliamentary processes as a rubber stamp for executive action. I know that is not the first time it has occurred, but yet again we must stand and demonstrate our disapproval of this type of action.

Another matter that I want to bring to the attention of the Senate is that the Pharmacy Guild has also pointed out that the proposed professional allowance, with a total allocation of $2 million annually, does not go very far when notionally distributed among 4,000 pharmacies nationwide. It works out to be about $500 per pharmacy throughout the nation. It sounds like a great gesture, but yet again it is another example of the government coming out with something that, on the surface, looks to be a very good proposal but, in practice, means very little.

I would also like to draw the attention of the Senate to the pathetic excuse for an explanatory memorandum accompanying the bill. We had that evidenced again in discussion of a bill this morning. An explanatory memorandum which merely paraphrases the actual words of the bill, without any real attempt to explain or understand the bill's provisions, simply makes a mockery of the processes of the parliament. I have moved my amendment in the second reading stage, noting that the bill anticipates an agreement not yet signed, and criticising the government for treating the parliament as a rubber stamp by passing legislation to legitimise a set of circumstances still to be finalised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take very long on this bill. It is quite a simple piece of legislation. We will support the bill, and we do not have any amendments. The legislation provides for a new agreement covering community pharmacy. It is a continuation of the pharmaceutical restructuring program which has been going on for several years—a program which is supported by the pharmacy industry and which, I think it is fair to say, has been largely successful in its goal of rationalising the number and distribution of approved pharmacies across the country. As of December last year, the total number of pharmacies throughout Australia had declined by about 10 per cent, and more than 400 pharmacies were receiving the essential pharmacy allowance to ensure the supply of pharmaceuticals in remote and isolated areas.

PARA.TAB: As the minister in her second reading speech said, the restructuring agreement has also contributed to a period of relative stability between the government and the pharmacy industry following a prolonged period of conflict in the late 1980s. This is not to say that the restructuring process has been trouble free.

When the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs looked at the restructuring program in 1992, it found a number of problems—problems that were exacerbated by the fact that key criteria for many of the restructuring measures were not clearly defined. In short, while the committee had no major concerns about the policy behind the restructuring, our examination of the processes revealed something of an administrative nightmare. I have some concerns that this legislation may be a recipe for a similar set of problems, although I hope this is not the case. The community affairs committee has more than enough to do.

This bill represents the next step in the restructuring process. It replaces the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority with the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority. This new authority will make recommendations in respect of applications for approval to supply pharmaceutical benefits, the payment of allowances to pharmacists in remote and isolated areas, and the payment of allowances for specific professional services. From July of this year, the essential pharmacy allowance will be replaced by two new allowances: the isolated pharmacy allowance and the remote pharmacy allowance for pharmacies in isolated and remote areas which have a low number of prescriptions.

These allowances underpin one of the goals of the restructuring program which was to encourage and maintain pharmacies in remote areas. That is an extremely important goal, and I believe that it is appropriate for the government to assist pharmacies to stay in these sorts of areas. People living in remote areas suffer considerable disadvantage when it comes to access to health and other services, and it is certainly appropriate for government to offer some level of assistance to what are essentially private services in order to keep them operating in those areas.

The bill also provides for a new professional allowance which will be available to qualified pharmacists for the provision of specific activities not directly related to the supplier of pharmaceuticals. This is where I do have a few concerns which relate back to the earlier problems faced by the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. Nowhere in the legislation or in the explanatory memorandum—or, for that matter, in the minister's second reading speech—does it spell out the circumstances in which this new allowance will be paid.

I hope the minister can provide some additional information to this point today during the debate, because it does seem to me that, with the new professional allowance in particular, we are back once again in the land of the vague and the uncertain. We are once again dealing with something where the key criteria are not defined in the legislation and where the rules of the game are going to be set up by the minister.

Given the previous problems in the restructuring process, I just want to add a cautionary note here that such rules—the criteria for the payment of the professional allowance, in particular—need to be very clear and very certain. If they are not, we are simply going to be making trouble for the new Australian Community Pharmacy Authority, which will be the body making the decisions.
Those concerns aside, the Democrats do not have any major problems with this bill. We will be supporting the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 amends the National Health Act 1953. It also presents the legislative framework for a new agreement, which is yet to be signed, between the Commonwealth and the Pharmacy Guild, in order to replace the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority with the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority.

PARA.TAB: The Pharmacy Restructuring Authority administered a restructuring program of the industry which saw 639 pharmacies relinquish their approval to supply pharmaceutical benefits—61 received the amalgamation grant and 578 the closure grant, at a total cost of $42.37 million dollars: $4 million to amalgamation payments and $38.367 million to closure payments.Applications for new pharmacies to obtain a PBS approval was, likewise, tightly monitored, and a stringent criteria had to be satisfied before approval was granted.

The pharmacy restructuring program was designed to achieve a more efficient distribution of pharmacies as well as to cap the rising costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This rationalisation has seen the number of pharmacies Australia-wide reduced from 5,549 to 4,981—a 10 per cent reduction.

The pharmacy industry is currently tightly restricted in all states with ownership of a pharmacy limited to pharmacists, and the number of pharmacies an individual pharmacist can have an interest in is clearly prescribed. In Queensland over 70 per cent of the registered pharmacists have a pecuniary interest in only one pharmacy. It is overwhelmingly an owner-operated industry.

There are strong legitimate reasons which explain why the ownership of pharmacies should be so tightly controlled, and all these reason act to the benefit of the consumer. The primary reason is that `pharmacy' is a profession as well as a business. Pharmacists have a duty of care obligation to their customers, and the usual retail axiom of `buyer beware' does not apply when the health and lives of Australian consumers are potentially at risk if proper advice is not provided by the pharmacist when dispensing pharmaceuticals.

In exercising this duty of care, the pharmacist must weigh up his professional and ethical obligations to his customer against the commercial considerations of his business; overwhelmingly, this delicate balance will always be in favour of the customer. It is also widely acknowledged that, as well as pharmaceuticals, pharmacists dispense professional advice and counsel on a wide range of minor ailments afflicting their customers, which in many cases removes the necessity of a visit to the GP and reduces pressure on the health system.

The individual accountability of pharmacists is another important argument for maintaining regulations that ensure pharmacists should not have financial interests in more pharmacies than they could personally supervise. Great public benefits clearly flow from the present pharmacy regulations held by all the states. These regulations governing the pharmacy industry would seem to be at odds with the Hilmer national competition recommendations.

What effect will be had on the pharmacy industry by the government's impending national competition legislation based on these recommendations which the government wants to implement by July this year and has been reported in the media as willing to go over the top of the states, if necessary? Hilmer's competition recommendations repeatedly return to his central proposition that `the competitive conduct rules in part IV of the Trade Practices Act should apply uniformly and universally to all business activity, including the professions'. It is further stated that `competitive conduct rules are aimed at protecting the competitive process and thereby avoiding misallocation of resources and inefficiency which adversely affects community welfare'.

According to Hilmer, exemption of particular business, sectors of business or kinds of conduct has the potential to include inefficiency and disadvantage consumers. `There should be no regulatory restriction on competition, unless a public benefit is clearly and transparently demonstrated.' This public benefit exemption would not be granted in perpetuity but would be subject to regular review by an independent body, involve a public inquiry process and include a public assessment of the costs and benefits of the restriction.

The national competition framework has received bipartisan support in this place and support by all the states. However, our enthusiasm to embrace competition reform as a panacea for our economic woes and a means to boost our economic performance should not come at the expense of full and rational debate on the matter. We must not compliantly embrace a university professor's program of radical change—no matter how well received, without wide ranging debate.

Up until now, the debate has been running all one way as though there were a $22 billion pot of gold at the end of the Hilmer rainbow. But the effects of Hilmer's competition reforms will resonate throughout the economy and the community, and this must be fully canvassed.

In our haste to reap the economic benefits forecast to flow from competition reform, such as boosting our GDP by $22 billion, as indicated in the media coverage of the leaked Industry Commission report into the effects of the competition reforms, we must not baulk at examining all of the Hilmer propositions, the benefits and the downsides, and the possible adverse consequences that could arise as a result of the sweeping economic change.

We have to ask ourselves what sort of Australia we want. Do we want every industry sector exposed? At present only the newsagents and the pharmacies are a strong part of the retail sector. Over the last 15 to 20 years we have seen inroads made into all major sectors of the private retail industry. Seventy per cent of the grocery market is controlled by three industries and most other retail industries—the butcher, the hardware stores, all major private retail industries—have lost market share to the corporate sector of the retailing industry.

Currently state legislation quarantines pharmacies from competition from the big retail chains. The chains would say the pharmacy industry is uncompetitive and needs opening up. However, these free enterprise assertions must be weighed up against the fact that our present pharmacy arrangements give Australia one of the best, if not the best, pharmaceutical systems in the world in terms of both the price of pharmaceuticals, which are at half world parity price, and equity and efficiency, in that the distribution of community pharmacies means that all Australians, including those in rural and remote areas, have a reasonable access to a pharmacy or the means to obtain pharmaceuticals within the maximum 24-hour period.

Australians are indeed fortunate to live in a country that currently maintains such an equitable, orderly and efficient pharmaceutical and health system. The efficiency of this system is reflected in the total cost of health care of eight per cent of GDP compared with that bastion of deregulation and competition, the United States, which has a huge health bill around 14 per cent of GDP.

The question has to be asked: why would we want to change a system that works so well and so equitably and to the benefit of all Australians in both metropolitan and rural and regional areas simply in order to comply with a radical economic program that in this case we do not know will give any increased benefits? If the regulations governing pharmacy ownership were relaxed by compliant state governments in conformance with the federal government's competition policy, owner-operator pharmacies would be greatly disadvantaged and most, if not all, would lose market share to the retail chains.

We have seen, as I said before, the decimation of the small business retail sector. The butcher, the baker, the local corner store, even the larger independent grocery store, and the hardware store, which were once integral elements of our retail landscape, are now greatly reduced in number. The spectre of deregulation is currently looming over newsagents and it seems likely that the 4,500-strong pharmacy industry will be the next retail sector subjected to an economic analysis of its laws and regulations governing ownership. Once one state relaxed or removed its pharmacy ownership controls, the floodgates would be well and truly open and the retail chains would move quickly to grab a share of the pharmaceutical market.

The three retail chains command 70 per cent of the total grocery retail market and independent pharmacies, particularly those in rural and regional areas, would find it as difficult as the other retailers to compete against the huge buying power that the chains have. Let us be quite certain about this: the three chains are hovering in the wings waiting for the pharmacy ownership to be opened up. Our largest retailer, Woolworths, is on the record stating that once ownership regulations were relaxed it would open 500 dispensaries nationally. Undoubtedly, the other chains would soon follow suit to increase store traffic and compete effectively with Woolworths.

We have only to look at the US experience to receive a sobering warning of the potential consequences for the independent pharmacy industry if supermarkets were allowed to open pharmacies. In the United States supermarkets generate around 25 per cent of the total US prescription volume. Supermarkets with pharmacies have a much higher turnover rate than those without pharmacies and a strong trend has emerged showing that most chains build new stores with dispensaries as those without are viewed as uneconomic in the long term.

Allegations of predatory pricing practices employed by the chains to force the independents out of business are periodically raised in the US. The US journal Nard recently reported that a group of independent pharmacies in the mid-west filed predatory pricing charges against retail giant Walmart for selling prescription drugs at 20 per cent below the average wholesale price, an action that was eventually settled out of court. In America, Walmart is the largest US retailer, yet it commands only 2.4 per cent of the total US market. In comparison, Woolworths, our biggest retailer, commands 31 per cent of the total grocery market, Coles-Myer 25 per cent and Franklins 14 per cent.

In the United States the largest 10 retail chains dominate 10 per cent of the total US market compared to our three biggest dominating 70 per cent of the grocery market. In the US independents cannot compete against their big retailers in a far less concentrated grocery market than ours. What hope would our independent pharmacies have against the might and massive buying power wielded by our big retail chains?

It is instructive to look at the United Kingdom situation, which has a national health dispensing approval system similar to ours. The biggest chain of pharmacies, Boots, has announced that it will increase its market share by 30 per cent over the next two years from 840 pharmacies to 1,080, with a new store opening every 10 days. Boots will open these pharmacies whether it obtains national health approval or not as the chain is able to carry an uneconomic, unapproved pharmacy by means of cross-subsidisation until successful in lobbying the government for an approval.

The UK experience shows that the big pharmacy chains are a very effective lobby in obtaining national health subscription approvals where independent pharmacists have failed. It is difficult to see how the situation would be any different in Australia. Once the Pandora's box of pharmacy regulation was opened, the consequences would be irreversible and, without a doubt, the independents would lose immediate market share, culminating in a greatly reduced pharmaceutical and pharmacy industry.

While pharmacy ownership is a state matter, the Commonwealth, through its function of issuing pharmaceutical benefit approvals, obviously has a major input into the future of the industry. It is well within the Commonwealth's powers to maintain the present pharmaceutical arrangements in all states by giving an undertaking when the new agreement is signed with the Pharmacy Guild that it will not issue pharmaceutical benefit approvals to supermarkets. Such a commitment to the pharmacy industry would be quite consistent with the minister's second reading speech asserting that the number of approved pharmacies is now at the correct level and in view of the $40 million that was spent in an industry restructuring program to achieve that outcome.

By approaching this Hilmer report we are now moving towards a change in economic circumstances. Unfortunately, in life the game is not played on computers or on paper; it is played out there in the field. There are a number of issues that do not come up on the computer model. Those are the lives and the futures of Australia's small business community.

The pharmacy industry has been a particularly successful one, advising and dispensing not only pharmaceuticals and drugs but also advice. I do not think that there is anyone in this parliament who would want to see that industry being hurt. I believe that we are facing a problem in Australia at the moment. We are going to deregulate all things for a $22 billion benefit. After allowing many businesses to dominate markets over the last 15 to 20 years, we are going to topple that domination process and bring in deregulation. That will give the three massive chains in Australia tremendous market power and tremendous market domination. I think that has to be looked at very closely before we make any decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 [1995], which will amend the National Health Act of 1953 and give effect to the new pharmacy agreement between the federal government, the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia. I will just give a brief overview of what this will mean.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will actually see the essential pharmacy allowance for pharmacists in rural areas replaced with two separate allowances—the isolated pharmacy allowance and the remote pharmacy allowance, which will target pharmacies which operate in remote areas, as the name would suggest, and would have a low prescription volume. Other changes will include the cessation of grants to pharmacists who close or amalgamate their pharmacies in line with the pharmacy restructuring agreement and will provide a new professional allowance to qualifying pharmacists for the performance of specific activities not directly related to the supply of pharmaceutical items.

The changes will also see the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority replaced with the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority, and I do not think there would be too many pharmacists around Australia who would be sad to see the PRA disappear. The new ACPA will make recommendations to the government on applications for approval to supply pharmaceutical benefit items, the payment of allowances to pharmacists in isolated and remote areas and the payment of allowances for specific professional services.

Prior to the introduction of this legislation, we are told, the government consulted widely with key industry groups—the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society. However, it is apparent that it has not consulted with consumer and community groups, which is a very important process for any legislative change such as this. The government needs to find out how this will impact upon the communities of rural and remote areas in Australia—areas which are already greatly disadvantaged by government policies on health.

I view this as a very serious admission, especially considering that last year in the government's national rural health strategy it was stated that, in providing integrated cohesive health services tailored to community needs and developing and implementing rural health strategies, there should be increased community consultation and participation in the planning of rural health services and an integration of the activities of rural health interest groups.

A further cause for concern is that the new pharmacy agreement, which is due to take effect on 1 April 1995—of course, it has not yet been signed—means the government is taking legislative action in anticipation of an outcome. This is not a dissimilar process to that which is occurring with the current health insurance reform legislation. It is objectionable that the government arrogantly treats parliamentary processes as a mere rubber stamp of executive action. Having had witness after witness in the health reform bill area tell us that they have not been consulted, I am not at all surprised that people in rural Australia have not been consulted about this.

Of course, further mockery is made of the political process when one reads the explanatory memorandum which accompanies this bill. It makes no attempt to explain or understand the bill's provisions. With respect to the amendments in question, I understand that the Pharmacy Guild has welcomed the replacement of the PRA with the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority, particularly given that the new authority will have a more independent chairperson. Pharmacists right throughout Australia have been asking for that ever since the PRA came into existence.

The pharmacy board of New South Wales is concerned that this bill does not go far enough to address the additional problems in the area of pharmacy restructuring. These problems principally include the need for branch pharmacies in remote or isolated areas and the problem of leapfrogging where pharmacies have closed and moved from one location to another, creating additional pressure on existing pharmacies in the area. The guild also pointed out that the proposed professional allowance, with a total allocation of $2 million annually, does not go very far when notionally distributed among Australia's pharmacies, which total more than 4,000 nationwide. So no-one really seems to know how that figure has even come into being.

There is also a need to ensure that, while subsidising pharmacies in rural and isolated areas, there is also prompt access to prescription medicines and drugs in times of need. I have raised this subject many times before, and particularly when so many pharmacies in country areas were closing down a number of years ago and people were actually having to travel hundreds of kilometres to get pharmaceutical services and facilities when their one town pharmacy was closed down. The statistics all point to the disadvantages of which I speak because those people in rural Australia are already gravely disadvantaged when it comes to health matters, and their prompt access to a whole host of medical facilities and services and treatments, including prescription drugs, needs to be assured.

In an article entitled `Rural Health Problems Exposed' in the Australian in August last year, it was reported that a paper prepared by the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health at the Australian National University on health of rural dwellers had dispelled the myth that life was healthier in the country and found that the government spends less on rural patients than urban ones. People in the country are very much aware of that.

The report found that rural dwellers were much more likely to become sick and die earlier and that rural women were the worst off, as they were almost 90 per cent more likely to die from pneumonia or influenza than women in the city. They were also 50 per cent more likely to die in a car crash or from diabetes and tended to be more overweight and smoke more than city women. Other causes of death which have increased markedly in rural people over city people are heart disease, stroke, respiratory problems, general injury, poisoning, and genito-urinary infections, including sexually transmitted disease.

One of the key differentials is that rural Australia's access to utilisation of specialist health services is far less than for urban Australians. Both male and female rural people tend not to visit a doctor when they suspect that they are ill, and most attribute this to the distance they need to travel to access the service of a general practitioner. That is why it is still significantly important that they have the availability of pharmacists because, in many cases with less serious illnesses, people do go and consult their pharmacies. That is why the closing down of country pharmacies or the inaccessibility of country pharmacies is of great concern to country people.

Clearly, this points to a need for an urgent response to the health outcomes of rural Australia. Long-term and short-term actions should include a better, all-round package of health care for Australians in rural and remote areas of this country, especially one which targets Aboriginal people, who are undoubtedly the worst affected by the government's lack of effective rural health strategies.
In the introduction to the government's national and rural health strategy of March 1994, all of the problems I have just mentioned plus more are identified. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Some health problems such as mental illness, youth suicide, injuries, road trauma, alcohol and substance abuse are most acute in the rural areas and provide ample justification of the need for a specific rural health strategy. Aboriginal communities in particular are characterised by unacceptably high levels of morbidity and mortality. The incidence and prevalence of such problems as ear infections, eye diseases, diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular problems, communicable diseases, respiratory disorders, kidney disease and skin infections are often well in excess of those for the wider community.
That is something that we simply cannot tolerate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
