SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition welcomes this review. It points out that, both in terms of legislation and administration, the management of aged care is a morass of bureaucratic regulation. The review makes more than 80 recommendations and suggests sweeping changes to laws governing the aged. It places the emphasis not on regulation but on the outcomes and processes which will enable older people to maintain dignity, independence and control over their lives and quality of life.

PARA.TAB: Many senior citizens do not understand their entitlements and do not understand what is required to get into a home. When they do get into a home they are reluctant to complain or demand satisfactory conditions, services and treatment. This report confirms that the federal government's aged care program fails to satisfy the needs of an increasing number of older Australians. The coalition agrees with the general tenor of the report and supports the commission's recommendation that there should be a single aged care act that has a logical structure and is written in plain language. One of the other things about this report is that somebody has now listened to older Australians instead of telling them what is best for them.

This is a substantial report of about 300 pages and 80 recommendations. I have not got time in the five minutes available to me to deal with each of those recommendations. However, I will talk about the recommendations relating to consultation and planning. In relation to consultation, the commission recommends that the new legislation should reflect the importance of consultation to the aged care program. Consultation has not been a strong point in the department's handling and government's handling of the aged care portfolio.

Increasingly, and especially under the current Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), I am being told over and over again by peak bodies and other stakeholders in the industry that it is impossible to get an appointment to see the minister. If by some chance you are lucky enough to get an appointment it is not a consultation but a briefing on what the government intends to do. Genuine and appropriate consultation is a two-way process and it is vital if the best possible outcome for aged people is to be achieved.

The commission also recommends that planning should be needs based, should outline the process which should be open, transparent and flexible, include regular reviews of ratios and set out outcomes for the planning process. The report goes on at length to talk about the need for flexibility in the respite care and residential care areas. The commission also recommends that the legislation should set out outcomes for the assessment process and set out the steps in the assessment process. As I said before, the report talks a number of times about flexibility and emphasises the need for flexibility.

The commission has also suggested quite important changes to the area of domiciliary nursing care benefits. I have not got time to go into all of those recommendations. I welcome wholeheartedly the reforms it suggests. For too long eligibility for the DNCB has relied far too much on physical disability and dependency. The commission has also made a number of recommendations regarding funding—for example, that funding decisions should be transparent, the legislation should be set out on the grounds on which decisions are made, the conditions attached to the approval should be set out, the applicant's review rights should be outlined, and so on.

We sometimes forget that when we talk about nursing home residents we are referring to the most vulnerable, non-vocal, least empowered members of the community. It is up to us to ensure that the quality of life is as good as it can be. There is little point in the government revamping the legislation and using the rhetoric of caring when it refuses to fund nursing homes adequately. The three peak nursing home bodies have just issued a press release condemning the government and stating that they have received report after report which shows that the government is not giving sufficient funding to the SAM component of nursing home funding. We can have Law Reform Commission report after Law Reform Commission report, but unless the government addresses this issue it will fail to look after the aged and frail in our community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the report on the next triennium for higher education funding. It is difficult to know where to start because there are so many things to talk about. I will concentrate on four issues of great concern to me. The first relates to the allocation of research funding. The Industry Commission recently brought out a report recommending a change to the allocation mechanism for research funding in universities. The Senate will recall that a committee of the Senate investigated this and brought down a major landmark report last year. We certainly did not recommend what the Industry Commission is recommending.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission is saying that we should move research money out of the research quantum—over $200 million—and put it into the ARC. More money in the ARC is most welcome because it is a very successful research mechanism. I do not believe this is the way to do it. If you move over $200 million out of the research quantum in universities, what you are going to do is turn the great majority of them into teaching institutions and the money allocated through the ARC will largely go to the big seven. The concentration on research money that we already have in this country—that is, where two-thirds of the money goes to seven universities—will be therefore more concentrated under that system, impoverishing the other 19 universities.

We recommend that the overall level of funding for research be increased because it is desperately needed. There is not enough money in most of the mechanisms. At the moment, we have, in relation to ARC grants, a success rate of 16 per cent. The evidence before the committee last year showed that that rate should be closer to 40 per cent. The rate has dropped since the report from 19 per cent to 16 per cent.

The second issue in the report that I will mention is the credit transfer arrangements. This is an excellent idea. It has great potential for helping to smooth the articulation of students through the whole system. It has a great capacity, if the government realised it, to save money but it has not progressed very far. We have not progressed far since my sister-in-law transferred 30 years ago, when her husband moved to Queensland, from the University of New South Wales with eight-ninths of a degree to the University of Queensland. She was awarded four-ninths of that degree. She had one unit to go and they told her to go back and do another five units. That is a wasteful use of resources. We should think about the extra lectures, the extra material and the space in the university that was taken up by a student who should not have had to repeat the program. That was 30 years ago.

In relation to credit transfer in this country, even though there has been progress in reports, the actuality, as I discovered with my daughter recently, has not changed at all. She was facing exactly the same problem—transferring between universities and losing a great deal of the credit.

The third and final thing I want to talk about is the quality assurance mechanism mentioned in this report. There is some danger and some fear that the $80 million will move out of the university system. There is at the moment a report to the minister on the second round. We are all very anxiously awaiting the outcome of that report. There is considerable fear in the universities that the third round will not occur and that the funding will not be reallocated but, in the budget cuts that are coming, will probably disappear altogether. This would be a great pity.

We obviously need to reform quality assurance greatly, but our fear is that the $80 million that should be reallocated to the infrastructure needs of universities, the re-allocation that is needed for extra places, will disappear out of the system entirely. That would be a tragedy for the university sector, which is already considerably under-funded. More money is needed for teaching. More money is needed for research. More money is needed for infrastructure. But if this $80 million quality assurance disappears, situations in the universities will be made much worse. This report before the Senate allows me to underline starkly that after 12 years of Labor rule there are still massive problems in the university sector in this country because the government has not been able to fund this sector adequately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could have made my same remarks on item No. 9, but I want to concentrate on the employment part of this portfolio. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, joins other world leaders at this very moment in Copenhagen at the United Nations summit for social development. The aim of this conference is to explore how millions of strugglers—not only the traditional poor in third world countries but also the new underclass of out-of-work professionals—fit into the world which seems increasingly to have left them behind.

PARA.TAB: The United Nations Secretary-General cites research which shows that one out of every 10 people of working age cannot find a decent paying job. He says, `The world is suffering from a social and moral crisis.' Unemployment is one of those misery benchmarks that are used at this conference. Australia still has a very high unemployment rate and we cannot go to that conference thinking that we can lecture to the rest of the world. On its raw figures Australia's unemployment rate is nine per cent and its youth unemployment rate is 27 per cent. But behind those figures lies a deeper, more serious social concern. In raw unemployment terms, that places us behind the United States, Japan, Germany and even our closest neighbour, New Zealand.

Figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics really highlight the deep social concern we should have in regard to those raw figures. The ABS labour force figures released today show that there are more than 700,000 children under the age of 15 living in families where neither parent has a job; there are over 300,000 children in couple families where neither parent has paid work; and there are near on 400,000 children in one-parent families where that parent does not have paid employment. The statistics released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics also show that some 568,000 Australians were or considered themselves underemployed. The serious social ramifications in those figures are quite obvious to both sides of the chamber.

Moreover, a trend in December and January has quite clearly shown the number of part-time or casual employed. For example, in the December figures—and this trend continued in the January figures—while the employment rate increased ever so slightly, for which the government took great kudos, the information behind those figures shows that the increase was really due to some 62,100 part-time jobs, and that was leading up to Christmas. So the vulnerability and the uncertainty in the workplace still exists. In that month of December full-time employment actually fell by some 18,000 jobs. As I said, that trend continued in January. That is a very concerning trend, particular in regard to youth.

The University of Adelaide's Centre for Labour Studies issued a report last month which said that the trend is set to continue beyond the year 2000, particularly in the youth market. So all those new opportunities in employment for youth between the ages of 15 and 24, according to this survey, coming on to the market really means that the majority of them will be able to gain only casual or part-time work. TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of matters I want to address in tonight's adjournment debate. The first is to record with great sadness the death last week of Mr Justice Brian Treyvaud of the Family Court of Australia. Justice Treyvaud was not an intimate friend of mine, but I did become acquainted with him during the time that I was chairman of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. It was about that time I first met Justice Treyvaud that he became a member of the Family Law Council of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I found Mr Justice Treyvaud to be a very decent human being and a very likeable individual in the brief contact that I had with him. I found him to be very reasonable in all of the discussions I had with him and I was able to test various proposals that I had in mind in terms of the inquiry that the committee was conducting at that time. This was also true of him in the more general sphere of life. He was a great human being in the limited contact I had with him.

My reason for speaking in the chamber of a person whom I did not know intimately is that of the shock his death brought to me. It was only last Thursday night that Senator Cooney, my wife and Mr Justice Treyvaud had a meal in the dining room of this house. I know Senator Cooney wants to say much more about Mr Justice Treyvaud because he obviously knew him much more intimately than I did.

I also want to put on the record tonight the text of a press statement that I issued on 2 March entitled `Interdiction may have to be considered'. The reason for taking this unusual approach to my press statement is that it has received quite an inordinate degree of attention as far as I am concerned. All through yesterday and today I have received requests from members of the opposition in the other place for a copy of the statement. I have also had numerous requests through the parliamentary library for a copy of this statement. Since there is such an interest in the statement, I shall indeed put the whole statement on the record. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The press statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MEDIA RELEASE
"INTERDICTION MAY HAVE TO BE CONSIDERED?"

"Australia will have to consider implementing a policy of interdiction and turning boats around at sea if the Bill relating to China's One Child Policy is defeated. The Bill is currently before the Parliament" Western Australian Labor Senator Jim McKiernan said today.

Senator McKiernan was commenting on the Coalition Senator's dissenting reports to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee report on Migration Legislation Amendment Bill No. 3 (1995). The Opposition Senators' were joined in dissent by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Democrats, and Independent Senator Harradine.

"I appreciate that interdiction would be a most serious step to take and should only be considered as a last resort, but the Government will have to consider it if the Bill is lost. I would anticipate that hundreds of thousands of people from China and some other Asian countries will shortly be making plans to get to Australia. They will hear, if they have not already heard, that the numbers are in the Senate to defeat the Bill".

"This serious action, which would have a negative effect on Australia's International reputation can be avoided if the Opposition Leader, Mr Howard acts immediately, decisively and positively. His first action should be to sack his spokesman on Immigration, Senator Jim Short. While Senator Short did not sign the dissenting report, he was involved in it's development".

"Mr Howard must also act to neutralise the influence that the secretive National Civic Council has on his Party. The NCC influence has already caused his Party to make an embarrassing backdown on the Compensation Bill (Migration Amendment Bill No.3 [1994]) which was passed this week in the House of Representatives, after it had been defeated in the Senate last year".

"Turning boats, that carry illegal migrants to Australia, around as sea, may be the only way to stop the flood gates opening and protect Australia in the long term. The antics of a leaderless, but power hungry Coalition in opposing responsible legislation, is sending a message that Australia is a soft touch".

"Irresponsible decisions in our Courts, and I refer particularly to Mr Justice Sackville's decision of November last year, which expanded the definition of Refugee Status, has embellished the view that Australia is an easy target for those who profit by providing passage for boat people".

"The mixed messages coming from the Australian representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Australia is also of great concern. Mr Fontaine is publicly contradicted between his evidence to the Senate Committee and personal correspondence which found its' way to the media".

"Outrageous statements from NCC inspired asylum support groups that distort the aims and objectives of the Bill and Government policy, are further exaggerated and given credence in the media. This further compounds and confuses the signals being sent to Asia. People who want a better life will, in their thousands, maybe tens of thousands, make their way illegally to Australia".
"How can Australia stop people who already have two and in some cases three children, making claims for refugee status based on China's One Child Policy?".

"How can Australia stop illegals blocking up our Court system (after they have failed to gain refugee status), if there is an army of lawyers prepared to give them FREE legal advice and representation?".
"Can Australia limit the availability of free legal representation to illegals from the various Legal Aid Commissions of Australia?".

"Can the Legal Aid Commissions justify expending scarce resources on illegals when they continually complain that they have insufficient funds to meet the demands on these resources from Australians who are lawful and legal in this country?".

"Stopping the illegals landing in the first instance would be one way of solving these problems, but this action should not even be considered until Mr Howard is given an opportunity to put things right in his own Party. If he puts Australia and the Australian taxpayer's interests before those of the illegal boat people, pledges support and passage of the Government's Bill, then the last ditch action of interdiction need not be considered.
For further information contact Senator McKiernan on (06) 277 3416 or 018 949 681
2 March, 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —I add to the eloquent remarks made by my colleague and friend Senator McKiernan about the death of Brian Treyvaud. William Brian Treyvaud, a Justice of the Family Court, died in Melbourne on Friday, 3 March 1995. The fact that on the previous evening, as Senator McKiernan has already pointed out, he had been a delightful and apparently fit dinner companion for Senator McKiernan, Jackie Watkins and me here in Canberra shows the suddenness of his death.

PARA.TAB: Brian's family was central to his life. Lillian and I extend our sympathy to Joy, his wife and a person of great courage, to his children, Robyn, Penny and Philip, to his daughter-in-law, Vicky, and to his grandchildren, Thomas, Amy Ben and Samantha, for their fearful loss. They will be comforted in their sorrow by the knowledge that Brian was a man and judge of great merit and was recognised as such by the community.

I first met Brian in the common law courts. He was a considerable advocate, whether addressing a jury or judge alike. The number of verdicts he won shows the truth of that statement. Many more personal injury cases ended in settlement than in judgment. This is fortunate because the legal system could not otherwise cope with the volume of work given it. It is better, too, for the parties to agree upon an issue rather than have it decided for them.

The practice of settling cases flourishes only when those negotiating them are faithful to their word. What Brian said he did, and never was there a doubt he would do otherwise. Advocacy tests the temper. Brian always passed the test with high distinction. He was constant in his courtesy, attentive in his audience of others and truly fair in the resolution of a matter. He carried these characteristics on to the bench.

Judging is an exacting task. Where the rule of law is diminished, so is the integrity of the community and the wellbeing of each person in it. Accordingly, how our judges perform determines the quality of the society we live in. Brian was forever conscious of his judicial responsibilities. He received evidence fairly, he listened to submissions patiently, he applied the right law to the true facts to the best of his remarkable capacity, he reached his conclusions with equity and he gave his decisions clearly and with dispatch.

Brian was a sociable man. He proved a good friend to others in every sense of the word. Brian relished the colour, the culture and the company of thoroughbred racing. It provided him with a break in a very busy schedule. Brian was a believer in Christ and his teachings. Brian's family and friends look forward to seeing him at the resurrection.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Education: Funding in New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —The New South Wales government, desperate to cling onto office, is engaged in one of the most misleading campaigns ever seen during an election campaign in living memory. It is engaged in a blatant misrepresentation of the sources of education funding for schools in that state. It is a sinister exercise designed to mislead the public of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Since coming to this chamber I have had the opportunity to visit a number of schools in New South Wales, particularly to represent the federal Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) at the opening of new facilities at those schools. What is abundantly clear is that the New South Wales government is seeking to use these openings to mislead the public into thinking that it is solely and totally responsible for the provision of these facilities.

Let me cite two recent instances. On 23 February I attended the opening of some new facilities at the Kurnell Public School in Sydney. As I approached the school that morning, I found there was a large sign outside the school which said `The New South Wales government—building better schools'. But what are the facts? The facts are that the total cost of those new facilities was of the order of $1.4 million and of that amount $1.1 million was contributed by the Commonwealth government. Seventy-eight per cent of the total construction cost of those facilities was contributed by the federal government but very little, if any, acknowledgment was given by the state government at the opening. In fact, a sign, as I said, outside the school said that it is the New South Wales government which is building better schools.

On 3 March, last Friday, I attended the opening of new library facilities at Cobar High School. These facilities were opened by the New South Wales Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, who gave a very grudging acknowledgment of a cooperative approach, as she said, with respect to the provision of these facilities. But, again, what are the facts? What did the minister not tell the people there? What was not told was that the entire construction cost of that new library, $388,000, was contributed by the Commonwealth government.

Around the state of New South Wales in the months of February and March in the lead-up to the state election this scenario is being repeated almost on a daily basis. The Premier of New South Wales and his minister for education are running around the state opening up schools and TAFE colleges that have been overwhelmingly funded by Commonwealth government funds. Over 72 per cent of the capital costs of these schools and colleges is being met by the Commonwealth government.

What is even more sinister than not revealing the real sources of this funding is the timing of these openings. In the month of February and March 1995 but prior to the state election on 25 March, new facilities in 45 schools will be opened in New South Wales—45! As I said, the overwhelming proportion of the funds is being contributed by the Commonwealth government.

I thought to myself that maybe it has something to do with the fact that the school year starts in the end of January and that there might be some coincidence here in terms of the timing of the opening of these new facilities and the school year. So I checked for the same two months of last year, February and March of 1994, and what did I find? How many new facilities were opened in New South Wales schools in February and March of last year? One new facility was opened. One new facility was opened in February and March of 1994, and 45 were opened in February and March of 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they win the election.

—I do not think we will have to worry too much about that, Minister. In the entire year of 1994, 33 schools with new facilities were opened in New South Wales. That is 11 fewer than have been opened in these current two months. But the cynical, deliberately misleading exercise gets worse. In some of the cases, the facilities at those schools have been finished and operational for many months. In fact, at the Lucas Heights Community School, which is near where I live, the project was finished in 1993. The school was opened on 22 February this year. Out of the total cost of $13.8 million, the Commonwealth contributed $10.5 million.

PARA.TAB: Here we have the state government claiming that it is building better schools. In other cases, the facilities have not even been finished but, in the state government's desperate rush to cling to office, it is opening them anyway. I am advised that at Lidcombe TAFE the buildings will not be finished when it is opened. There is no structure sufficiently advanced to put a plaque on, so they are going to plant a tree. It is going to be opened up before it is even finished.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does all this cost?
—It is costing a lot of Commonwealth money.

—Senator, one understands that occasionally there might be a bit of pork-barrelling that goes on in election campaigns, but the New South Wales government has taken it to new extremes. It is pork-barrelling with someone else's money. The people of New South Wales will see through this cynical exercise by the New South Wales government and recognise that education and the provision of educational facilities are not just something that the New South Wales government claims to provide solely. It is not just solely and totally building the new schools and the new facilities of New South Wales. Notwithstanding the fact that it is primarily a state responsibility, a significant proportion of Commonwealth funds is going into these new facilities.

PARA.TAB: This government, as we know, has a proud record in respect of the provision of education, increasing school retention rates and the provision of new facilities around the country. That will continue under a federal Labor government and it will certainly be immeasurably improved under a Carr Labor government when it is elected on 25 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about the unbelievable cynicism of the federal Labor government in respect of the failure to release compartments for logging to the New South Wales logging industry. The federal government has not taken into account the fact that this is a decision about people. It is about people like Don O'Reilly, 44, who is a timber contractor. He is married to Katheryne and has two sons, Dean and Ross, aged 19 and 17. It is about people like David Johnson, 37, who is a pulp and log truck owner. He is married with two children aged 13 and 12. It is about people like Tim Beddingfield, 42, who is an excavator-operator. He is married and has two children aged 13 and 10. It is about people like Anthony Batten, 19, who is a nightwatchman.

PARA.TAB: You might ask, `What do all these people have in common?' These 15 people all rely on Badja compartment 64 in New South Wales for their livelihoods. This week the government put the livelihood of each and every one of these people in jeopardy because compartment 64 has not been released by the federal government's shonky list in this 11th hour attempt to help that all-Australian guy, Bob Carr, win on 25 March.

Today the Canberra Times reports that, if New South Wales Labor wins on 25 March, with the help of the green seats and its decision making process of the last three months, most of the 399 remaining coupes presently protected will be permanently set aside for export woodchipping on conservation grounds. Let us not forget that the federal government has very little say as to whether a coupe is logged or not.

The other day Senator Collins pointed this out in the Senate in answer to a question. He likened the federal government's power over woodchipping to having hold of the tail of a dog. It has the power to license for export, but in terms of the moratorium controlling logging based on high conservation value it does not have that power. The federal government does not have it, and neither does the federal minister.

Depending on viability, Badja compartment 64 could still be logged and the by-product of the sawlog operations will be burned instead of bringing in valuable export dollars. The federal government cannot prevent the logging of this particular compartment, but it can say that it is non-economic because the woodchips would not be available for export.

This is a very cynical exercise to buy green votes. It could subsequently mean that the areas that are presently protected will not be protected after the New South Wales election. This parliament has seen such political opportunism, such shoddy policy making and such a shambles that threatens to throw into turmoil the lives of 30,000 timber workers in New South Wales and about 85 timber workers Australia-wide. This week's decision is a complete about-face by the Commonwealth on the south-east forests agreement signed only in December 1993. In essence, it is a regional forest agreement of the type provided for under the national forest policy statement. You would have thought that the cabinet would have come up with a better excuse than deficient state government assessments. Cabinet members and the rest of this government know what a shocking lie it is.

This afternoon the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) in the other place clearly blamed the New South Wales government for not providing enough information about the conservation value in the coupes it wanted to release. He said that the areas remaining on the list would be considered at the end of the month—naturally after the New South Wales state election. If the Minister for Resources is right and if his claims are accurate, why did Senator Collins not raise these concerns about the nature of the information the New South Wales government provided through the nine telephone calls he had with the responsible New South Wales minister, the Hon. George Souris, during the last two weeks? Why were these concerns not raised and these issues discussed at the meeting held between the Commonwealth and the state officials in Sydney on 13 and 14 February? How can the government possibly claim that its decision, which will affect the jobs of hundreds of workers according to the union—the CFMEU—has been made because of anything other than political reasons? Michael O'Connor, the national secretary of the CFMEU, said today:

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows that on March 25 there's a state election . . . and to have NSW not have any logging coupes released before the 25th March quite clearly smacks of them attempting to support their mate Bob Carr.

Oh, what a mate! Mr Carr brought out his forest policy today—a $60 million package. That is another $60 million on top of the $15-odd billion worth of expenditure that he will saddle the New South Wales government with over the next three years if he is lucky to be elected. The main aspect of that—I am sure timber workers will be interested to know—is retraining. It is going to retrain and redeploy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Waiters.

—They can look forward to that. New South Wales has under way an EIS program which is by far the largest ever undertaken in the southern hemisphere. Sixteen EISs are being done at the cost of $1 million each. About 30,000 hectares of state forest are under moratorium pending the completion of these EISs, which are independently determined by the Department of Planning.

PARA.TAB: The Natural Resources Audit Council has recommended a program of regional audits, the first one covering three million hectares of the upper north coast of New South Wales. No less than four separate government agencies oversee public forest operations in New South Wales: the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Soil Conservation Service, the Environment Protection Authority and the Department of Planning.

The decision by the federal Labor government to restrict the release of any compartments has today seen its first victim. The closure of Coastline Timber, which employed 13 men, is a massive blow to the Moruya community, where it pumped around $1 million per year into the district economy. The sad thing is that Moruya is the first of a long list of towns that could be affected in the same way. Towns like Coffs Harbour, Glen Innes, Casino, Bombala, Lismore, Walcha, Wauchope, Kempsey, Captains Flat, Cooma, Drake, Urbenville and Bonalbo are some of the towns that will be affected in the same way.

It is really criminal what this Labor government has done to these honest, hardworking Australians who would be expected to vote for it. If they were not traditional Labor voters, these decent, hardworking Australians would expect their government to govern for them and their communities in a non-sectional and generous manner. It is a very sad reflection on the sectional interest way that this Labor government governs when these groups of ordinary Australian working men and women are affected in this way. They certainly feel let down and excluded from the decision making process.

The inability of the opposition leader in New South Wales, Bob Carr, to deliver a forest policy today will be seen by the electorate as no more than a cheap political stunt aimed at helping New South Wales Labor win at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the situation faced by 35 former employees of McDonnell & East who have been unable to access their superannuation entitlements due to a deficiency of over $500,000 in their superannuation funds.

(2) Given that responsibility for this shortfall has been denied by both the trustee and the fund manager and the former employees have legal advice that they have an excellent case for taking legal action against the trustee and fund manager, and also given the inability of regulatory authorities to assist due to the situation occurring at a time when those authorities had no powers and the reduced amount of funding available for legal aid:
(a) are there any discretionary powers available to the Minister or the Government to provide financial assistance to a test case such as this; and
(b) is the Minister or the Government prepared to consider an application from the former employees or their representative for financial assistance with any such legal proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The legislation applicable in this case does not provide for a shortfall in the defined benefits of a superannuation fund to be addressed. The discretionary powers available to the Government to provide legal aid come under the portfolio of the Attorney-General. I have referred the second part of your question to him for reply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 1 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1841 regarding Asset Services, and in particular to paragraph (3) which indicated that when undertaking non-Commonwealth work Asset Services must make allowance for all indirect taxes such as payroll tax, sales tax, customs duty, excise duty, fuel tax, financial institutions duty, bank account debits tax and stamp duty: does this mean that when tendering for Commonwealth Government work, Asset Services does not pay payroll tax, sales tax, customs duty, excise duty, fuel tax, financial institutions duty, bank account debits tax and stamp duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: When undertaking work for the Commonwealth Government Asset Services pays customs duty, excise duty and fuel tax. Asset Services, like its private competitors, does not pay sales tax when undertaking Commonwealth Government work. Asset Services does not pay or make allowance for State payroll taxes, financial institutions duty, bank account debits tax and stamp duty when undertaking work for the Commonwealth Government. However, the impact of these taxation arrangements on the competitive position of Asset Services cannot be assessed in isolation from a range of other factors. For example, as part of a Commonwealth Department Asset Services does not have access to various industry assistance programs that are potentially available to its competitors. Successive studies have demonstrated that when all major differences in the operating circumstances of Asset Services and its competitors are taken into account, including taxation factors, Asset Services operates at a net competitive disadvantage in bidding for Commonwealth Government work.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) When is it expected that the Government will commence work on the building of Sydney's second airport at Badgery's Creek.
(2) How many runways are planned for Badgery's Creek.
(3) Does the Government consider that the current Environmental Impact Statement for Badgery's Creek is adequate or will a new more up to date one need to be commissioned.
(4) What is the timetable for negotiations leading to the privatisation of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport.
(5) Is it intended that Sydney's proposed second airport at Badgery's Creek also be privatised.
(6) Is it intended that Kingsford-Smith or Badgery's Creek be the principal airport for Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government remains committed to meeting the 1998-99 timeframe for the commissioning of the major aircraft runway which it announced last year. The precise timing for the commencement of construction of Sydney West Airport will be considered by the Government in the Budget process.

(2) The master plan for Sydney West Airport is based on two widely spaced parallel runways with lengths of 2,500 metres and 4,000 metres. It is proposed that, in the initial development announced by the Government, a 2,900 metre runway will be built on the alignment of the 4,000 metre runway proposed in the master plan.

(3) The Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), completed in 1985, was based on the planned ultimate development of a major domestic/international airport on the Badgerys Creek site. A number of subsequent studies were undertaken as a result of the EIS. The Department of Transport and the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency are currently examining the possible nature and extent of any further environmental assessment that might be required.

(4) Options for the disposal of the lease for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport are being prepared as part of the scoping study into the sale of all Federal airports. These will be considered by the Government in the near future.

(5) The Government's policy is that Sydney West Airport should be leased as part of the disposal process for Federal airports. Options for the future development and ownership of Sydney West Airport are being examined in conjunction with the scoping study into the future of all Federal airports.
(6) Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is likely to continue to be the primary airport for Sydney for the foreseeable future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Environment, Sport and Territories: Brewing Kits

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many home brewing kits were purchased by the Antarctic Division during the financial year 1993-94 and the current financial year to date.
(2) Why were these home brewing kits purchased.
(3) What is the total cost of purchasing these home brewing kits.
(4) What are the upkeep/ongoing costs of the home brewing kits.
(5) Where will these home brewing kits be located.
(6) When obsolete, what happens to the home brewing kits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Each "kit" comprises a small can of ingredients for production of home-brewed beer.

(2) Food and beverages are provided to all expeditioners at Australia's Antarctic stations on a pre-determined ration scale per person per year. Beer produced by home brewing forms part of this ration.
(4) The kits of ingredients are fully expended in the brewing process and no upkeep is involved. Minor costs are incurred for bottles, stoppers and sterilising agents.
(5) Casey, Davis, Mawson and Macquarie Island.
(6) The ingredients in the kits are fully expended in the production of the brew.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the purpose of the consultancies by McIntosh Corporate Limited, Melbourne and Potter Warburg and Co Limited, Melbourne, which cost $818,500 each, into Qantas PSO.
(2) What was the outcome of these consultancies.
(3) Who paid for these consultancies.
(4) Why were these consultancies required.
(5) What was the reasoning behind these two consultancies.
(6) How were these consultancies allocated.
(7) What other costs were involved with these consultancies.
(8) What were the total costs of the two consultancies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) McIntosh Corporate and Potter Warburg were engaged under a single contract, through the Task Force on Asset Sales (A) within the Department of Finance, to act as Joint Lead Managers (JLMs) for the Qantas sale. In their role as JLMs, the two firms have been contracted to provide a wide range of specialist advice and assistance on all aspects of the Qantas public share offer generally and in particular on the proposed offer structure, both domestic and foreign; valuation issues; pricing structure and strike price; the preparation of the prospectus; liaison with the ASC and ASX and conduct of specialised marketing seminars to share brokers and potential institutional investors.

(2) The JLMs have been advising and assisting the Task Force since the consultancy was awarded in August 1994. On 31 January 1995, I announced that the Government had been advised that given current market conditions, it would be prudent to make best use of the time available under the Qantas Sale Act, and go to the market between mid-May and mid-July 1995. The precise timing of the offer has not yet been determined but the JLM consultancy will not be completed until the end of the offer period.
(3) The cost of the consultancy will be met solely by the Department of Finance.

(4) and (5) The consultancy is necessary because the relevant specialist skills and industry presence required to ensure the tasks outlined at (1) are completed, are not available from within the Task Force on Asset Sales nor from elsewhere within the public sector. It is normal commercial practice for Lead Managers to be appointed to assist with public share offerings. To illustrate, some recent examples of major share floats which involved Lead Managers include GIO, Woolworths, Channel 7, the CBA Secondary Share Offer and CSL Limited.
(6) The consultancy was allocated following a competitive selection process which involved proposals from a number of suitably qualified and experienced firms.

(7) Some additional costs may be incurred under this consultancy. The contract provides that the Task Force on Asset Sales may direct the JLMs to procure various services through sub-contracting arrangements. These services may relate to activities associated with the provision of Mailhouse services; Banker to Issue services; printing of the Prospectus and related documentation; design of the Prospectus; the Share Information Office; marketing and advertising; and distribution of the prospectus. As at 21 February 1995, the Task Force has not directed the JLMs to procure any such services.

In addition, the JLMs will incur costs in assisting with the organisation, management and conduct of the specialised marketing seminars mentioned at (1), (including the provision of logistical support) within Australia and overseas. As at 20 February 1995, the Task Force on Asset Sales has not been invoiced for any costs associated with these seminars.
(8) Payments made for this consultancy, up to 20 February 1995, total $450,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What type of craft is used for sail training and recreation within the Royal Australian Navy.
(2) When were these craft purchased and from whom.
(3) How many were purchased.
(4) What was the cost of the initial purchase.
(5) Which company(s) are able to supply replacement parts for these craft.
(6) What is the total amount spent to date on craft and replacement parts since the initial purchase of these craft.

(7) In the 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years and the current financial year to date, what is the total amount spent on accommodation, travel, expenses, remuneration and transportation of equipment on sending: (a) navy; (b) army; and (c) airforce personnel to sporting events, both within Australia and overseas, whatever the event.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are three types of craft used for sail training, these are:
(a) Swarbrick Yachts (11 metre);
(b) Tasar Dinghies (4.5 metre); and
(c) Endeavour Yachts (7.3 metre).
(2) (a) Swarbrick Yachts from Swarbrick Bros (WA) in 1983.
(b) Tasar Dinghies from Starboard Products Pty Ltd (NSW) 1985 and 1991.
(c) Endeavour Yachts from Endeavour Yachts Pty Ltd (NSW) in 1970.
(3) (a) 6 Swarbrick Yachts.
(b) 82 Tasar Dinghies in 1985 and 40 Tasar Dinghies in 1991.
(c) 3 Endeavour Yachts.
(4) (a) Swarbrick Yacht unit price in 1983 was $110000.
(b) Tasar Dinghy unit price in 1985 was $3865. Tasar Dinghy unit price in 1991 was $7050.
(c) Endeavour Yacht unit price in 1970 is estimated at $6000.

(5) As a recognised `racing class', the Tasar Dinghies have certain parts such as sails, keel boards etc which are generally purchased from the boat manufacturer, Starboard Products Pty Ltd, to keep these craft in `class'. These are normally purchased by the Navy Supply Centre and forwarded to the users on request.
For all other items for the Tasars and the other craft, replacement parts are generally available through marine merchants, ship chandlers and sail makers.

(6) The total amount spent in purchasing the three types of craft used for sail training and recreational activities within the RAN since the initial purchase is $1,279,000. The total amount spent in purchasing recommended spares for these craft is $369,000.

(7) Sporting activities are part of normal military life. They assist in maintaining a high level of fitness for Australian Defence Force personnel and contribute greatly to team building and morale. The cost of answering this part of the question would be prohibitive and I am not prepared to authorise the time and expense involved in obtaining the information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs the following question:

(3) What was the purpose of these fridge calendars.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the reasoning behind the Government's decision to base illegal immigrants at RAAF Base Curtin.

(2) (a) How long does the Government intend to use RAAF Base Curtin as a detention centre for illegal immigrants; (b) what assurances can be given that this use of Curtin will not be a long-term arrangement.
(3) How many detainees does the Government intend to house at RAAF Base Curtin.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) An interdepartmental Task Force identified RAAF Base Curtin as the most suitable site for short term accommodation for the following reasons: it was immediately available and could be made operational at very short notice with relatively little modification; and it was available on an `if required' basis with no costs incurred unless the site was activated as an immigration reception and processing centre.

(2) (a) The Acting Minister for Defence approved my Department's use of the base until 31 March 1996. The Government does not intend to activate RAAF Base Curtin for use as a detention centre unless the need arises.

(b) A Memorandum of Understanding with the Department of Defence has been signed which states that the agreement takes effect on date of execution and terminates on 31 March 1996. Investigations of alternative sites for longer term accommodation of boat people are continuing.

(3) It is not known how many detainees would need to be accommodated at RAAF Base Curtin. This will depend on whether it needs to be commissioned. The base has an initial accommodation capacity of 300.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has caused the delay in deciding the fate of an application for funding for a secretariat for the Australian Women's Health Network.
(2) When will the decision be announced on funding for this important service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The delay in announcing the outcome of the 1994-95 Community Organisations' Support Program (COSP) national secretariat grants funding round, including my decision on the application submitted by the Australian Women's Health Network, was caused by discussions being undertaken about concerns raised by a number of national organisations in regard to the four year limited term seed funding grants.
In response to these concerns, I have decided to conduct a review to address the issues raised. The review will be undertaken in the first half of 1995.
(2) A letter advising the Australian Women's Health Network of my decision on their application was dispatched on 20 February 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australia's support for World Health Assembly Resolution 47.5 on infant and young children nutrition, adopted in May 1994:
(1) Is the free and low cost distribution of infant formula highly detrimental to encouraging mothers to breastfeed.
(2) Why has the Commonwealth Government failed to stop the supply of free and subsidised infant formula in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There have been no national studies to investigate the effects of the distribution of free and low cost supplies of infant formula on breastfeeding rates in Australia.

Recent national studies of breastfeeding rates indicate that the rates are generally high at discharge from hospital (about 85 percent) but these rates decrease rapidly following discharge, falling to about 40 percent at six months of age.

The reasons for this decline are being investigated in research commissioned by the Commonwealth Government. Results are expected by mid-1995 and will be used for developing health promotion strategies to increase the acceptance and length of breastfeeding.

(2) The State and Territory governments as the recipients and/or purchasers of infant formula, and the infant formula manufacturers and importers are the two sectors which would be directly involved in ceasing free and subsidised supplies of infant formula.

The cessation of free and subsidised supplies is within the jurisdiction of the States and Territories and it is inappropriate for the Commonwealth to do more than encourage the States and Territories to adopt best practice in their provision of health services. It has urged the States and Territories to take action to cease these supplies by bringing this matter to their attention through correspondence and placing the issue on the agenda of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC). A meeting of all concerned parties was also convened by my Department and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs in November 1993 to discuss this issue. Western Australia and Tasmania support the cessation of free and subsidised supplies and are planning to take some action to stop their acceptance and use in the health care system.

The Trade Practices Act prevents the infant formula companies from collectively agreeing to a suitable price at which to sell infant formula supplies to health units, however two infant formula manufacturers have taken unilateral action to cease free and subsidised supplies—one in only maternity hospitals and the other in all hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the news summary produced by the department's public relations section called Daily Defence News Summary.
(1) Who is responsible for the selection of clippings, production and distribution of the summary.
(2) What is the annual cost of the summary.
(3) What are the specifications for the content of the summary.
(4) Who receives copies of the summary and on what basis.
(5) At what time of the day is the summary compiled and distributed to subscribers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Defence Public Relations using the service of Media Monitors ACT Pty Ltd.
(2) The cost for the production of Daily News Summary for 1993/94 was $25,148 including copyright.

(3) Defence Public Relations instructs the contractor, Media Monitors, to search all news items relating to Defence and associated defence issues. Defence Public Relations routinely briefs the contractor about current defence-related issues and

ANSWER.PARA: key words are used to identify and source media material.

PARA.TAB: (4) Within resource constraints, the summary is distributed to those who need to be informed about issues the media is covering and who have a possible requirement to address or respond to media inquiries. Recipients of the summary include:
my office; the offices of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence and relevant shadow ministers; and
the Defence Higher Executive and selected First Assistant and Assistant Secretaries and one and two Star Officers.

In addition, the summary is provided to selected Defence project directors and Defence Attaches overseas and is sent to all Defence Public Relations regional offices for distribution in the regions. Defence libraries also receive a copy of the summary.

(5) The Daily News Summary clips are received at 0730am and compilation and preparation for dissemination made in Defence Public Relations—Canberra and is completed no later than 0830am. Depending on the size of the News Summary and because of the large number of recipients and volume pressure on facsimiles, distribution is sometimes not complete until 3pm.
